movie_review_blurb: Tupac's legacy deserves better -- and so do the fans.
However watchable the second outing may be, Hart and Cube should pull up to the curb and bring their much-milked ride to a stop with this sequel for fear of exhausting the formula even further.
Lathan, Ealy and Chestnut do their best with the poorly-written script but even their experienced acting chops fail to save the copycat thriller.
Foster is wickedly brilliant in his portrayal.
Todd Haynes has crafted a visually stunning picture with Carol, a lesbian love story brought to life with remarkable performances by Cate Blanchett and Rooney Mara.
Yorgos Lanthimos's black comedy is entirely strange and a head-scratcher but its core message is certainly relatable to a large demographic.
Cranston is certainly unforgettable but Trumbo is by no means a one-man show.

While Focus is fun, with intrigue, twists, and turns that will likely only hold up to one viewing, the romance ends up being the focus. Unfortunately, loyalty between liars doesn't equal a love story.
It's a fairly standard murder mystery with some good acting and an ending that comes out of nowhere.
Director Catherine Hardwicke, who is known for making movies about women (yes, even Twilight sort of counts), is unsparingly honest when it comes to depicting human behavior in relationships.
Although the film follows a somewhat traditional script, it also deviates -- because superheroing while female is a radical act.
This setup for a pretty standard situation comedy ought to lead to heartwarming hilarity. It doesn't.
Damien Chazelle, the writer/director behind the Oscar-nominated Whiplash, set out to make a musical romance, but his new film La La Land transcends both genres.

[Whit] Stillman has finally achieved what he now seems to have always been working towards: the merging of his contemporary bourgeois comedies of errors with the literary precedents that inspired them.
The film works because it swerves and slips and slides around itself with a sort of thrilling abandon.
Even with the melodrama and comedic elements, there's a deep sense of sincerity to performances happening on-screen.

A mix of scripted and real-time improv performed throughout adds to the film's nuanced emotional playing field-an impressive feat as the Commune struggles with their own understandings and frustrations.
It's an exceptional look at the strength of empathy and openness in a world seemingly hellbent on destroying such ways of living.
Overall, if you're a fan of the spy genre, there's a lot to like in Red Sparrow. If you're like me, however, you may be left wanting a bit more.
A dynamic and original film we're so thrilled for you girls and boys to see.

It's an intelligent and emotional film, which (judging by the struggle the filmmakers had of getting an American distributor) proves that Darwin is still making people think, more than 120 years after his death.
The sweet sincerity that Yi portrays makes her an ideal documentary host and subject in this touching, low budget documentary.

The Time Traveller's Wife makes for an enjoyable enough movie experience, if all you are after is a few tears, a nice romance and a frequently naked Eric Bana; but viewers unfamiliar with the novel might be left wondering what all the fuss was about.
The slapstick comedy will amuse a young audience, but their parents will find it tedious.
This is Miley's first dramatic role, and it proves that she should stick with her popular TV character.
As with most romantic comedies, this misunderstanding could have been resolved with a simple question, but instead the film stumbles along towards its predictably happy conclusion.
A tense and interesting psychological thriller.
There are a few moments where the romance is overdone, and the film verges on being too sentimental, but those scenes are saved by the sweet performances of its cast.
Rather than delving into the issues presented by a clash of cultures, this film diverges into frivolous romantic comedy territory but still offers plenty of laughs
The story is predictable and the acting is not always natural, but StreetDance 3-D is enjoyable to watch, thanks to the impressive dance sequences...and there are plenty of them.
While the windswept locations are dramatic and the performances are touching, this simple story is too drawn out to be completely compelling.
With witty dialogue and astute comedic performances, this film parodies the clich√©s of other teen movies but still feels fresh.
While the film begins as an intriguing and tense thriller, the latter half veers into ridiculous melodrama.
Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs 2 is full of cute food puns and enough on-screen action to keep kids amused. Whatever your age, it's really hard not to enjoy this film.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Audiences new to this world will likely find themselves confused, with too many different elements stuffed into one movie.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: First time feature writer/director Maggie Carey has crafted a genuinely funny and refreshing female teen sex comedy.
Marling and Batmanglij deliver again with a smart script focusing on timely themes, such as the rise of the Occupy movement, the dangers of fracking, and recent environmental disasters.
Despite having a fairly standard haunted house horror plot, James Wan has created a fun, scary and beautiful looking movie.
While the two leads have terrific chemistry; this is largely a predictable love story which skims over the more hard-hitting aspects.
Could have benefited from extra editing to lift the more leaden moments.

Never deviates from the romantic comedy guidebook. It delivers exactly what you would expect, and nothing further; tears, laughter, romance, and plenty of cute baby moments, awkwardly wrapped in a tragic situation.
Nobody expects A Haunted House to be a masterpiece, but in going for the easy joke, the film missed out on many opportunities for satire.
There's no denying the charms of these frank-talking little Freds and Gingers, and the film delivers the expected dose of pathos and humor.
Eddie Murphy proves he doesn't need a fat suit to play soft in Karey Kirkpatrick's surprisingly nuanced family comedy.
This effort soundly delivers the inconvenient truth to the generation who'll inherit it.
The screenplay retains the gritty emotion of its source but gets ponderous in the iconic third act.
Wakefield anchors the well-paced quieter moments.
By the time the Ganesha cake is cut, you're left with the poodle as the only family member worthy of empathy.
The emperor penguin waddles forth as an exemplar of family values in first-time director Luc Jacquet's quiet, engrossing documentary.
Perfection never enters into director Mark Rosman's insipid comedy drama.
Blanchett never curtsies to caricature. Her interpretation is complex, restrained, warmly sensual.

It takes guts to make a personal film, and Smith's tender characterization of Alyssa proves he's got the goods. Never mind the convenience store or the mall: this time he dares to set his New Jersey story in the heart.
Without this emotional edge, Buffalo '66 ends up like the hard-luck football team at its center: it just misses.
The film mocks Selena's short life by dragging on forever.
This tale about the genius of paradox presents its own curious puzzle: how a life of such epic passion and tragedy can elicit so little emotional pull.

As director Megumi Sasaki's leisurely yet absorbing documentary tells it, the crusty postman and the mild librarian emerged as the Fred and Ethel Mertz of modernism, championing the early careers of such artists as Sol LeWitt and Christo.
Barrymore aces her 16th-century elocution, but her vampy magnetism -- always her dominant charm -- is snuffed in this goody-goody role.
Little Voice loses its way at points, especially in its hurried, portentous ending. Yet it never obscures the blinding talent of Horrocks.

Although a contrived plot and heavy-handed symbolism hobble the story, the film delivers several revealingly funny moments, and it transcends its claustrophobic setting with a fusion of cin√©ma-v√©rit√©, hazy filters, and march footage.
No matter how hard My Fellow Americans tries, there's no competing with the real-life high jinks of that wacky White House. Think Ford taking a tumble or Bush puking in Japan. Now that's funny.
Despite flashes of bawdy humor, Can't Hardly Wait is just like its beer: it starts out frothy but soon goes flat.
Hayden Panettiere provokes many emotions as the title object of desire in Chris Columbus's dreadful teen romance. Love is not one of them.
Taken as an assault against self-pity and sentimentality, this War puts up an involving, and ultimately thought-provoking, fight.
Throughout, the terrible script and garish, pointlessly 3-D visuals distract -- why do all the women, among them Flint's weather-girl crush (Anna Faris), look anorectic?
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This retread of recent rom-coms, with yakky aspirations to Woody Allen, is none the edgier for Westfeldt's indie roots and hip cast. In fact, it's maddeningly conventional and clich√©d.
[A] surprisingly sympathetic portrait of a bitch on the brink.
Winter may be a moving symbol of resiliency, but Smith's film unfortunately sticks to shallow waters.
This G-rated Disney documentary about two wild feline "families" plays like Saw for six-year-olds.
[Thomas] remains a mesmerizing mix of carnality and class, and through richer and poorer, she keeps director/co-writer Catherine Corsini's bourgeois fantasy from overheating.
Boring, pointless, and instantly forgettable, this return to Jellystone Park is no picnic.
Flashbacks of the hazing go down like meta-torture, as Bell overacts and the clich√©s stack up.
Though supporting players Jane Lynch, Michael Keaton, and Burnett make a valiant go of it, the film, perhaps a casualty of its own meandering aspirations, never graduates to anything special.
Revelations that the 75-year-old comic is needy, hard-driving, and relentlessly self-flagellating aren't all that surprising.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: If the images of poultry without beaks don't inspire a trip to Whole Foods, the mouth-watering harvest of an organic farm in downtown Milwaukee will.

Cuts from rich nation (birthday cake) to poor (tub of viscera) are predictably pointed but not always thematically coherent. Still, the film stops short of it's-a-small-world platitudes to elicit awe -- and awwws.
Snicker all you want at the unfortunate title of director Roger Kumble's horrible family film, for that's the only thing funny about it.
The topic may be urgent, and the fallout heartbreaking, but this clumsy treatment barely passes.
As a pregnant single woman, Jennifer Lopez glows spectacularly. Director Alan Poul's bland baby comedy, however, appears to have been a light labor.
Middle-school antihero Greg Heffley may depict himself as a comic illustration in Jeff Kinney's bestselling kids' books, but director Thor Freudenthal turns him into an outright caricature.
The gripping yet hyperbolic drama examines the ownership of art and the public's right to it.
The indie trifecta of clunky voiceover, scrambled chronology, and dream sequences can't fatten the slight story.
By the end, the film has slipped into TV-ready hagiography while nonetheless inducing the urge for a crisp white collar and French cuffs.
Crammed with more recycled offal than a can of Alpo, Marmaduke exults in fart jokes, offensive stereotypes (the cat, voiced by George Lopez, laps guacamole), and sloppy storytelling. Bad, bad dog.
At one point, F√©licie's ballet teacher tells her that she has "the energy of a bullet" but no technique or focus; the same is true of Ballerina itself.
Fatally, the film cannot make up its mind who its target audience is.
As much as the claustrophobia of watching him alone spinning his wheels reinforces the idea of a man trapped, the story soon runs out of momentum.
None of it is especially effective as satire, either - apart from a throwaway reference to how boring some of the race can be. But Tour De Pharmacy is good for a giggle or three.
The film may not be revelatory as an expose of two Hollywood icons, but as a celebration of love and resilience as captured in the smallest moments of their lives, it is remarkable.
movie_title: Bright Lights: Starring Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It is a surprisingly profound portrait of an artist, and all the more affecting for the connections made to the emotion and humanism of his work.
Fans of the man, who arguably invented post-modern observational comedy "about nothing" (and yet about everything), will be delighted by the set-up.
The visual and verbal humour is cartoonish rather than clever and it recycles gags seen in far too many animated films, such as animals in a high-speed car chase.

Eastwood masterfully re-creates the blood-curdling fear and panic on the train, contrasting that with the men's astonishing courage as the rest of the passengers do what most people would: Freeze and cower.
Borowczyk has woven such a mesmerising tapestry that the audience can't help but continue to watch as it slowly, senselessly unravels.

The film's artistic credentials are boosted by Borowczyk's virtuoso use of close-ups and point-of-view shots, which lend something of the unexpected to an otherwise slavish blow-by-blow, over-long enactment of the novel.
La Grande Illusion retains its power as an example of European camaraderie and co-operation.
Electra, My Love mesmerises from the very beginning.
This silent Czech tale of seduction continues to mesmerise with its sensual portrayal of female sexuality.
While Wayne stole the show in the original film, Steinfeld easily takes the honor this time around with a performance that belies the actress's age and experience.
For a category that could serve as a showcase for the next generation, it's an opportunity wasted.
"The Lost Thing's" unusual steampunk aesthetic brings to life a first-person narrative that really resonates in its 15 minutes.
movie_title: The Oscar Nominated Short Films: Animation (2011)

movie_review_blurb: "The Rite's" insistence on chewing over Michael's snoozer of a spiritual crisis keeps the story from taking hold and taking us anywhere at all.
As a crime-fighting duo, Britt and Kato have the sophistication and finesse of a pair of middle school boys on a joy ride.
To comment upon meaninglessness by creating something entirely meaningless yourself is hardly a way to make your point - let alone get people into the theater.
Be prepared for an emotionally devastating portrait of a marriage that, at times, feels like an eavesdropping expedition.

This is a film bursting with words; much of it elegant dialogue, some of it energetic bursts of profanity. But Lionel and Bertie's close relationship is built soundly upon them, and it's a believable bond.
Director Tony Scott's frequent doses of visual adrenaline, combined with admirable restraint in both the script and lead performances, make for an exuberant ride that avoids the curse of the corny.
"Tangled" is a welcome reminder of why we call [Disney] the Magic Kingdom.
Ralston may be pinned in one spot, but Boyle's camera is anything but, taking us to every place a frantic mind could wander while under such strain.
It's a classic you-stole-my-identity setup, and director Jaume Collet-Serra delivers it tightly enough to keep you engaged, despite many obvious signposts leading the way.

In this refreshing twist on a familiar format, director Tom McGrath combines flawless 3-D animation with a bevy of comedic talent to craft an entertaining adventure with plenty of smart, grown-up laughs.
Despite being packaged as a thriller, "Hornet's Nest" lacks the urgency and suspense of the previous films.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Hereafter is the perfect example of an intriguing concept in need of some collaborative brainstorming between a talented writer and a visionary director, followed by a few rewrites.
Instead of remaining true to the much darker graphic novel, "Red" goes for the funny bone, using what amounts to wink-and-a-nudge stunt casting that never gets past its own cleverness.
Kosinki's most imaginative 3-D contraptions are stunning, though it's unfortunate that they don't show up until we've slogged through a slow, dreary, middle bursting with overblown political themes.
Feels as wholesome as a Norman Rockwell illustration, hitting just the kind of nostalgic chord the game inspires in those who grew up playing it.
movie_title: Under The Boardwalk: The Monopoly Story (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Cool enough to position the movie as the thinking man's blockbuster, but "Inception" it isn't.
No matter what you take away from director Tom Shadyac's philosophical treatise "I Am," you have to admit its timing is eerily apt.
Gives contemporary audiences the chance to embrace this cultural phenomenon on their own terms with (near) total seriousness and superior special effects.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: They actually made a real movie beneath that crazy title.
Clean-cut, well intentioned and downright gorgeous, today's Captain America is a throwback to the good old-fashioned heroic ideal.
If this year's hit "Bridesmaids" is the woman's answer to the male-driven, R-rated comedy, then "Horrible Bosses" is a strong rebuttal.
While one can appreciate the film's rousing endorsement of our community college system, it's about as realistic as an episode of the TV sitcom "Community."
While we're grateful for Ordal's introduction to this atypical artist, the film's focus on the sentimental side of the story is at the expense of showing us enough of his terrestrial achievements.

While the little ones will have plenty to feast their eyes, ears and short attention spans on, grown-ups should accept that this is one Pixar effort that treats the adults in the audience more like baby sitters.

As familiar as "Submarine" looked, it's hard to overlook Ayoade's natural skill as a storyteller with an affinity for character and humor. If he grows into his own visual style, he's definitely a filmmaker to keep an eye on.
Quite possibly the most emotionally wrenching, stunningly beautiful film I've yet to encounter - fiction or otherwise.
More than anything, "Super 8" is a straightforward love letter to those carefree days when anything felt possible as long as you had your friends, a movie camera and some semblance of a plan.
There are plenty of d√©j√† vu moments,...but before you know it, Phillips yanks you in an entirely unexpected direction, continually ramping up the stakes, the raunch and the visceral humor.
While "On Stranger Tides" is the shortest of the four "Pirates" films, its two-hour, 17-minute running time is still far too indulgent.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: What we get is a cultural standoff, and it's awkward, nonsensical and really funny.
Just like he did with "Super Size Me," Spurlock has cast himself as the underdog outsider trying to crash the corporate party and, while the results aren't as revelatory, it's easily as entertaining.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The director's clever use of extreme landscapes and surreal sets keep us immersed in a visually stimulating world somewhere between fantasy and reality.
McCarthy has finally delivered a realistic take on the male teen, along with a tender, funny look at family and what it means to be a man.
Guggenheim knows how to hit that sweet spot, where the head and heart meet, and where great ideas begin to transform into action.
When [Wasikowska and Fassbender] come face to face - his light eyes burning white heat, her porcelain neck quivering beneath his possessive grip - the atmosphere is explosive.
The magic is missing from X Men: First Class, and without it, the film's just an average superhero movie with a dark side and a groovy Bond-era paint job.
Even with his constantly affectless expression, Eisenberg gives Zuckerberg just enough vulnerability to make you not entirely hate him.

Bar-Lev's portrait of the outspoken Tillman family demonstrates another, more realistic side of American honor and integrity - one that values truth over what Mary Tillman derides as a "tidy and mythic" story.
With gunshots that roar like cannons and exhilarating car chases through Boston's narrow streets, the execution of the crimes is far more interesting and convincing than Doug's personal journey.
A sometimes brilliant takedown of modern American culture with a populist bent that would make Frank Capra proud.
A pleasant enough excursion into the growing genre of male-bonding cringe comedy, though not an entirely memorable one.
So maybe we're not on the brink of war with Russia, but this intelligent, exhilarating Cold War spy fantasy almost makes you miss those days.

As the dreams build upon each other and Cobb's past creeps through, Nolan has us just where he wants us -- deliriously lost in a world where dreams and reality are indecipherable, and curious enough to stand in line for another showing.
Director Daniel Alfredson has created a smart, stylish thriller that engages the audience while the mysteries are patiently revealed.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: My inner adolescent craves a role model who's got more going for her than a melodramatic crush.
By the time this crazy cast of characters settles into a rental house by the lake, the story has nowhere left to go -- except exactly where you expect it to.
My advice? Bring a tissue.
A costly, chaotic mess.
Sloppily edited scenes are worsened by desperate performances and dialogue that amounts to frenzied screaming and running about.
So, should you see it? If you're a SATC devotee, does it matter what this review says? It shouldn't.
Fresh, funny and, for once, a sequel worthy of summer blockbuster status.
As she has in four previous films, Holofcener smartly relies on Keener's talent to create a layered character who is neurotic and often inappropriate, but still good at her core.

Memorable performances from Johnson, the terrifically weird Cage and, especially, Moretz as the nimble Hit-Girl, make this an underdog adventure that will have you laughing, gripping your armrest and bursting into applause.
Imagine it: Liz Lemon and Michael Scott. Married with kids. I want to go to there.
Alice in Wonderland lands in a comfortable zone that should accommodate both kids and adults.
This Sundance hit is really about the universe within our own minds, whether it's the prisons of guilt we lock ourselves in or the fantasies we construct to escape.
Cholodenko has not delivered a pro-gay marriage treatise, but a funny, touching and relatable story about the colossal effort and love it takes to create and maintain a family.
What we're seeing isn't the aftermath of an extermination plot, as in the post-liberation concentration camp films, but the dehumanization process itself.
Even with Berman's halfhearted inclusion of a few angry feminists and appalled religious figures...it's hard to deny that Hefner might actually deserve the title the film bestows upon him.
movie_title: Hugh Hefner: Playboy, Activist and Rebel (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's easy to see how parents and teachers of school-aged kids could find "The Little Traitor" useful to begin an introductory conversation about tolerance and friendship. But the film's childish tone does little to enlighten the rest of us.
"I'm Still Here" is a film that gets in your face and under your skin. Kind of like a portrait wiped with the artist's excrement. It's disgusting, but it's still art. The question is, at what cost?
Lest you think this is some sappy "chick flick," be warned: "Going the Distance" has a lot more in common with the raunchy male-bonding comedy "The Hangover" than it does with "You've Got Mail."
Chamaco has all the bumps and bruises of a boxing-themed film, but its story is also a tender one about a young man coming of age, and a father and son mending a frayed relationship.
With so much working against the film, it's a genuine surprise when you find yourself entertained anyway, thanks to the strong comedic leads.
Comes off more like a female midlife crisis fantasy than a substantive search for knowledge and inner peace.
Remember Me actually does know exactly where it's going. It just takes too long to get there.
A well-acted little film, The Yellow Handkerchief captures the loneliness of these characters and the sparks of hope they harbor, despite everything.
Good luck with yourself, Greenberg. But I think I want to break up.
Even with all the sexual prerequisites met, Chloe feels more like a damp domestic drama than a steamy erotic thriller.
No matter what side you end up taking, you still might be tempted to call your lawyer to go over your will just one more time.
Sadly, the Kraken is far scarier in our imaginations. Just like the 1981 version is far better in our memories.
The setting is stark and simple - a semi-deserted, two-street town amid long, flat marshland - but Director Henrik Ruben Genz infuses it all with a dark, twisted beauty.
Although Feste delivers a well-acted, competently directed film with The Greatest, it ultimately lacks the originality that could lift it out of the fog.

De Felitta chose well by casting 24-year-old actor Steven Strait, who gives the exasperated convict humor, charm, and sex appeal - something that doesn't go unnoticed by Joyce, or many of the women in the audience as well.
We know by now that blatant, senseless consumption is bad, harmful even. But the biggest surprise about The Joneses is its skillful avoidance of any meaning or significance whatsoever.
The answers Garcia offers aren't necessarily satisfying; particularly for those who believe in adoption or (gasp) childlessness, but they are thought-provoking questions nevertheless.
Although Caine lives up to expectations in this nicely crafted (though violent) film, the oversimplified story he's given to work with keeps it from the top of Caine's impressive filmography.

Directed and co-written by Herzog (with Herbert Golder) and executive produced by Lynch,[the film] offers a whiff of originality in a sea of cinema schlock. But compared to both filmmakers' prior works, it's nowhere near as memorable.
movie_title: My Son, My Son, What Have Ye Done (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Writer/director Tate Taylor takes care to balance the at-odds themes of shameful social injustice, female bonding and outright comedy in this tale about African-American maids in 1960s Jackson, Miss.
This Norwegian import quickly surprises as a quirky, dark comedy reminiscent of lightweight Coen brothers.

By the time this flat, excruciatingly predictable film reaches its drawn-out, melodramatic (and unintentionally comedic) ending, we've not only stopped caring about Emma and Dexter, we're actively rooting against them.
Even during Pi's bleakest moments lost at sea, Lee's artistry gives us something at which to marvel
It's Kushner the playwright who moves "Lincoln" from uncanny historical re-enactment to near-mythic memorial.
"Skyfall" is as much a joyful trip down memory lane as it is a 21st-century Bond adventure.
In an outstanding, raw performance, Washington never strays from Whip's rough road of addiction and psychological turmoil.
With all that Cloud Atlas throws at you over the course of three relatively swift hours, something is bound to stick.
Despite the youth of its main characters, "Smashed" doesn't deliver much that's new to the sobriety genre.
Take away the regrettable late-1970s fashion and facial hair and director Ben Affleck's "Argo" is one timely, taut thriller.
The one thread that does run through Daniels' wildly fluctuating, self-indulgent film is a preoccupation with pointless perversity.
"Frankenweenie" is Burton boiled down to his wonderfully weird essence, coated with warm nostalgia for his early days as a filmmaker and his childhood as an artsy loner stuck in the suburbs.
It's not the most novel character arc in the world, but sometimes a story doesn't need to break new ground. Sometimes it's enough for it to feel comfortable, maybe even familiar, and make you smile.
It's Cooper who's the biggest casualty, forced to deaden his surefire spark to accommodate his dud of a character.
An unexpected and bitterly funny take on the misery of the modern, maladjusted woman.
A steady, though rather lifeless backwoods crime drama.
If it didn't star the universally beloved Gordon-Levitt, "Premium Rush" would quietly fall in the category of late-summer time killer for teenagers.
A bittersweet, quietly hilarious buddy caper that deserves to be the sleeper hit of the summer.
Friedkin creates a twisted work of trailer-park noir that both surprises and horrifies, and gives us one more reason to call 2012 the year of McConaughey.
For a film with Jason Bourne's DNA, this is the slow one in the family.
For all the guys who get whacked in gloriously grisly and stylized ways, there wasn't one moment when I cared even slightly who came out of it alive.
"Hitchcock" marks the first time Hopkins and Mirren have appeared together on-screen, and it's as fun to watch as you'd imagine.
Jackson's risky creative choices have drained Bilbo Baggins' adventure of its magic.
It's great that Apatow isn't afraid to dig deep to mine the uglier sides of matrimony, but his unusual personal connection to the material and the cast...is somewhat off-putting.
A Beavis and Butt-Head-style bank robbery comedy that leaves you longing for the intelligence and sophistication of a bachelor party in Bangkok.
Think of it, in the best way possible, as an intellectual's midlife crisis movie, which resonates all the more because we've known them - and aged along with them - for the last 18 years.
It gives Black and his co-writer Drew Pearce ample opportunity to showcase the natural ease with which Downey creates America's snarkiest of flawed heroes.
A twisty-turny piece of sci-fi escapism that mostly stands on its own.
Alvarez is relentless in his pacing, delivering blow upon blow with so much breathless gusto that you don't know whether to scream, vomit or laugh maniacally.

Nguyen creates a mesmerizing tone through his camerawork, editing, sound and the infusion of African folk imagery and ritual, but it's Mwanza's performance as Komona that makes "War Witch" feel so miraculous.
It's a little bit corny and sometimes too in love with its own cleverness - but it's also the most fun I've had at the movies this year.
It's all at the right level for a PG-13 audience, though older teens, and adults not accompanying kids, might find it all to be just a little too storybook.
A refreshing romantic comedy for the smart set.
A clumsy mess of supernatural hooey that conveniently shifts its rules and reasoning whenever the story needs a shove in the direction of its inevitable showdown.
A thoughtful little buddy caper comedy that wisely exploits the audience's natural affection for its aging stars.
A delightful set of films spanning genres, styles and the globe in just one outing.
movie_title: The Oscar Nominated Short Films 2013: Live Action (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Nearly overwhelms you with hopelessness, if not an adrenaline rush of rage - even if you're familiar with the case.

Apted possesses the unsettling ability to shape perceptions of their lives and personalities from inside an editing suite, a fact that the members of his flock begin to recognize at varying points throughout their adult years.
Ruben Fleischer's gleefully grisly shoot-'em-up is just one more chapter in the epic love story between Hollywood, guns and gratuitous violence.

Haneke treats Georges and Anne with absolute respect, never pandering to sentiment or clich√© and most assuredly not sugarcoating the experience of walking one's partner through suffering, toward death.
The suspense comes not from how we ultimately bring down bin Laden, but how Maya - and what remains of America's fraying do-gooder conscience - fares in the process.
It's not much of a stretch to call Tarantino's entertainment-oriented brand of revisionist history tacky, if not deeply offensive, but the energy and audacity with which he executes it is undeniable.

Although he can still kick it into gear when the situation demands it, it's not entirely clear if it's McClane, Willis, or maybe the franchise itself that's barely mustering up the strength to carry on.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A tragicomic indulgence of schadenfreude with the sophistication of a Kardashian reality show.
A delightful set of films spanning genres, styles and the globe in just one outing.
movie_title: The Oscar Nominated Short Films 2013: Animation (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Zeitlin's grainy, hypnotic feature film debut offers a child's fantastical perception of life at nature's edge.
Fincher delivers a well-paced story (even at more than 2 1/2 hours), without a lot of unnecessary Hollywood flash...
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Williams' delicate, underplayed performance demonstrates the actress' courage and confidence in her own talent to take herself - and her audience - inside Monroe's fragile psyche.
"Hugo" is as much a tribute to the medium that gave [Scorsese] life as it is to the magical world Selznick created in his illustrated book.
"The balmy breezes and small-town intimacy of island life give "The Descendants" a leisurely tone that distinguishes it from Payne's more angry-edged work."

Doremus reminds us of what love felt like the first time - before our hearts were dented, dinged or all-out broken - when we could fall irrationally hard, with pure intentions, and no idea that it simply can't stay that way forever.

We get straightforward narration and expository dialogue that introduces each time-traveling vignette and dictates Hoover's tiresome "me versus them" rationalizations for whatever unscrupulous thing he did to stop them.

"Tower Heist" and its cast still manage to hit a few functional notes that allow the film to pass as a serviceable comedy that will probably play best on Saturday afternoon cable (you know, where all the other '80s action-comedies live).
Durkin eschews the sensationalism so often associated with cults in favor of an intimate, psychological portrayal of the confusion, fear and mistrust someone in Martha's situation might experience.
Almod√≥var puts Vera on display like a piece of grocery store meat wrapped under cellophane, designed to be appetizing - as long as you don't think about where it came from.

"The Big Year" proves yet again that comedy isn't just magic that happens when funny people stand next to each other. They actually have to be doing or saying, or not doing or not saying, something that might inspire humor.
"50/50" is an unusual comedy that should be taken seriously.

Just like any baseball game, "Moneyball" has its slow points. But while you're waiting for something of substance to happen, there are plenty of worthwhile glimpses behind the scenes of a low-budget baseball club to keep your interest.
An enthralling piece of filmmaking in the same class as Martin Scorsese's "Taxi Driver," and Oscar-worthy acting that firmly places Gosling in the role of top-tier star.
As he did in his 2000 film "Traffic," director Steven Soderbergh weaves together multiple perspectives in a seamlessly edited collage.
Glodell's vision is a disturbing portrait of the first generation to come of age in a post-9/11 America.
There's no doubt that fans of the legendary Nolan trilogy will find a finale that satisfies.
Hey, man, if you've got Paul Rudd spreading sunshine in every scene, what's there to complain about?
When Fassbender is paired with McQueen, the actor is at his most intense, physical and even a little frightening.

The story and the silent-era conventions may not be entirely original, but the director revives this uniquely American storytelling style with such infectious joy and life-affirming enthusiasm that it's nearly impossible not to respond in equal measure.
While the story itself takes some tense turns, Clooney's moralizing doesn't, leaving us with a bit of a campaign hangover.
For a film that's so up in women's business, it's surprising how far it gets from putting an authentic woman on the screen.
The film feels much like where it came from, modern-day Broadway - a formerly grimy section of New York City that's been scrubbed clean and thoroughly Disneyfied.
"Prometheus" may go overboard on the existential inquiry, but it's still an epic ride.
Exactly what you expect from Anderson, and also dangerously close to overstaying its welcome.
"Men in Black 3" is a bore.
It's disappointing that the team of writers, including Andrews and Chapman, failed to redefine what it means to be a heroine in big-budget animation.

Despite the lack of solutions, "Murder Capital of the World" accomplishes what seems to be Minn's goal: make his American audience feel compassion and a righteous sense of injustice for the people of Juarez.
It's all rather serious and ominous, yet outlandish and mostly entertaining. Sounds about right for summer, doesn't it?
Shenk's tight storytelling makes for a gripping film that delivers the ugly, at times ennobling, truth.
It is, indeed, what a moviegoer should expect from a genre in which an ensemble cast of famous, pretty faces is loosely strung together by an innocuous holiday or, in this case, baby-having.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Even at 76, Allen maintains his grueling pace of releasing one film a year, which doesn't allow much time for finely tuned scripts, robust character development or visual finesse.
A cartoonish, nonsensical mishmash that falls somewhere between a Saturday morning cartoon and the Three Stooges.

Take away the hullabaloo surrounding the film adaptation of Suzanne Collins' best-selling young adult book and what you have is an absorbing film with a dire premise that stands pretty much on its own.
A touching documentary that offers a field-level portrait of male mentorship, compassion and unvarnished hope - all without a Hollywood ending.
Disney and director Andrew Stanton may have dusted off the creaky franchise and wrapped it in $300 million worth of 3-D digital effects, but the final product still feels like ancient history.

Moments before and between the missions plays like stilted filler cable TV programming, but once our heroes step onto that helicopter or sea vessel, Act of Valor puts the audience into the boots and under the helmets of these elite fighters.
Yes, Daldry extracts a few tears in the process, but the increasing number of precious touches leaves you feeling pandered to and clumsily manipulated.

By ignoring the perpetrators, Hirsch keeps the finger pointed only at the victims and the underfunded, overworked school administrators. In a way it feels like the bullies were yet again let off the hook.
Even Ms. Streep's best efforts can't rescue this sloppy biopic from itself.

While the story is about teens, it isn't made for teens. In fact, Sleeping Giant should probably be watched only by adults, who can look back knowing they somehow managed to live through those confusing, difficult, sometimes dangerous years.
At its best, this is an absolute darling of a movie, offering a tender and rueful look at the intensity of youth, when love and music are practically inseparable.
Susan Sarandon is the meddler in this sweet but so-so dramedy, and meddle she does.
Sharp, tender, topical take on female empowerment.
The geopolitical complexities running underneath this period story will reverberate into the 21st century.
The results are frantic rather than dynamic, with nothing much to say under all the hepped-up style.
Dinner parties, good and bad, are a rite of adult life. The Invitation is that rare thing, a horror film for grown-ups.
Karamakate worries the world will forget how to see and hear. This lucid, original and unsettling cinematic dream offers a way to remember.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This is an imperfect film, but even its imperfections are worth watching.
Jia's larger narrative of modern-day China is mesmerizing, its ambitious 25-year stretch punctuated by abrupt, astonishing moments of insight.
movie_title: Mountains May Depart (Shan he gu ren) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: These familiar pleasures don't outweigh the fact Vardalos doesn't find much new to say about the Portokalos clan or the immigrant family experience in general.
Audacious but uneven.
Despite some achingly lovely moments, Sunset Song feels like an echo of Davies' better work.
The story covers a lot of loving, leaving, hurting and cheating. There are evocative sequences, but the overall narrative is listless and often falls into Walk Hard-style musical biopic clich√©s.
If you give in to Cemetery of Splendour's slow, dreamy, dozy vision, you might end with a wide-awake cinematic jolt.
Very little is spelled out, with most of the story's momentum coming from the performances, especially Fiennes' glorious scene-bombing.

The story involves tricks and illusions, bluffs and double-bluffs, turnarounds and reverses, to the point where the unpredictable becomes weirdly predictable. Basically, you know that whatever seems to be happening probably isn't.
In the end, The Conjuring 2 is a solid, straight-up scare-fest, but there is little lingering fear when the lights come up.
Lady Susan may be a bad person, but with Austen at her sharpest, Stillman at his snappiest and Beckinsale right on form, she is very good company.
Right there in the title, this wry, warm, rambling anti-rom-com makes it clear love isn't going to work out quite the way the super-organized Maggie thinks.
Too often literal rather than literary, stagey rather than cinematic, Genius can't live up to its title, and ultimately its good intentions are undone by mediocre instincts.
Director Susanna White, a veteran of British prestige TV, offers handsome location work in Paris, London and the Swiss Alps, but the screenplay, adapted by Hossein Amini (Drive), feels rushed.

The film manages a slight melancholy tug, and Woody's recent tendency to stop suddenly actually works here, underlining the characters' impossible romantic dilemmas. But the script is often lazy and listless.
We really do need a "bad mom" comedy in 2016, but Bad Moms isn't it.
Mature, meticulous and faithful in its own fashion, this is the best of the Roth adaptations that have come out in the last 15 years.

Peggy Guggenheim: Art Addict brings some balance to Guggenheim's spectacular bio. While listing off the many men - and occasional women - Guggenheim slept with, this documentary amply demonstrates that her one true love was art.
Despite some crackerjack work from Cranston, this story of agent Robert Mazur's infiltration of the Colombian drug cartels often feels rushed and perfunctory.
The progressive girl-positive content never feels earnest or mandatory or tacked on. It's actually funny, as Moretz and crew fight for their right to party, feminist-style.
Ultimately, the filmmakers are unable to overcome the central character's nastiness. The Bronze scores high on degree of difficulty but struggles with execution.

Doing some deft shadow boxing with the increasingly wheezy, cheesy Rocky legacy, Coogler honours its 1976 roots -- getting some poignant support from Sylvester Stallone -- while giving the franchise some relevant, rousing 21st-century direction.

Anyone who's seen the hilarious, what-the-heck trailer for this Egyptian-themed extravaganza knows there's a good chance it will be bad. The real question is whether it's "boring bad" or "fun bad." It turns out to be mostly fun bad.
Despite Mehta's attempt to update the old gangster genre with a brand-new cultural context, Beeba Boys is all dressed up with nowhere to go.
The movie plays with clich√©s only to upend them.

Rock the Kasbah is not only a catastrophic miscalculation of comic tone. It's an all-around dismal display of cinematic incompetence by scripter Mitch Glazer and director Barry Levinson, who ought to know better.

Sorkin isn't interested in dutifully depicting Jobs or his brilliance... But with this smart, intense, ingeniously designed and occasionally exasperating film, Sorkin does deliver an appropriately Jobsian end product.
Powerful but problematic.
Good intentions and genuine talent abound, but as Jane would probably point out, those things don't necessarily get you anywhere in the muck of real-world politics.
Spectre is a solid Bond outing, with strong performances and eye-catching spectacle, but it spends so much time trying to fulfill its complex mandate that it's never able to enjoy itself.
More problematic is the frustrating feeling that there are fascinating layers to this survival story, if only the scripters had dug deeper.
Ultimately the characters in Love the Coopers don't feel like a family. And yes, you could argue that's kind of the point. But they don't even feel like a dysfunctional family.
Gibney doesn't offer a big, final Sorkin-style statement. Instead, he grapples with his own ambivalence about Jobs and his enormous social and technological legacy.
movie_title: Steve Jobs: Man in the Machine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: With grander goals than the earlier movies, Mockingjay Part 2 has some bigger flaws, but it's grounded in a remarkable central performance. Thankfully, Jennifer Lawrence is as steel-willed and world-saving as her heroine, Katniss Everdeen.
Spotlight is a tight, economical model of understated craft.

Al Purdy Was Here is not a definitive portrait, and probably isn't meant to be. Instead, the film uses an image here, an anecdote there, to build up a dynamic sense of an elusive and complex personality.
Children and grown-ups who watch with their hearts will be rewarded with a very sweet film.
In the Heart of the Sea is neither history nor myth but a hokey, unworkable Hollywood mix of the two.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Often hilarious but frequently frustrating, this raucous raunch comedy suffers from a common problem, especially with Saturday Night Live reunion movies. Its script doesn't live up to its stars.

Haynes looks back on mid-century conformity without camp or condescension. Carol's extravagantly beautiful surfaces are both seductive and dangerous, reminding us that nostalgia for this so-called simpler time papers over some stark injustices.

Even when pulled down by his worst impulses and most self-indulgent tics, Tarantino can pull off scenes that possess a mad, bad, unsettling power. In Hollywood's increasingly bland landscape, that's something.
Goodnight Mommy is not easy to watch, but with elegant cinematography, impeccable pacing and a thrumming sense of dread, Franz and Fiala make it hard to look away.
Starting as a deeply sad character study, the film becomes a deeper investigation of identity, fame and failure.
You might expect a clich√©d fish-out-of-water comedy. But, no. Norm of the North is so lazy, sloppy and confusing, it can't even pull off clich√©s.
With its sepia-toned period detail and earnest Eisenhower-era feel, this stoic seafaring adventure comes close to being hokey. But it's honest hoke, told with sturdy craft.
Even as Travis and Gabby fuss and feud, everyone around them is thinking, "Can't these two crazy kids see they're made for each other?' The obstacles set up to keep them apart seem contrived.
The extraordinary improvisational performances somehow hold everything together, bringing us right into this exhilarating cinematic encounter.
Starting with this seemingly glum premise, The Heart of Madame Sabali adds in absurdist comedy, surreal drama and inventive, super-stylized visuals. The final effect is weirdly, unexpectedly upbeat.
The story doesn't work as popcorn entertainment or as serious docudrama, and 13 Hours often feels conflicted and confused (something we never thought we'd say about a Michael Bay film).
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There's not much narrative oomph. Director Nicholas Hytner and scripter Bennett compensate with lovely anecdotal bits and wonderful dialogue. They are aided, incomparably, by the 81-year-old Smith.
Race starts with good intentions and a genuinely inspiring true-life tale, but with a scattered story and shapeless direction, it struggles at the finish line.
With sure but small gestures, Ronan manages to suggest both luminous innocence and reserves of strength that Eilis is only beginning to understand. It's a quietly commanding performance.
Taken all in all, The Wild Life is a harmless but instantly forgettable children's movie.
This offbeat project is actually very engaging, bringing droll humour and sweet-hearted feeling to its low-key affirmation of ordinary life.
This modest, moving and unshowy ode to professionalism gets the job done.

Well-intentioned and handsomely produced, this fact-based war film is an important account of human decency, featuring moving performances and some effective scenes. Yet The Zookeeper's Wife... still feels somehow off.
The final result is such a deftly understated mixture of humour and sadness that it's only after the storm, when the end credits roll, that you really feel its full emotional force.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Jacobs may be pessimistic about marriage √° la mode, but he retains some qualified optimism for his characters, with a bruised tenderness for the story's central quartet, all flawed and flailing but trying, somehow, to move forward.
I, Daniel Blake is stark, plainspoken and predictable. Maybe a movie that makes the case for treating society's most vulnerable people with respect should be.

While this threequel is not as good as the 2001 original, which was irresistibly zeitgeisty, it's better than the wobbly second. And in its silly, completely shallow way, it could be the flat-out funniest.

It is because of Serkis's nuanced and emotionally affecting work that in a showdown between people and apes, our sympathies are with the apes. In all the ways that matter, they are more human than the humans.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Nolan has crafted not just his own best film but one of the finest war films of the 21st century.
Dark, difficult and morally slippy, Lady Macbeth looks a little like Downton Abbey but plays more like Double Indemnity.
[Director Joshua] Weinstein, one feels, comes to Borough Park not to judge but to quietly observe.
As summer winds down, gardeners looking to extend the season might want to take in this beautiful, contemplative documentary from filmmaker S√©bastien Chabot.
Director Burshtein is both morally serious and subtly funny, overcoming the clich√©s of romantic comedy with a sideways exploration of the nature of love and faith.
Far from being depressing, dirge-like or morbid, Obit is vivacious, funny and effortlessly entertaining.
Blade Runner's world is grotty, grey, crowded and retrofitted. This future doesn't jettison the past. It cannibalizes it, from ancient ziggurats to Art Deco glamour.
My Little Pony: The Movie may not be terrible, but it simply has no compelling reason - beyond more sparkly, rainbow-coloured merchandising tie-ins - for this leap onto the big screen.
Produced by Robin and Diana's son, Jonathan Cavendish, the film is affectionate and optimistic.
Loving Vincent is made up of visually lush, gorgeously coloured, constantly moving surfaces, but the narrative underneath remains awkward and static.
As much as I love Gerwig's sunny, grounded presence as a screen actor, her assured solo directorial debut demonstrates why we need women to get behind the camera.
The film has crafted an essentially benevolent comic universe where everyone is goodhearted - or at least, they are who they are, and there's not much to do about it.
Kaurismaki places his hope in individuals, his sad but tender story making a modest and much-needed case for the value of simple human kindness.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Square keeps viewers off-balance, taking on race and xenophobia, gender and abuse, poverty and class privilege with a sideways Nordic tone that is both hilarious and serious.
With a C-list cast and generic direction, Forever My Girl comes off more as a mid-budget Lifetime movie-of-the-week that has somehow migrated to the big screen.
Nothing happens and everything happens, the story's growing emotional power coming from subtle, complicated lead performances, exquisite pacing and dreamy, melancholy music from Sufjan Stevens.

As an account of a serial killer, then, My Friend Dahmer doesn't quite work. Instead it is Derf's story, with its uncomfortable mixture of compassion, complicity and retrospective horror, where the film's real strength lies.
In particular, the film celebrates the stories we tell ourselves and each other - the stories that educate, encourage and inspire.

The Party remains fast, brittle and more than a bit mean...Anchored by Scott Thomas's portrayal of cool competence and boosted by Clarkson's magnificently crisp zingers, the ensemble cast is tight and terrific.

Mixed in with these dark strains, we have glints of comedy and bursts of magic realism...In this empathetic portrait of suffering and resilience, Lelio has also crafted a very 21st-century version of the woman's picture.
Ai's subjects remain nameless and voiceless, viewed en masse. He often seems to overlook individuals in his attempt to underline the almost unimaginable magnitude of this crisis.

The modest pleasures of Going in Style come from watching three old pros expertly and enjoyably playing off each other. They may not be quick... but they have skills and experience, a point that applies to acting as well as armed robbery.
This beautiful, provocative, maddening, magnificently titled anarchist epic is both operatic and intimate, ambitious and ambivalent.
movie_title: Those Who Make Revolution Halfway Only Dig Their Own Graves (Ceux qui font les r√©volutions √† moiti√© n'ont fait que se creuser un tombeau) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The scenery is spectacular and the food porn is fabulous, but what should be insouciant feels insipid in this stretched-out travelogue, mostly due to underwritten characters and awkward performances.

I just wish 3D wasn't the default setting for all big animated movie projects... Sure, they catch your eye, but sometimes you just want that crooked, pokey little two-dimensional tree that's shedding needles.

Junior and Tulip are a likable and funny duo with great comic chemistry, and like all contemporary cartoons, Storks ends with a nice lesson about the true meaning of family, which might even make you teary -- though probably not Pixar levels of teary.
This crowd-pleaser is bolstered by intelligent scripting, crafted direction and strong performances, making the uplift feel earned.
It offers a tender testament to the risks and rewards of the creative existence.
While Moorhouse pulls off some quirky comic sequences, she can't quite corral the story's expanding slate of characters and tearaway themes.

There are minor conflicts and revelations, but these never seem like plot points. Rather they feel like the fabric of everyday life, observed with limpid simplicity and given powerful emotional effect with natural, easy, unforced performances.
At its best, the film will make you see trees with new eyes.
movie_title: Call of the Forest: the Forgotten Wisdom of Trees (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The message, though simplistic, is still worth hearing: you can't consume happiness; you need to find it within yourself.

This wry and warm Brazilian take on the upstairs-downstairs divide (in Portuguese, with subtitles) centres on the meaning of motherhood, formed by love but also shaped by economic and social pressures.
movie_title: The Second Mother (Que Horas Ela Volta?) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Combining a scrupulously intelligent script with standout lead performances, Loving is stubbornly modest and profoundly moving.
Ants on a Shrimp is an intense film and, for a food flick, it's much more about the hard labour of cooking than the pure pleasure of dining.

The story is about how we get past trauma and how sometimes we don't but keep going all the same. And even that latter situation is not without a gleam of hope, as Manchester by the Sea slowly uncovers its broken but humane heart.
It's a slight, often affecting story that mixes the confusion of contemporary life with nostalgic yearning for a time when the whole boy-meets-girl thing was less complicated.
Tampopo is one of the great food films, its dizzy deliciousness pre-dating our addiction to the Food Network, celebrity chefs and exquisite plating.
Like everything by Korean auteur Park Chan-wook, The Handmaiden is meticulously controlled in form and bonkers-crazy in content. That's a heady combo.

Lipman blends his detailed historical account of Film's production with good gossip and gently wandering reflections on the big questions: perception, memory, mortality, time and the fundamental nature of cinema.
Dorothea may be eccentric, but she's never reduced to the cutesiness often seen in pop-culture moms. Bening's work is just too prickly and warm and real.
A quietly illuminating character study.
As a Batman movie, however, this smart, self-aware, fast and funny outing is just made to puncture the self-serious, overinflated mythos of the post-Nolan Bat.

What The Wolfpack makes very clear is the way the movies, and the imagination and empathy involved in watching and making movies, helped these boys survive their difficult, claustrophobic childhood, make some sense of their bizarre history.
The film doesn't disappear, of course. It just folds into itself, again and again, ultimately transforming into an ecstatic, enclosed, gloriously self-indulgent expression of pure filmic desire.

Unfortunately, it doesn't take much for charming camaraderie to cross over into uncritical cronyism. Clooney could have used someone telling him to do a few more rewrites. If he's not careful he'll turn into a classier version of Adam Sandler.
Meandering but mesmerizing, this new film from French auteur Olivier Assayas is part old-style ghost story, part stylish Euro-thriller, part millennial sociological study.

After finally watching this ruthlessly constructed, exquisitely vicious depiction of all-out gender warfare, I would say that, yes, Gone Girl is anti-female. It's also anti-male. Hell, it's anti-human. That's where the fun comes in.
Toni Erdmann is ostensibly a comedy-drama, but that catch-all label doesn't even begin to cover its idiosyncratic tone, in which the comedy is often killingly awkward and the drama so oddly sweet.
This is a humongous movie built on flimsy foundations.

Whatever you think about his later abstractions, which can be rigid and dry, there is something inspiring about Harris's ceaseless artistic and spiritual curiosity, which kept him questioning and experimenting even into old age.
If only there had been better comics in the writing room. The drama, meanwhile, is as unconvincing as the comedy.
McConaughey is left holding only fool's gold with this leaden script, which lacks not just a coherent moral viewpoint but even basic dramatic structure.

This well-acted drama has its moments. But as with so many highly pedigreed literary adaptations, these flashes of insight and poignant power just make The Sense of an Ending's ultimate failure even more frustrating.
Room begins with a ripped-from-the- tabloids premise and then systematically rejects every bit of conventional wisdom regarding how that premise might unfold.
Rock has thus made his most personal special without ever getting that personal‚Ää-‚Ääa testament to his talents, not a criticism of them.

"It's chaos, be kind" is how Oswalt closes the special, a perfect motto for both this highly specific story and whoever might be listening. It's not exactly revolutionary, but that's what makes it so profound.
Few comedians have managed to dodge the dog-caught-the-car problem of successful stand-ups as smoothly as C.K. has. Look no further than his latest special, Netflix's 2017, for proof.
Because between the inadvertently hilarious and the downright offensive, Pan is a generic mold for a reboot that shares little with the original beyond a handful of proper nouns.
Rowling imbues Fantastic Beasts from start to finish with a sense of discovery.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Bright Lights is a heartbreaking tribute to a singular mother-daughter relationship.
movie_title: Bright Lights: Starring Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If [Colin] Jost is angling for a big-screen, or in this case laptop screen, career, Staten Island Summer is an inauspicious start.
This is romance by numbers and though not execrable, it's a movie for a wet Friday afternoon on the telly.
Fincher maintains a steady tension throughout. He also adds his own tweaks to the twists at the end.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Something of a curate's egg, the film seems to be a little bit of everything and not enough of anything...
Vaughn and his co-scriptwriters temper the tension and the spectacle of the big set pieces with dashes of humour that will have the fanboys chuckling...
For all its A-list ingredients of concept, cast and director, the resulting mash-up is merely a superior B-movie, as uncertain a fusion as potato on a pizza.
Red Lights has an interesting premise and Weaver is on top form at the start.
We marvel not at what it is, but what it could have been.
Low budget director Drew has an eye for cityscapes and a finely-tuned feel for the mostly untrained cast.
The Dark Knight Rises certainly isn't the low note of a Godfather III, but a fitting end to the franchise.
There are no real belly laughs and it lacks the sureness of touch and character of other Australian comedies.
Predictable as the day is long, but it certainly makes a massive change from the usual crime-infested gangster movies set in London.

Fans of Smith's first film will appreciate Mallrats for its combination of the same type of humor and many of the same actors from Smith's acclaimed debut.

Beyond The Black Rainbow is more surface than substance, but those surfaces are gleamingly polished enough to make for a hypnotic experiment that goes beyond genre pastiche or art-school wankery to seem formally daring.
An overly bleak film ready to write off the world and go down in a blaze of gunfire, both middle fingers raised.
It's hard to say whether A Bag of Hammers is deliberately stylized or simply so lo-fi it inadvertently comes across that way, but the simplicity of its elements works.
