Lovely Molly is a portrait of either spiraling madness or a haunting, and it deftly handles the slow erosion of its title character's consciousness.
Greyhound-lean and adrenaline-dazed, Sleepless Night keeps up a relentless pace once it arrives at its main location.

The Observers creates a haunting sense of people engaged in an otherworldly duty-huddled over incomprehensible charts and dials, they seem like they're busy maintaining the clockwork mechanism of the world itself.
I Wish makes us feel like we are watching these kids discover each new sensory pleasure of youth for the first time, or that we're experiencing it ourselves.
Like the hashish-laced pastries the ladies make to sedate the male population, the film feels like it has been dosed with sugar to mask its distressingly bitter taste.

As mild, comforting and vaguely colonial as beans on toast, The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel brings together some of Britain's top-shelf acting treasures for a story of late-life awakenings and self-discovery in India.
Turner's interactions with Deschanel are so much weightier than the rest of the film that the other storylines seem extraneous.
The Samaritan takes a jarring turn right out of Park Chan-wook, and from there takes a tumble into ludicrousness from which it doesn't recover.
Last Call at the Oasis has more than the usual share of gloom, though it's too steady with the facts to ever come across as alarmist - and some of its imagery is downright haunting.
Treadaway and Tena are meant to have a deep connection based on their love of music, but their barely there characters get together only because the story requires them to.
Virginia is so scattershot it feels like it's a vehicle created to loosely hold a group of ideas rather than function as anything coherent.
It's an exhilarating, though unfocused, look at how the country reached its tipping point, one that feels unfiltered in ways both good and bad.
It offers a look at how a tireless protest can sometimes only come at the expense of one's own daily existence.
Presents a sickening chorus of accounts not just of rape but of institutional betrayal, of a system that's utterly failed to protect or serve those who've joined it.
The stakes of the final competition [are] heart-poundingly high, even for those who don't give a damn about tights and tutus.
Palatable overall, if vaguely inauthentic and unsatisfying, like an allegedly local meal bought at a tourist restaurant.
Skims over the vast topic of religion-divorced spirituality, particularly as attached to yoga, with a calculated superficiality...
This is a film that finds poorly chosen, impulsive back tattoos endlessly hilarious.
Could easily be relabeled Sin City Lite.
movie_title: The Girl from the Naked Eye (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A run-of-the-mill low-budget flick focused on killing off stupid, pretty young things slowly enough to fill out 90 minutes.
A Todd Solondz film, one that provides the same kind of bracing counterbalance to man-child genre tropes as Welcome to the Dollhouse did to teen comedies in which the outcast kid makes good.
Deeply, engagingly weird.
This musty comedy makes its chosen location look like a place that exists only to heal refugees from the city, and provide answers for life's problems.
Hide Away has more clunky moments than it does elegantly minimalist ones, the worst of which is the glimpse of what actually happened to the man's family.

High School has such a winning premise that you want to send everyone involved in making it back to the drawing board for a do-over - just take it from the top, folks, and this time everyone actually have a good time.
Horowitz has Michael Moore's smug tendencies without his schlubby everyman charm, which makes his attempts at goading humor out of uncomfortable interviews come off as unpleasant.

[It examines] issues of class and race through the lens of its ragtag athletics program while also reinforcing American mythos of bootstrapping, hard work and community. Its triumphs are bittersweet, but they're irresistible.
By tying it back to characters that don't seem popped from any too-familiar mold, the film allows its sense of regret, its alarm at time passing, to feel earned.
Despite its cloying genuflections to its source material, Think Like a Man is rowdy and funny and showcases an immensely likable ensemble cast it uses to delineate its war between the sexes.

The Snowtown Murders builds into a multipronged horror effort in which the torture and murder on-screen are matched by the psychologically convincing disintegration of a previously sympathetic protagonist.
Elles is racy and often sexy, but underneath that simmers an old-school feminist anger.
[It feels] curiously rudderless, its off-stage journey pale and enervated in contrast with the cheesy, ebullient dance numbers it makes room for.

It's not as wild or as fun as it may sound (or that it needs to be to hit the midnight-movie sweet spot for which it aims), but it's a minor improvement on the unintentional silliness of the initial installment.

Light as a bubble, Hipsters suggests that age may catch up with everyone, but that there will always be people fighting against the current of conformity, even if they only express it via how they wear their hair.

It's Rudd who provides the tenuous through-line that holds together this scattered ramble of a film, by realizing that there's a middle ground between high-rise living and a cooperative farm, and that it's where most people end up.
[Tyler Perry's Wesley] is Prince Charming for a prospective audience of women who are less enchanted by rippling abs than by kindness and responsibility.
Chow and Jiang having an especially great, crackling chemistry based off surface agreeableness, hidden aggression, and below that, an almost-fond recognition that they're all just crooks.
The breeziness of The Salt Of Life disguises a barbed consideration of mortality and being written off, becoming part of the scenery in later life...
movie_title: Gianni e le donne (The Salt of Life) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The picture is tonally and stylistically consistent with what they've done for TV, but those episodes run 11 minutes.
movie_title: Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It seems to agree with its gossip journalists that celebrities are an exotic alien species placed on earth to be gawked at, waited on by personal entourages, and mocked behind their backs for their odd enthusiasms and incomprehensible emotions.
Cedar breaks up these father-son dynamics with visual flourishes, including nods to old-school slideshows, or footnotes about the characters thrown out onscreen.
Remember Eddie Murphy? He used to be hilarious.
It'd be easy to thread this story through with condescension, but instead, it's modest and compassionate, a midlife awakening for a woman long out of touch with her own needs.
Goes from adequate to ludicrous but is only ever compelling enough to serve as audiovisual wallpaper while you're focused on something else.
Detachment is overwhelming and didactic, intolerably so in some moments...
Free Men offers a pleasing historical escape via a story of everyone setting aside religious, colonial, and ethnic divides to unite against the Nazis.
This isn't a movie; this is propaganda for the already converted.
The film aims to present a mosaic of crazy New York life, but instead seems more like a shaggy-dog story being spun out by an easily distracted barfly over the course of an idle afternoon.
Marling provides a grave, otherworldly center around which everything else orbits...
Efron and Schilling simply look like two pretty people who are bound to get together because they both have the big blue eyes of a porcelain doll.
Since the movie is one long build-up to a reveal, it offers a lot of time to learn to hate Brondo and everything she represents.

Lockout is derivative and ridiculous and a good time, provided you can turn off higher brain functions along with any other part of you that might want to lodge a complaint about liberal borrowing from better movies.
[Love] burns much brighter than the film's focus; she's a raucous, disastrous, undeniable star.
Late Bloomers is at its best when it's being breezy and simply taking pleasure in its lead actors, who turn in strong performances in spite of certain clunky character developments.
It's a good thing these characters are played by Segel and Blunt, who share enough dorky charisma to carry The Five-Year Engagement through a sprawling runtime to a deservedly happy ending.
The Three Stooges isn't very funny, but it is, like last year's far superior The Muppets, a sincere act of fandom on an epic scale.
Even by the most lenient of genre standards, the behavior of the characters in David Brooks's ATM is ludicrous enough to make anyone grind his or her teeth in frustration.
Brisk and technically efficient, The Assault is a dull film based on a real event that certainly wasn't.
How to resist a film in which one kid taunts another by quoting Mo'Nique's monologue from Precious?
The film, which director Jannicke Systad Jacobsen adapted from a novel by Olaug Nilssen, allows Alma's journey to be funny, embarrassing and poignant without ever seeming leering or exploitative.
[Kent is] the least credible scientist since Denise Richards donned short shorts to play Dr. Christmas Jones.
This is a film that serves as a reminder of just how wonderfully cinematic violence can be.
Comic-Con Episode IV is a valentine to an event and a group of people so in ascension they don't really need it, but it's still a pleasant thing to watch.
movie_title: Comic-Con: Episode IV - A Fan's Hope (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A sad, standout showcase for Weaving's talents as a man whose good intentions can't fix the fact that irreparable mistakes have already been made.
The film is all for teaching as a calling. What it doesn't do is offer it the dignity of also being a job.
I, frankly, was hoping for at least some hair-pulling.
Deserves serious points for boldness, though not cohesiveness.
It's a portrait-as-thriller whose fundamental elements are all fine, but whose protagonist just isn't as grippingly complex as the film needs him to be.

It's built around a strong turn by Dano, but one that feels studied and sometimes at odds with the naturalism the film aims for with its grubby settings, loose camerawork, and tendency toward inquisitive close-ups.
It could itself be a dusty but treasured rediscovered artifact from another era.
There's something to admire in Bachelorette's initial flag-planting outrageousness, even if it goes too far and then sheepishly pulls back to a more conventional conclusion.
Tonally, Snowman's Land feels like a German throwback to a '90s indie, but without the energy-the pacing is languid to the point of aimlessness ...
The through-line from a rustic preparation of milk skin and chocolate on bread to a high-concept dessert illuminates the story of a family and how food unites generations.
10 Years does nothing noteworthy, but it does it well, thanks to its ensemble cast.
The Master is built around two towering, career-high feats of acting.
The film's extravagant action scenes have not a whiff of consequence to them, and other than Alice, the foremost quality of all of the characters is their disposability.
An earnest, big-hearted ode to friends as support and salvation, and to the talismanic quality a favorite song, treasured hang-out, or shared tradition can take on for a teenager.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It has a didactic undercurrent, making its main character into a beautiful blank, ready to blossom under the bright camera lights and to be unabashed in the face of the unenlightened.
Ayer manages to give a startling sense of a changing of the LAPD guard as well as the forces they're up against.
Adams quietly steals the movie out from under her co-star, and she does it while steering clear of the stereotypical ruts that could have mired her performance in mediocrity.

A clever, clever contraption about trading in your future to feed your present, and the lost boys and regretful men who willingly embrace such a bargain already believe they have nothing to live for or look forward to.
Headshot is, unfortunately, far better with ideas than with narrative.
Bringing Up Bobby centers around a mugging performance by Jovovich, who can't ground the film's attempts to tie together sentiments from Paper Moon and Miss Saigon.
Justice is a pretty, personality-free screen presence, while the more interesting cast members, like Levy and Handler, are stuck in shrill, unsympathetic roles.
The Loneliest Planet was made with an intoxicating and precise faith in the ability of images to convey feelings that words would be too clumsy and blunt to appropriately delineate.

Alex Cross is a misfire, but it's sometimes an entertaining one - enough to make you curious about who else Perry could go up against in another installment, and just how much overacting would take place.
While the film breaks no new ground, it does manage the giggly shocks that make this franchise so much fun to see with a rowdy midnight movie crowd.
With beautiful period trappings and picturesque backdrops, the film doesn't skimp on visual details, though the resulting product is inert.

There's an irresistible cinematic appeal to watching kids dedicate themselves to fundamentally non-kid-like practices like competitive ballroom dancing or studying etymology to ease their way in spelling bees.
This variation on the demon child subgenre has enough of the familiar and the new to be a decently good time at the movies.
Argo is a subdued thriller about a small triumph in a troubled moment in time, but it's not without its sting.
The image of [Perlman] in makeup and a wig, painting his toenails, is a terribly easy joke, but it's the best one this otherwise abrasive comedy can manage.
Though this version transplants the tale to World War II, it doesn't try for any nuanced commentary on the conflict.
movie_title: La nouvelle guerre des boutons (War of the Buttons) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Taken 2 grabs everything that was surprisingly enjoyable about the original film and batters it into the ground like... Liam Neeson beating up an Albanian human trafficking ring.
The Paperboy provides a lurid spectacle, but it's one that leaves you wanting to scrub yourself clean in the shower afterward.
It might actually make audiences understand the urge to bully.
movie_title: Someday This Pain Will Be Useful to You (2012)

movie_review_blurb: If men are from Mars and women from Venus, This Means War drifts in cold, empty space somewhere between the two orbits, where, as the famous tagline goes, no one can hear you scream.
Seven Psychopaths presents a clever if largely surface-level argument about cinema as art versus cinema as a delivery system for more immediate gratification.
It's a film that finds delicate beauty in the image of someone bleeding out in the snow, and turns a drunken, impulsive visit to church service into an overwhelming sensory experience.
An incomprehensibly garbled, derivative attempt at a horror flick from first-time writer-director Todd Lincoln.
No film can possibly capture the human experience as globally and completely as Samsara attempts to, but there's something stubbornly endearing about the way it tries and the surrender it demands ...

In both its setup and its theme, Nuit #1 hopes to explore what it means to skip social precedents in order to go straight to something intimate, and whether those in-between stages can be revisited afterward.
While the editing creates a sense of frantic momentum, it's also dizzying and disorienting.

It's startlingly funny in an uncomfortable, envelope-pushing way that's all the more effective for how it sneaks up on you - its shocking gags are folded into a low-key, semi-realistic style like a Dogme 95 take on The Hangover.

With little story to speak of, Planet Of Snail is more of an experiential piece, closing in on the pleasure and wonder with which Young-chan takes in details like rain falling outside the window and the bark of a tree.
It develops an almost mournful empathy for its subjects as they fall from great heights to merely impressive ones.
Just a sugary jumble of goofy voices, hyperkinetic action scenes and rote plot elements that rolls forward just enough to get us to the de rigueur pop song that plays over the closing credits.

It's a smart counter-jab to the many movies out there that put forth the myth that the world is full of quirky angels in ballet flats who are just waiting for some morose protagonist to come along in need of their love.
It loses momentum and the sense of the unexpected that gave it fuel. Its most operatic moments are actually its weakest.
Trishna is in love with India without romanticizing it.
There's no sense of how this service ever works, and only a scant indication of the miseries from which Papoulia is trying to escape by assuming a new identity.
As sticky-sweet and textureless as a bowl of pudding, though an amused central performance from star Morgan Freeman continually finds nuance and the unexpected where there ultimately isn't any.

The film seems to aim for a gritty and real depiction of a drug- and drink-fueled not-quite romance, but it's in fact just your worst fears about the kinds of people who populate L.A. brought to ugly, misogynistic and sometimes maudlin life.

Savages is a bright, messy smear of a movie adapted from Don Winslow's novel of the same name, one that's violent, sultry, and entertainingly sleazy while falling short of the satirical edge the material necessitates.
The 3-D performance footage is impressively lavish, though the film's unending idolization of the amiable singer will quickly exhaust all but the most devoted fans.
It's a wealth of semi-examined ideas about globalization and a twist on the commoditization of our national pastime, all of which are tumbled out, then largely set aside.
The film defers to the vagueries of the human heart and the way we can, despite our better judgment, form a connection with someone that can't easily be set aside.
Munn has proved on TV that she has solid timing, but she does little here other than look pretty and, when the plot calls for it, outraged.
360 has the pedigree, cast, and scope of a weighty film, but nothing much to say.

Premium Rush is a half-entertaining, half-exasperating movie - one that sells you on the notion of New York bike messengers as great fodder for cinema but then doesn't know how to build a feature around them.
When the biggest name in the movie is Janeane Garofalo, why waste her in an extraneous, laugh-free side role as the protagonist's neglected housewife mother?
Beloved is a tenderly sincere musical that celebrates love even as it acknowledges the ways in which it can sometimes lead to tragedy.

The Awakening is both a ghost story and an exploration of mourning and survivor's guilt, though a late twist turns the film away from its delicate merging of these two themes into something both more plotty and stilted.

Whatever throwback charm the first film had has been utterly Snakes on a Plane-d by this sequel, which from the start is far more pleased with itself than audience members are ever given a chance to be.
Easier to admire than to love, David Cronenberg's Cosmopolis is an amplified, feverish vision of the one percent as scarcely human.
Yes, there is a triple-breasted hooker in Len Wiseman's Total Recall remake.
The movie's cloying cotton-candy flavor develops a seriously astringent aftertaste.

movie_review_blurb: [The] solid cast ... can't make the film feel like anything more than a meander through the familiar-feeling angst of a privileged teenager.
Renner and Weisz have the crackle of legitimate chemistry, enough to make you want more scenes of them together and less of them in visually garbled clashes and chases.

While funny enough, the film feels even smaller than its 85 minute runtime, like it runs through every last bit of the territory deemed safe to tread and just barely makes it to the credits at a credible feature length.
[A] quiet, deliberately paced documentary ...
This isn't so much a rom-com or even a break-up movie as it is a portrait of a woman getting her unearned certainty about life shaken up a bit, and coming to terms with her own imperfections.
Assassin's Bullet feels like a shameless, dismal vanity project.
It's difficult to understand what's film-worthy about these people, or why their stories have been joined.

The Phantom Menace, in any number of dimensions, is an exercise in disappointment, a film filled with enough callbacks to the first trilogy to remind you about what you loved about them without adding much of note in all the new material.

movie_review_blurb: Senna is considered one of motorsporting's greats, but Asif Kapadia's film also makes it clear he was a sort of artist, his talent accompanied by an unquenchable thirst for excellence and a belief that racing offered him a connection to God.
The little glimpses of everyday magic on offer here are lovely, from a "universe suit" to a porous apartment door, but they're not enough to hang a film or a life on.
As propaganda, 5 Days Of War is unlikely to make a mark, though perhaps the idea of reaching people through would-be blockbusters will.
Rodriguez's family franchise about underage secret agents limps into its fourth installment with shiny CGI and frequent fart jokes to hold the attention spans of the underage and undemanding.
movie_title: Spy Kids: All the Time in the World in 4D (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It all becomes ridiculous, despite an appearance from the excellent Lorna Raver, the malevolent gypsy woman from Drag Me To Hell.

In the end, the truth we learn simply looks like a manufactured and cynical plot twist.
Despite the attention the film pays to the divide between the man as the ungainly, loving second-gen immigrant versus the boozy provocateur, it's not a portrait of much psychological depth.

Rottiers is excellent at embodying someone who projects vulnerability most when he's attempting strength, and who continually, heartbreakingly searches his mother for signs of attachment or regrets that fail to surface.
movie_title: I'm Glad My Mother Is Alive (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's a ride worth more for its journey than its destination.
movie_title: Resurrect Dead: The Mystery of the Toynbee Tiles (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A twisty French drama about office competition and revenge that's the final film from director Alain Corneau, who passed away last year.

Meticulous in its "found" visual details, minorly smart in concept, painfully slow to actually watch and so ridiculous in its big reveal that it almost has to be seen to be believed.
Warrior is a man-weepie of the highest Hollywood order, a would-be Rocky for an empire in decline.
The result isn't bad, it just lacks momentum and a strong reason for existing.
Main Street is an ensemble drama that functions as a display case for a range of regional drawls, from the authentic to absurd.

While it's fleet on its feet and steady in its tension, Contagion is an exceptionally dry-eyed movie about mass death, interested more in how the structures we've built to keep order deal with the disaster than how people handle it emotionally.
This may be the first film I've even seen where when an actor goes to put his hand thoughtfully on his chin, it's so awkward I became afraid he'd somehow miss and poke himself in the eye.
A wearying middlebrow movie that doesn't make its days of self-improvement and altruism seem any brighter than its days of smack addiction and violence.
The Man Nobody Knew is far better with matters of the public record than with matters of the home, which may sum up its subject better than any talking-head interview.
movie_title: The Man Nobody Knew: In Search of My Father, CIA Spymaster William Colby (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Its small scale allows for detailed looks at two men who are likeable and flawed, and who connect on a level neither expected -- nor in one case, was even looking for.

movie_title: Over Your Cities Grass Will Grow (2011)

movie_review_blurb: [It] has been contemporized, sanitized and stripped of all complexity, and what's left is as empty as a used pi√±ata.

For a supposedly strong character, Kate infuriatingly allows herself to be victimized by everyone around her, even her kids, who withhold affection when they feel she's gone too often because of work.

movie_review_blurb: The sincerity of the film's thoughts on loss and longing, on the burdens of grief, and on reawakened awareness of existence, is always painfully heartfelt.

An affable reminder that the French are just as capable of making cornball cinema as any Hollywood studio.

movie_review_blurb: Wanders around in the general vicinity of a joke idea without ever approaching anything like a punchline.

movie_review_blurb: For the most part, being in 3-D provides a minor refresh for a style of animation that was the big-screen norm 17 years ago, and that doesn't seem dated these days so much as simply different.
Smith isn't up to doing anything other than setting up caricatures and then knocking them down.
Kondracki offers a glimpse of a monstrous world -- made worse because some of the monsters in it were sent there to protect people -- but doesn't suggest any nuanced understanding of it.

Cloud Atlas walks a crooked line between the glorious and the ridiculous, its reach unencumbered by sensible decisions or restraint.
Unfortunately, the film is insultingly soft in its portrayal of neurological disorders, linking the disease to Phoebe's fanciful conversations with characters from Alice in Wonderland.
The film's cast and the fluid camerawork are as hip as can be, and in this age of Obama, so is the sentiment -- unflinching but optimistic.

I'd say "Four Lions" is intended to be, not a jihad satire, but a satire of the idea of a jihad satire, of the belief that humor of even the edgiest variety can effectively be troweled on to any topic to make it accessible, to humanize or defang it.

[Seems] like a downmarket David Lynch knockoff, right down to a mysterious glowering man who occasionally appears out of nowhere.
A mess -- but a beautiful one, crammed with enough big ideas and outsize performances for three movies.

While Jumping the Broom showcases rarely depicted class issues within the black community, the film still relies on wince-inducing stereotypes to delineate them.

Anthony Burns' directorial debut is all trappings, with very little there there, giving the mind plenty of time to wander through compare-and-contrast games. Skateland is more soundtrack than substance.

Though it can occasionally seem like an indie-dramedy answer to The Grudge, structured to pack in the maximum moments of whimsical connection instead of supernatural kills, the film does find something deeper in its treatment of Smith and Lloyd.

[Gleeson] is both the comic center and the melancholy heart of a film that's content to put its sprawl of engaging characters above their meandering trail of misdeeds.

It's difficult, if not impossible, to imagine anyone who isn't already a devoted Palinite seeking out or sitting through The Undefeated, which makes its distance from its subject all the more befuddling.

Life, Above All is something of a blunt instrument, but that doesn't minimize its crushing impact -- this fictional story of the prejudice faced by AIDS-infected people in rural South Africa could wring tears from a stone.
Aims for The Joy Luck Club's crossover appeal but ends up stilted and emotionally remote.

movie_review_blurb: The setup and storyline are absurd, but the angst underneath is as earnest as a campfire confession.
Magic Trip is about as fun as being the only sober person at a party.
Love Etc.'s cross-section of New Yorkers simply isn't as captivating as its cross-section of New York, particularly the Queens and Brooklyn neighborhoods that rarely grace the screen.
The type of film that demands viewers to submerge themselves in it like a pool of water -- anything less, and it will seem hopelessly abstract.
A physically taxing movie, jiggling and off-center and filled with dizzying whip pans.
A film that can't seem to buy into its own strident message of "family first," possibly because to prove your love, you apparently have to risk the wrath of everyone from your co-op board to PETA.

The debut of writer-director Djo Munga, who's from the DRC and studied filmmaking in Belgium, Viva Riva! has a sleek international sheen.
A sometimes silly but enjoyable experience.
The soundtrack ... goes miles toward making what would be an unmanageably dour experience into an acute emotional resonance; the songs are freed to say more than the characters onscreen.

The film is relentlessly one-sided enough to become tiring, but it's impossible not to feel for the main characters, who all love what they do while continually being forced to question how feasible it is.

It feels like a film that's been years in the making, and something this rich is worth the wait.

An obligingly tense, scruffy addition to the one-last-crime genre.

As the sisters lead them to desperately seek a path to forgiveness and peace for all concerned, Nesher expertly builds suspense while echoing and reinforcing their quest with the film's hauntingly beautiful musical choices.

A smart, charming, and bittersweet tale about the Kingdom's millennial generation and their take on the social and political restrictions that stand in the way of meeting and mingling with the opposite sex.

This low-key romantic comedy marks a return to one of Burman's oft-repeated themes -- a son coming to grips with his relationship with his father -- and to the setting of one of his most successful features, Lost Embrace.
movie_title: The Tenth Man (El rey del Once) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A shallow but good-looking soap opera-like drama set in the world of high fashion.

Low-budget, over-ambitious multi-strander from debuting helmer Deepak Rauniyar is more interesting for its glimpse of a politically tense, mixed-race society where tradition and modernity mingle uneasily than for the surfeit of uneven dramas.
For the first time, older characters are at the heart of a Sl√°ma film, and Kronerov√° and Nov√Ω repay the helmer-writer with warm, dignified turns that require both soul- and flesh-baring.
Although dealing with weighty matters, Jarchovsky's script (which is based on a real-life incident he experienced during primary school) is leavened with welcome humor and irony.

Although the film will be banned in its home nation, fests and niche arthouse distributors in most territories will welcome this brave, underground production for the way it manages to resonate on both specific and universal levels.
A sober, downbeat indictment of a patriarchal society's traditional right to uphold family honor.
It succeeds as a showcase for the thesping talents of the helmer's athletic son (a producer as well), who essays the eponymous lead.
Absorbing and cinematic, "The Quest of Alain Ducasse" offers the documentary equivalent of a memorable meal at one of the eponymous chef's three Michelin-starred restaurants.
movie_title: The Quest of Alain Ducasse (La Qu√™te d'Alain Ducasse) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Eye-opening in every way, especially for those who may think that Cuban food is just rice and beans, the film makes extensive use of Soto's engaging voiceover narration.

With a vibrant performance from fresh-faced Alba August as the lead, "Becoming Astrid" looks sure to become a hot seller and makes one eager for more episodes from Lindgren's astonishingly unconventional life.
Csord√°s and Ill√©si, the non-professional actors playing Ricsi and Vir√°g, do a fine job, but the camera loves Ill√©si, and it's her story that stands out whether it was meant to or not.
This accomplished, absorbing, even-handed look at the pain of a marital breakup should broaden the director's fan base on the festival circuit.
A beautifully crafted, intimate, and revealing observational portrait of five youngsters with Asperger's Syndrome.
Certainly, multihyphenate Qayumi deserves credit for his deft use of archival footage and animation, which provide useful context and historical background.
A troubled student is challenged by his literature teacher, who aims to open his narrow worldview to other possibilities.
The kinetically shot film brims with authenticity and immediacy and benefits from a deeply sympathetic turn from sublime discovery Maria Mozhdah as the lead.
movie_title: What Will People Say? (Hva vil folk si) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Plays as if it might have come from Yorgos Lanthimos' bin of discarded ideas.
Both off-putting and engrossing, the pic marks [Hanna] Skold as an idiosyncratic talent.
The vibrant, Fauvist color-washes and overlays represent the film's most impressive element, recalling the cut-outs of Henri Matisse or the decorative work of Raoul Dufy.
movie_title: The Girl Without Hands (La Jeune fille sans mains) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Terhes makes palpable √Ågoston's optimism, loneliness and frustration - and he gets viewers to care about the character's fate.
The beautifully crafted and creative documentary Tempestad traces the stories of two women whose lives, through no fault of their own, became utter, incomprehensible nightmares.
Although some might find the twists and turns of the narrative to occasionally defy credibility, others will be swept along with the gripping human dilemmas of the main characters.

Although more compelling on a visual level than a narrative one, the movie represents an enticing festival and niche event item, as well as a vision of Sadat's homeland that is far different from what the media normally depicts.
"Dressage" powerfully illustrates the consequences of growing social divisions within contemporary Iranian society and indicts a middle and upper class that have lost their moral center.

A fearless, tour-de-force performance by star Paprika Steen is the main attraction of the Danish drama Applause, about an abrasive, alcoholic actress trying to regain control of her life and custody of her young sons.
An atmospheric tragedy set in the sordid world of Bombay's exploitation-film industry during the late 1980s.

As matter-of-fact as its mouthful of a title, Danis Tanovic's touching social-realist drama An Episode in the Life of an Iron Picker offers a modest, low-key glimpse into the struggles of an impoverished Roma family.
movie_title: An Episode in the Life of an Iron Picker (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Jeremy O'Keefe directs a tonally all-over-the-place drama that fails to convince.
Walkouts and snores are to be expected, although those on the film's meditative wavelength will be held rapt.
Lebanese-American helmer Rola Nashef delivers a lively slice-of-life in this mainstream-friendly romantic comedy largely set at a Detroit gas station.

Although discomfiting to audiences desiring a steady narrative thread (and less accessible to those unfamiliar with Eastern European history and culture), it sustains interest throughout as a devastating critique of Russian society.
Combines the folksy charm of Taggart Siegel's The Real Dirt on Farmer John and the frightening facts of Robert Kenner's Food, Inc.
A sober, intelligently made drama.
Sensual and horrifying, The Patience Stone plays like a mesmerizing, modern take on the tales of Scheherazade and a parable on the suffering of Afghan women.
Baltasar Kormakur's latest is a touching, low-key depiction of an incident in which a fishing boat sinks a few miles from shore.
The sight of Robert De Niro and John Travolta sharing the screen for the first time reps the one and only selling point of Killing Season.
An engaging, warts-and-all look at the Williams sisters.
An eye-catching parable about scapegoating and the multitude of sins it covers.
This odd, tonally all-over-the-map drama proves less intriguing in its narrative than in its visuals ...
While some viewers may find the film's length (162 minutes) and a certain repetitiveness off-putting, it gives Arnold scope to capture the spontaneity and rawness of their lifestyle.
Mohammad Rasoulof's slow-burning, clandestinely made fifth feature is a brave, challenging look at Iran's feared security apparatus.
A slender but polished dramedy.

A showy vehicle for producer-star Lauren Ambrose, whose emotionally volatile character comes off as unsympathetic and practically bipolar, the overly contrived, hard-to-swallow script undermines viewer compassion.
This comic romp boasts the sort of humor that can be appreciated by anyone who thinks the world is going to hell in a handbasket.
It's a heartwarming tale about a stubborn, short-tempered man with steadfast beliefs, strict routines and the feeling that everyone around him is an idiot - and no reticence about telling them so.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A middle-class Guadalajara teen with typical adolescent-male summer plans must come to terms with significant life changes in the tender, pitch-perfect coming-of-ager We Are Mari Pepa.
Lenken excels at establishing a realistic relationship between Stella and Katja, and the actresses share good chemistry as well as a certain resemblance.
Expertly laced with visual humor, Sabali is a gorgeously stylized, wryly comic drama about a train-ticket seller with heart and relationship problems.
Compelling, surprising and tenderly performed, this low-key arthouse title deserves further distribution and clearly marks its co-directors as talents to watch.
[A] provocative query into what makes life worth living.
[This] gripping chronicle of [composer Sara Najafi's] efforts covers a nearly three-year period and is as full of ups and downs as a roller coaster, and bursting with beautiful music.
A smart, offbeat comedy about how hard it is to end a romantic relationship.
As the woman who is victimized twice yet refuses to play a victim, theater thesp Cahani makes a strong impression in her first feature role.
Even though mood trumps character psychology, the entire cast provides mesmerizing, evocative performances.
Three intertwining stories add up to grim but compelling viewing in strong Croatian drama from Zvonimir Juric.

Told with passion and sincerity, this moral tale offers an audience-friendly blend of didacticism and naivete reminiscent of an Afterschool Special.

With its peppy, pop style, complete with silly, colorful special effects and animation, this documentary should prove accessible to school-age viewers, who might profit the most from its frank information about sugar's effect on their minds and bodies.
This mostly disappointing valentine to the Georgian capital epitomizes the law of diminishing returns.
Although some may find it a tad too sentimental and under-nuanced, the film depicts the ways of a community infrequently seen on Israeli screens.

Blends intimate and unflinching medical details, poignant performance footage and a survey of its subject's place in musical history through well-chosen archival footage and interviews with other iconic performers.
The movies (gratefully) violently counteract any attempt we might make to see them as fun escapism.
So it was good, if a bit jarring, to feel myself shrink at the film's beginning, when I found myself floating above the surface of the earth for a little while in absolute silence.

[McCarthy] reminds us (with a particularly American sensibility) that this world is broken and tragic and not fair, and that pushing past that fact too fast is an error we can't afford to make, for the good of our souls.
That said, there's something about The Place Beyond the Pines that grows on you-something tragic, something that sits uncomfortably in the gut.
A rollicking, highly entertaining, very instructional cautionary tale.
Chi-Raq is raucous and transgressive, but most of all, it's a lament. And lament is exactly what we-you and I-need to learn: right now, this year, this month, this week, today.
A ton of fun.
As The Big Short goes on, it becomes progressively less funny and more depressing, mirroring the attitudes of the characters.

Inside Llewyn Davis is a darkly funny film that recreates the texture of the Greenwich Village folk scene in 1961, and for those of us who love the Coens' meandering storytelling style, it's a masterpiece.
People are people, says Z. They will repeat their mistakes. But it is possible that those mistakes will make way for a new world, a lot like the old one. And maybe love will let them muddle through.
The movie is sad and, occasionally, devastating, but not without hope.
movie_title: The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them (2014)

movie_review_blurb: We get set piece after set piece, character moment after character moment, with few of them doing more than letting characters talk about themselves and tell each other things that we're not yet sure we believe.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Don't go trying to find the key to the film in a Bible story. A lot of the film's fun comes from just seeing those motifs pop up, like jokes.
movie_title: The Son of Joseph (Le fils de Joseph) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Those women are painted as full, complex characters in a few deft strokes-women who are struggling after rape to know whether they believe in something anymore, to understand their vows of chastity, to live in the problem of theodicy every day.
The film was seven years in the making-and it paid off.
99 Homes is very good at showing that the housing crisis is not a problem that belongs to one person.

Night Moves calls us (inadvertently or not) to reconsider our definition of what's "natural." Certainly, some of the ways we've failed to care for the planet as we were charged back at the beginning have had dire consequences. Let's not ignore that.
The Monuments Men is okay, if you don't expect too much from it. It's a fine rainy-Saturday movie. But shouldn't we expect more from our art?
This film wanders like a fl√¢neur between past and present, traversing space and history, crossing from fiction to nonfiction and back.
The real question, as for any remake, is simple: does it hold up? In the case of this Jungle Book... yes, and yes against all odds,
These films have a catastrophically low regard for the intellectual abilities of the people in their target market.
Slipstream meanders into some lucidity by film's end, but it remains difficult to determine if it's a work born of genius or madness. The decision lies with the viewer.
Satisfyingly entertaining.
Besotted with its own playfulness, Mister Lonely gives off the distinct impression that it was a lot more fun to make than it is to watch.
Clever, quirky, and surprisingly affecting, Paper Man is a good reminder of what it takes to finally grow up.
It is relentlessly bleak, even in its lighter moments. The downbeat tone is wearying. These days, we just need some hope.
A painfully formulaic message, trite dialogue, and a strangely episodic narrative structure that renders the whole thing exhausting.
The Answer Man is reaching for something but never quite grasps it.
Well-acted and gripping, Sangre de mi Sangre augurs well for Zalla's career.

The film, intimately shot, sidesteps exploitative potential, and the finely tuned screenplay obscures its titular theme (colloquially translated "tit for tat") in multiple layers of narrative and a hit of noir.

Begin Again is the best sort of summer movie, with great performances and a solid core. It's clearly a work that comes from love shared by people who enjoyed making it, and that makes it fun for us to watch out in the audience, too.

It explores concepts like grace, justice, pride, guilt, and love. It respects its source material and respects the power of human imagination. It takes a sober look at the evil in the human heart. That is the sort of movie worth watching.
[Belfort is] in the wrong. That's for sure. But to walk away and not realize we're at least a little complicit, too, would be foolhardy.
Julie & Julia is a delectable cinematic concoction about two food-loving women.

You won't feel anything at all. There are no clever catchphrases. There is no message, meaning, or moral. Nobody even makes a speech about believing in yourself or the importance of friendship, those staples of children's entertainment.

Translating life's happenstance into an effective bit of entertainment is trickier, and the movie has a disconcerting tendency to turn a hero's existential, enigmatically signposted journey into a sandy path strewn with red herrings.

I've seen a whole string of lovely family-oriented films this summer, but Kubo and the Two Strings might be the most stunning.

Give me... Ben-Hur -- with its pulsating battles and chariot races, its proclamation that mercy and sacrifice are more revolutionary than anything you can cook up with swords or chariots -- over any of this summer's exhausting superhero movies.

Nothing here is overwrought. The real-life drama is real enough.
Cameraperson is a marvelous film, and I plan to watch it again and again.
Entertaining and engrossing and funny and heartwarming.
Mostly it's about the meaning of life by way of religion, with which the Coens have always fiddled, sometimes dancing around the edges and sometimes diving straight into the middle.

Evoking war is an effective tactic for Deepwater Horizon, which is more interested in reminding audiences about a recent disaster that dropped out of national headlines years ago than it is in indulging anyone's love of disaster porn.

Sing Street takes teenagers' troubles seriously while also letting them create like grown-ups -- and it's a rollicking time at the movies, too.

In a summer top-heavy with... depressing underachievers, Star Trek Beyond is a breath of fresh air -- not a clever or innovative movie, but one with at least an idea in its head and the dose of optimism we all need right about now.
If it didn't so obviously want to be a Serious Adult Drama, leaned into its own melodrama with zest, it could have been pretty good.

Usually I'm not on board with films that withhold information and flash back to it later -- often it's just lazy storytelling -- but here, it works, resulting in something impressionist and simple at the same time.
Near the beginning, it's genuinely moving, but somewhere around the middle, the film's sheer excess and occasional silliness gets exhausting.
Vital viewing.

Though The Conjuring 2 lacks some of what made its predecessor a genuinely excellent, critically-acclaimed horror film, it's still compelling.
[Finding Dory] is flat-out terrific, even a little subversive.

"Parched" is vibrantly alive, full of color and light and movement and music. There is sex in this movie, and there is dancing, and there are vibrant fabrics and foods and fire. It's a dry place, but one ringed with beauty.

Though at times the film feels like an improvised mess, it creeps up on a surprisingly heartwrenching-and heartwarming-conclusion.
Emotionally dismantling ...
It's absolutely essential watching for anyone who wants to think about the human side-the business, the politics, the science, the art-of living in our connected world.

movie_review_blurb: You can practically hear the "wake up, sheeple" whispers around every corner

We are confronted by their crimes and their false superiority, unable to look away. We must wince. We must pay attention.

This isn't an innovative film, overall-the camerawork lyrically mimics the music, but it's mostly a straight-ahead informative documentary. And yet it holds your interest.
movie_title: The Music of Strangers: Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The key, as Fiona points out, is to know when you have everything, and be grateful. It's a worthy conclusion to the tale. We can all live happily ever after.
A fine example of excellent filmmaking on a modest budget. Its story sticks with you after the credits roll, a testament to the power of a good tale simply told on the big screen.

David O. Russell's film bobs and weaves, dodges and dances and hits just enough to keep us from relying on the formulas lesser sports movies have taught us.
The film is almost too broken and painful for most audiences to be able to experience Uxbal's pain. It's all here, and laid on a bit too thick.
This cautionary tale depicts consumers who believe they deserve stuff, whether or not they can pay for it. Rarely is this kind of truth seen onscreen in such a subtle and entertaining film.
Takes the themes of mumblecore (twentysomethings looking for love and life direction) and makes them into something more universal -- and, blessedly, less cynical, more full of hope.
It inspires because it says that sometimes overlooked people are worth a second look, without succumbing to a Disneyfied "anything is possible if you follow your dreams" trope.
The end is a head-scratcher, destined to provoke late-night pondering. But for anyone grappling with what it means to be a citizen of the 21st century, it's required viewing.
Though not particularly original, Lymelife is well acted and smart, and the Martini brothers' work is worth following.
I don't expect to see a better film this year than Short Term 12.
A Christmas Tale is a lively, capricious, mischievous ensemble delight.

movie_review_blurb: With its lush autumnal palette and hijinks worthy of Max Fisher or Dignan, the result is a film that only Wes Anderson could have made.
Based on an acclaimed Israeli film from 2007, this mostly retains the feeling of a foreign thriller, without succumbing to aggressive Hollywoodization.

There's nothing new unearthed in this film. The religious adherent won't have their mind changed, and the person who isn't sure what they believe won't find any help here, either.

I know stories of misfits are meant to be inclusive and empowering. It's an admirable goal. But maybe there's some way to tell the now-familiar story anew -- or at least value what makes us different without pretending it makes it easier.

movie_review_blurb: While The Women provides an evening of laughter and some points to ponder, relationships work only when all involved are willing to sacrifice for one another.
Throbs with life from title to credits, employing perhaps the most authentic characters you'll see on screen this year.
Though the movie is darkly funny, most people outside the movie business won't find themselves laughing too much.

A brilliant, gut-wrenching plunge into the painful work of facing the decisions we make and choosing to either continue onward, or live in regret.

Could have been a tour de force for director Paul Schrader and his cast, and the glimpses of greatness make the reality all the more disappointing.

Far more relatable than the Coens' recent work, and one cannot watch it without pondering some questions about the meaning of trials and the nature of fate.

The premise is flat-out creepy. Make sure you're game for that before you see it.
Movies help us think about who we are and how we live together. And as a movie, Life Itself is a heartfelt, clear-eyed tribute to a master.

10 Cloverfield Lane is a lot of fun, mostly because it's Michelle's story, and you're trying just as hard as she is to figure out the puzzle.

Have you ever wondered what it would be like to have your head driven through solid rock and glass and brick walls for two and a half hours, blinding flashes of lights unceasingly forcing your eyes shut?

movie_review_blurb: It's not a documentary, and it's not really history, either; it's most like an essay, where the various threads and motifs gain meaning from being placed next to one another.
Terrifying and essential ...
I blinked madly, willing myself to stay awake, chewing gum, rubbing a knot in my shoulder, annoying the guy sitting next to me.
This dramatization will twists your insides, no doubt about it.

As a technical achievement, it's interesting, if not perfect. But for a story of our time, I can't imagine anything better.

The film seems more than a little insecure, unwilling to let you feel its awesomeness -- it shouldn't have been -- and resorting to telling you, over and over, that this is a very inspirational story and you should be inspired by it.
Strayed is clear-eyed about her responsibility for her life's unraveling and realistic about what the trail can do. As Witherspoon plays her, she is foul-mouthed and tender, broken and strong.

Trzebuchowska is certainly the film's other great asset: all the performances are great, but she is not even an actress, having been spotted by a producer in a cafe and hired almost on the spot. You'd never believe it.
All of this elevates Le Week-End to the level of intelligent film without sacrificing humor, bite, and beauty, all of which it has in scads.
Inherent Vice is sensible and senseless, not as much a story as an experience of one.
It's not much fun, by the end. But golly: by my lights, it's a pretty perfectly-made, carefully crafted, well-acted, engaging film that is doing far more than meets the eye.

In the end, the film lacks an imagination, and that unfortunately winds up dragging it through the mud.

As you might imagine, shoot-outs ensues. But true to its name, Slow West takes a long time to get there, and gives us achingly gorgeous vistas in the process.

This is still a very nerdy movie, with lots of botany and physics and "we ran the numbers and it checks out," but most of the book's wonkiness is ironed out in favor of moving the story along more pleasingly for the science-allergic.

The Accountant wants to be a thriller, a shoot-'em-up, and a sensitive argument for neurodiversity all at once. What it actually is is stupid.
It's a shame, mostly because The Hitman's Bodyguard had the potential to be a weird, funny summer flick.
"Charming" is the best word for Home Again, and how could it be otherwise?
It makes a run at cleverness, trying to be a dark screwball commentary on America's race problem. But instead it's just a spectacular flop.
It's glorious to see [Idris] Elba working with great dialogue, but the movie belongs to [Jessica] Chastain, who throws herself into this role with abandon and vigor, and sells it completely.

movie_review_blurb: But the best part of Logan Lucky is that from the get-go you know you're in confident hands, and whatever's about to happen, it's going to be great.

... the movie just lets its subjects speak and trusts the audience to connect the dots. That's an effective and even illuminating approach, though it can make it hard not to watch the film through parted fingers.
[I, Tonya] is unexpectedly resonant.

The Death of Stalin is Iannucci's most complex and almost nihilistic rendering of what politics is: A team of bumbling and weak-minded people who lack any real conviction other than a desire for power and position.
I'm not convinced it's thoughtful, and suspect it's nothing more than clever and funny provocation for provocation's sake.
Martin McDonagh channels Flannery O'Connor's humor and sensibility in a film that looks at the absurd world and laughs.
At times, it works. But at others, it struggles to find its footing, and sometimes it flat-out falls down.
"Glib" is probably the right word for American Made, a movie that seems to exist purely to be Tom Cruise's rebound after his disastrous attempt to reboot The Mummy earlier this summer.
It is a difficult and beautiful dream - and del Toro makes it feel like just a bit less of a fantasy.
The Glass Castle seems to be missing a sense of purpose.
Wind River is a good movie, and very nearly an excellent one.

Its goal is to make us into witnesses and bystanders -- to put us into the shoes of those who stand by and watch, feeling helpless even when we're not -- something it achieves through confident, pulsating filmmaking and emotional performances.

It feels like Pitt is in a different movie than everyone else -- probably because he's giving a character actor's performance in the lead role, where everyone else (save Kingsley, who is cartoonish) seems to be playing their parts with a straight face.

The Florida Project won't let us look away. Nor, given its brilliance, would we want to. Instead, we laugh, we watch silently, and we're challenged to stop simplifying people's lives so we can offer easy theoretical answers.
The result isn't uplifting in the least. But it's deliciously frightening, a cautionary tale for the careless and a horror film that posits a world devoid of any real goodness.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While Elliott is great in The Hero, the rest of the film is curiously inert and predictable.
The Journey is the rare hopeful political film rooted in both reality and very recent history.
"Authentic" is an overused word in movie reviews, but there's no better way to describe The Big Sick: Every inch of it feels true, and not just because it's drawn from real life.
The Bad Batch squanders its strong start and rich setting on a too-thin plot.
Nobody Speak builds a damning, convincing case that journalism needs protecting.
movie_title: Nobody Speak: Trials of the Free Press (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Reagan Show does something that counts as a radical act these days: It looks back at history -- actual history -- by letting historical footage speak for itself, without any talking heads to tell us what to think.

The single most useful insight of Get Me Roger Stone is that men like Stone are driven not so much by ideology as by an overweening thirst for power and celebrity, propelled by absolute antipathy for their enemies.
It has something to say, and says it with a cinematic sensibility that's uncommon in most movies, let alone big-budget epics.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: [A] smart and even funny story of a young woman nearing the bottom of her anorexia.
Dunkirk wants us to sense what made this moment so pivotal without reducing it to an individual tale. And at that, it succeeds richly.
This movie is great, and far more fun to watch if you have no idea what it's about. So if you're already inclined to go, then you're making the right choice. Go forth and enjoy.
Looking back, it seems so obvious. We should have seen The Emoji Movie's utter awfulness coming. But as with so many other things in 2017, hindsight is not so much 20/20 as a giant regret generator.

... it's broadly understandable, too, which makes One of Us a bridge into empathy even for the outsider.

Right now there's something especially uncomfortable about watching a character based on the father of entertainment spectaculars praising exaggeration, falsehood, and ignorance for its pure pleasure value, reality be damned.

The new third entry in the series isn't interested in character development or logical storylines or anything resembling innovation. It's lazy and limp and profoundly weird, and not in any meaningful way a "good movie."
While the tale is interesting, All the Money in the World never quite makes clear why we should care about watching it.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In the end, Bright pulls off the uncommon (and not at all admirable) hat trick of being confusing, boring, and vaguely insulting about the matters it wants to appear smart on.
... its unwieldy, occasionally baffling progression has a charm all its own.

Proud Mary is still worth watching for two reasons. One: Winston is a talented actor, one worth keeping your eye on, and the chemistry between him and Henson as a mother figure is genuinely affecting. And two: Henson is just the greatest.
A sensitive, innovative, even beautiful feature that cuts right at the heart of the most difficult conversations we're having as a country.
It's more of a relationship drama, one that works as a showcase for two great performances against a post-apocalyptic backdrop that ups the stakes...

[Boots] Riley is swinging for the fences here, with a clear vision of what he's after, and on the whole, he succeeds tremendously. It's a fantastical, weird, funny, devastating movie, and it proves Riley is a director worth watching.

Bisbee '17 is a fierce, lyrical probe into the soul of a town haunted by a history it would rather forget. It's also an unsettling cipher for America, in a year when the ghosts of our past revealed themselves in frightening ways.

It's the sheer silliness of the proposition... that makes Early Man hum along.

Vital, searing, and engaging.

That's the most accurate picture of America that this American can imagine: a land of competing narratives, where the only thing everyone can agree on is that lots of stuff has gone wrong, even if we can't agree on exactly what that stuff is.
A workmanlike comedy with some fun surprises hidden along the way...

I can't shake the feeling that we ought to have been listening to Joan Didion more carefully all along.
movie_title: Joan Didion: The Center Will Not Hold (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A Bad Moms Christmas is thin and silly, like an overlong Christmas episode of a sitcom you pair with some reheated lo mein when you can't figure out what else to do on a stray weeknight.

Directed by Rob Reiner from a screenplay by Joey Hartstone, the movie jumps around in time in a way that doesn't serve the story, and it feels caught between cynicism toward and valorization of Johnson.

... Gerwig is by far one of the most talented filmmakers working today, both onscreen and behind the camera, confident and winsome in a way nearly unparalleled by her contemporaries.

You couldn't call it a hopeful film, exactly. But there is plenty of hope around the edges.
While the movie's premise feels prone to the maudlin, it's ultimately quite poignant...

... remarkable for how it turns literature into pure cinema, all emotion and image and heady sensation.

What we get of Marshall in Marshall is fascinating; if only there was more.

Hacksaw Ridge, the first movie Mel Gibson has directed in a decade, is about as Mel Gibson as you can get: grisly, devout, and patriotic, with a deeply complicated core.

movie_review_blurb: The movie feels flat and small, lacking the novel's energy and expansive ambition.

King Arthur: Legend of the Sword is a goofy, splendid medieval romp that also makes a distinctly English case for a moderate populism.

Unfortunately, Alien: Covenant is not really up to bearing the weight of the yarn it wants to spin.

Trumped is a missed opportunity.

A humourless mess.

movie_review_blurb: Harry Potter and The Half-Blood Prince succeeds in being a much more immersive film than normal. It's still not quite up there with The Prisoner of Azkaban, but it comes close to capturing on film some of the texture and richness of Rowling's books.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Enjoyably trippy, brain-bending stuff, but the most satisfying thing about Moon is that it marks a return to the notion of science fiction as a genre fuelled by big ideas rather than big special effects.

An incredible documentary that serves as a remarkable testament to the power of the recorded image.

movie_review_blurb: A credible, high-stakes thriller. Cracking stuff.

Writer/producer/star Emma Thompson resurrects the titular, magic-practising child-carer of her 2005 Mary Poppins-riffing hit for yet more old-fashioned, family-centric fun in this slightly improved sequel.

Carrey demonstrates an ability to successfully flit between the kind of flat-out slapstick physical humour with which he made his name and that darker, more disturbing strain of comedy he never quite nailed in early efforts such as The Cable Guy.
A likeable but giggle-free Brit comedy that brings nothing new to the ubiquitous mockumentary format, it succeeds only in gumming its targets instead of sinking its teeth into them.
A heartfelt, brain-bending mystery just slippery enough for answers to remain tantalisingly out of reach.
Keaton's directorial style is as muted as his uncharacteristically subdued performance, but it remains strangely compelling.
Descent: Part 2 completely destroys the first film's ambiguous tone.
The presence of Ridley and Tony Scott's names among Crack's 16 listed producers is probably the main reason it's currently in a cinema near you, rather than languishing in development hell.
Inoffensively bland.
It's no candidate for greatness, but it deserves to find an audience among connoisseurs of doomsday cinema.
This is filmmaking hard-wired straight to the heart: wild, untamed and quite, quite brilliant.
Such randomness never amounts to anything profound in this vapid little film, no matter how much Dos Santos dresses it up with New Wave-inspired visual flourishes and dated hipster soundtrack cues.
At times it's wince-inducingly weak, and no amount of lush visuals can disguise that. Nor can they disguise how second-hand everything feels.
Though often very funny, writer/director Lynn Shelton's film lacks some of the insight into the awkwardness of male friendship found in recent mainstream comedy hits.
There are plenty of lame pop-culture references to Apocalypse Now and Taxi Driver, should any losing-the-will-to-live parents need a final push over the edge.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A sex comedy with plenty of sex, not enough comedy, and nowhere near enough smarts to pull off its final act attempts at Midnight Cowboy-style pathos.
Punishingly lame and containing little romance to compensate for the absence of comedy.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It sort of works by virtue of the fact that his protagonists repeatedly look to the past in their frustration with the present. Still, that perhaps says more about Naranjo than the youth of today.
This balance of brain and brawn skews too far in the wrong direction, with a few too many mindless action sequences overcompensating for the shortcomings of a tedious story.
Linklater slyly chips away at this insular world, quietly opening it up in magical ways to reveal a hugely entertaining portrait of the maverick auteur at his bravura best.

The worst film of the year is here...for its absolute awfulness, for its mind-numbing shallowness, for its smug and self-satisfied cast, and for its ability to wreck Daniel Day-Lewis's otherwise unblemished record.
Scores points for actually investing time in scenes depicting the extent to which she worked on her art.
A horribly shrill seasonal flick.
This nicely performed French drama puts a human face on the ripped-from-the-headlines immigration theme, telling an absorbing, if contrived, tale.

Sort of like a twee version of Curb Your Enthusiasm, it's this blurring of fact and fiction that transforms Paper Heart into a rom-com for the cynical reality-TV age, one that smartly uses documentary elements to provide real heart.
A sedate, intelligent and quietly sensuous film.
As a slice of histrionic Charles Bronson-esque revenge cinema, it pushes all the right buttons.
Haneke... relies on intimidating us into submission with his supposed intelligence. But his superiority and sneering contempt is unearned.

What should have been a soaring, inspirational, complex epic has been grounded by bad storytell ADVERTISEMENT ing, chocolate-box visuals, rubbish star turns and another awful US accent from a Ewan McGregor.
Emmerich attempts to outdo himself in every reel, but the end result is too long, too cheesy and too lacking in self-awareness to be the brain-off, block-busting thrill ride it should have been.
Lee's film, rambling and maddeningly vague as it often is, does manage eventually to get at why something so ephemeral meant so much to so many.
Purporting to be a true story of alien abduction, in reality it's a clumsy attempt to update the hoax technique Orson Welles perfected seven decades ago.

It's a precious, whimsical premise, but while Barthes has some decent jokes, and a wonderful facilitator for those jokes in Giamatti, its underlying insights aren't all that profound and this ultimately feels more formulaic than it should.
Not vintage Coen brothers... but they're still filmmakers to love, even if they sometimes make it increasingly difficult to do so.
This is Soderbergh having fun with his craft again - and inviting us to join in the laughs.

Over-stylised and undernourished, French director R√©mi Bezan√ßon relies a little too heavily on clich√©d cinematic catastrophes to provide dramatic momentum to what is at heart a rather unspectacular saga of familial discord and reconciliation.
movie_title: Le Premier Jour du Reste de ta Vie (The First Day of the Rest of Your Life) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A creepy, unsettling little shocker, the premise of which is so simple aspiring film-makers the world over will be slapping themselves on the forehead for not thinking of it first.
A morally dubious, deliriously demented thriller.
Visually stunning and endearingly quirky.
[A] moving, emotionally direct biopic.

The erroneously titled It's Complicated revels in reducing smart, intelligent women to mewling morons whose ability to attract the attentions of past-their-prime leading men somehow counts as progress.
Moral complexity courses through Mugabe and the White African, adding extra dimensions to a story that unfurls with much more heart-in-mouth tension than your average thriller.
All credit to Cera for trying something a little different. It's just a shame Youth in Revolt feels so episodic and shapeless that it's hard to take any pleasure in its theatre of cruelty.
The animation is lush and the screwball dynamic between Tiana and Naveen lively.

Julien Temple concludes his cinematic history of punk with an origins story, making a persuasive, highly entertaining case for why rabble-rousing musical renegades Dr Feelgood are the unsung progenitors of the movement.
The presence of Danny Dyer, meanwhile, has likely tipped you off to the fact that it's a) set in a world of Brit gangsters, and b) not very good.
Holy crap, more like. This dismal "oirish" comedy fails to raise a single laugh from its limp premise.

Their dynamic is the main strength of the film; it's just a shame so much reverence has been paid to the novel's many twists and turns. It's paced more like a TV mini-series than a cinematic experience.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The most fascinating aspect of the film, though, is the way it intensifies the mystique of drummer Meg White.
movie_title: The White Stripes Under Great White Northern Lights (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Though Egoyan, as usual, frequently strains credibility he at least manages to weave all of this into a fairly absorbing detective story that explores the roots and damaging implications of prejudice with unexpected grace.

Greengrass -- reuniting with Damon -- does so with plenty of verve, plunging us into the chaos of the conflict in its earliest days and gradually pulling into focus a clear-headed narrative of what might have happened.
Luridly entertaining.

The Bounty Hunter fails to locate any laughs or charm over two punishing hours as its chemistry-free leads, Gerard Butler and Jennifer Aniston, mug their way through two of the worst performances they've ever given.
[It] may be a sign that age has finally caught up with this once most agile of action heroes.
A strange and absorbing psycho-drama exploring class division and the suppression of guilt among Argentina's privileged classes.
movie_title: La Mujer sin Cabeza (The Headless Woman) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: First-time director Tom Harper creates a suitably foreboding atmosphere, ensuring that even if the dramatic turns the film takes stretch credibility, the film feels like a sincere reflection of its protagonist's world.
You've never experienced horror until you've seen Robin Williams in a Speedo getting a spray tan.
Even in CG-animated form, Nicolas Cage has ridiculous hair.

Invictus does leave you feeling oddly satisfied, but it's a very fleeting satisfaction, perhaps because its rainbow nation conclusion immediately starts to ring hollow once the euphoria of the triumphant sports movie ending subsides.
It's no candidate for greatness, but it does a good job of condensing a six-hour story into a lean thriller without feeling as if too much has been sacrificed.

Though he frequently makes use of the kind of gritty aesthetic usually associated with social realism, he's not afraid of throwing more polished visual flourishes, fantasy sequences and moments of comedy into the mix.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Watchable, but somewhat mechanical; mark it down as a C/C minus, and hold out for the DVD.
The film's desire to avoid enforcing a story arc on the girls - who remain in a state of constant bemusement through out - makes it difficult to engage with the film as a whole.
Daybreakers is one of the most purely pleasurable genre films of recent months.
The film seems a bit too in thrall to U2, which means far too much time is devoted to The Edge at the expense of watching Page fire through some of his thunderous Led Zeppelin riffs.
Its high-minded, this-is-good-for-you equation of bleakness with brilliance works against it a little, serving up many of the same allegorical ideas as a George Romero film.
For all the sharp one-liners and breezy visuals that sometimes suggest the film might be in danger of floating away into the ether, Reitman remembers to add some weight to proceedings.
Despite a committed, nakedly emotional performance from Winstone and some juicy turns from Hurt, McShane and Dillane in particular, it makes for pretty tedious stuff.
Really, who cares? The essence of the story has been lost in the process. Give me The Muppet Christmas Carol any day.
As Hollywood's most box-office-friendly female star, surely it's about time Sandra Bullock started challenging herself with something more worthy of her comic talents.
Its loopiness is fervent, but the Hugheses really do know how to move the camera, and Gary Whitta's script offers up a steady parade of fanboy treats.

With its shaky camera zooms and ridiculous abundance of split-screens shots, it also nails once again the stylistic quirks of the pop films of the 1960s in a way that's more astute than Austin Powers and funnier than recent Hollywood efforts.
