movie_review_blurb: Raw yet stylish, exhilarating but never overwhelmingly so, it's the kind of muscular filmmaking that exudes authoritative power without reverting to histrionics. It also remains thoroughly alive to the way movies can excite on a primal level.
Jim Sheridan smartly retains Bier's deceptively simple plotting, which provides a solid foundation for him to explore the emotional journeys of his characters.
Clive Owen gets a decent showcase for his more sensitive side in this otherwise middling drama.
Somehow securing cinematic distribution when its script, plot and execution scream straight-to-DVD, Armoured is the worst kind of B-movie: a dull one.

Part front-row peepshow, part history lesson, new documentary Burlesque Undressed is actually more of an extended promo for its producer and star, Immodesty Blaize, than a serious attempt to examine the resilience of burlesque over the years.
A sturdy, hard-hitting account.
It's beyond laughable ...
Rohrwacher creates a moving, unsentimental portrait of a dying way of life.
An effortlessly slick medical thriller that makes no grand statements or summations beyond being effortlessly artful and entertaining.
As quietly damning as it is tragically hopeful.
Sci-fi with a big emotional sweep is tough to get right.
Another quietly brilliant example of some of the great narrative documentary filmmaking currently being done in Scotland.
Like its hero it's full of magic, but endearingly modest with it.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The way it gleefully embraces the violent, racist and misogynistic impulses of its ageing white male protagonists in post-recession America makes it feel sickeningly apropos.

Marcus is constantly reminded of the fact that even small mistakes can have serious consequences and the film uses this to subtly explore whether an emphasis on conformity cultivates a fatalistic psyche by forcing us to deny our most basic yearnings.
Your Name exploits anime's limitless potential to tell a poignant love story that incorporates gender identity and cosmic wormholes to dazzling narrative effect.
Brad Pitt and Marion Cotillard find themselves at the centre of not just one but two of the most risible scenes of the year.
[Jarmusch's] best in a decade.
It's been a while since there's been a gripping serial killer movie, but Kiyoshi Kurosawa's new film Creepy more than lives up to its title.

Younger takes care to keep things rooted in the real and he's aided by Teller and Eckhart, who give it their all in a movie that ultimately celebrates the simple power of living for the thing you love most.
Where the film succeeds in a big way - aside from casting Hanks and Eckhart - is the recreation of the emergency landing itself and its immediate aftermath: it's thrilling, heart-in-mouth stuff.

Chi-Raq doesn't all work, but it's simultaneously righteous and bawdy enough to get its message across in entertaining fashion and features a great performance from up-and-coming actress Teyonah Parris in the lead.
Though the film isn't exactly deep, Steinfeld makes it watchable and there's amusing support from Woody Harrelson as her wry teacher.
Too often the Dardennes rely on their ultra-naturalistic style and socially aware themes to excuse some pretty contrived and unconvincing plotting. A rare misfire.
Though Baxter recycles a lot of material from the first two films, he gets some interesting results ,,,

Parker's decision to use the tropes of the Hollywood historical epic is a political statement in itself, one made more pointed by the title's bold repudiation of DW Griffith's cinematically ground-breaking, horrifyingly racist 1915 epic of the same name.
There's a genuinely uplifting true story behind A Street Cat Named Bob. Sadly this film version - based on James Bowen's best-selling memoir of the same name - is too twee to do it justice ...
The thriller elements have genuine gut-wrenching power, but everything around them is comically severe.
Various high-level flunkies meet their match in Theroux's calm, collected and actually very respectful approach.
Oyelowo and Pike generate so much heartfelt chemistry it never feels like we're being preached at. The result is absorbing mainstream cinema, a great story told with real craft and flair.
A remarkable drama about a young black American man wrestling with his sexuality in a society already prejudiced against him because of the colour of his skin.

A bold, beautiful and way-out-there female revenge story that eschews the bloodless nature of most costume dramas to revel in the lusty passions, kinky hobbies and digit-dicing proclivities of its main characters.
It's a story about grief and redemption, but it's told with the same complexity, depth and humour as [Lonergan's] debut film, You Can Count On Me.
Mixing animation and heartfelt storytelling, the film features an impressive break-out performance from Edinburgh actor Lewis MacDougall in the central role.
Serves up a nonsensical plot, lots of bright colours and a raft of celebrity voices, but not much else.
What emerges is a sprawling coming-of-age film that deliberately tempers the romanticism of the landscape with the rawness of a life lived tethered to the bottom rung of the societal ladder.

It takes real effort to make a film as heroically awful as Inferno, so if nothing else Ron Howard and Tom Hanks deserve credit for their ongoing commitment to bringing the Dan Brown-sourced franchise to the big screen in such dire fashion.

Mostly ... this is a weird and witty breath of fresh air- and as a bonus it also finds a neat solution to the excessive third-act destruction of The Avengers/Captain America films without stinting on spectacle.
This exploration of the birth and development of the internet is nothing if not entertaining.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A lovely and poignant animated adaptation of Raymond Briggs's picture book biography of his eponymous working class parents.
Features good performances from Tom Riley and Joanne Froggatt as the couple trying to come to terms with very altered lives.
Sang-ho can't quite resist a last-minute lurch towards sentimentality, but for the most part he keeps this moveable feast for the undead on track with relentless and bloody carnage.
Rain Man meets Batman in The Accountant, an enjoyably silly action movie starring Ben Affleck as an on-the-spectrum forensic accountant who doubles up as a secret vigilante.
Though the cast (which includes Rachel Weisz) does some good work, it's too controlled to rip you apart the way a film like this should.
Has almost no redeeming features beyond providing empty entertainment for a couple of hours, which it mostly excels at doing.
In its own typically bombastic way, the film is not unentertaining.
An office-based (and less funny) riff on last Christmas's superior Tina Fey/Amy Poehler hit Sisters.
A funny, post-modern riff on the entire canon of big and small screen adaptations of the Caped Crusader.

Mills brings the era alive with spot-on pop culture asides, but he smartly makes the movie all about Bening, who crafts a brilliant portrait of a woman unwilling to pamper her son or shield him from the realities of her own life ...
The execution is a little amateurish, but it's watchable enough.
A chaste coming-of-age tale about a gay teens learning to be true to themselves in a rugby-obsessed private school in Ireland.
It never feels exploitative, just nurturing. By the end you'll just want to give them a big hug and tell them everything is going to be alright.
It understands how capture the anxiety of childhood, but also its vibrancy and its joys.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The convoluted story takes a while to get to grips with, but once the action kicks in, it's frequently dazzling - and fairly extreme.
Strange and unsettling ...
A film that's undeniably tense and about as exciting as action movies get. Yet it never feels exploitative or artificially emotive.
If Best's story is a cautionary tale that's become a clich√© across all walks of life, Gordon's film functions as a useful reminder that there's always a human being behind such tales.
A fairly goofy monster movie that manages to seem bloated even with a running time of less than 90 minutes.
Singularly fails to dramatise the genocide at the story's core with the cinematic force it deserves.
The fight scenes are entertainingly brutal, but the consequences are bloody and the emotional stakes high. It's an elegiac superhero movie that understands there's no living with killing.
Reichardt transforms these subtle, subtext-laden tales into achingly humanistic cinema, making for a film that's moving, funny and absurd in all the ways that life is.
Chadha weaves together various emotive subplots with varying degrees of success, resulting in a film that's watchable enough but one that also sometimes feels a little lightweight.

Washington and co-lead Viola Davis deliver Wilson's loquacious dialogue with such dazzling force that their combined screen presence renders any thoughts about the cinematic limitations of his approach obsolete.
The film offers a fascinating testament to the power and limitations of movies as tools for understanding and communicating with the world around us.
It's mildly diverting, but nothing more.
Rich, funny, rewarding and ultimately moving.
One of the most exhilarating in the series, a film with a real sense of how to tell a story - and tell it well.

The latest whack-a-doodle slab of gooey cosmic nonsense to star Will Smith.

There's a reason this has sat on a shelf for two years.
A sincere, austere, intellectually rigorous attempt to grapple with God's silence in the face of human suffering.
It's not hard to see the appeal - or indeed admire the ambition of Chazelle, who's still in his early 30s (La La Land is only his third movie).
Affleck - directing for the first time since Argo - just can't quite make it come alive on screen.
Don't expect a comprehensive biopic of the wife, mother, widow, tastemaker and White House style icon. This is a rigorous exploration of Jackie Kennedy's steely determination ...

The effect is entrancing: an expressionistic portrait of the itinerant lifestyle her career dictates and a subtle exploration of the ethics and practices involved in documenting the world in a truthful way.

Stripped of any melodrama, the film does a good job of laying out the particulars of the case and the significance it had in terms of challenging the US constitutional ban on interracial marriage.
The film does nothing innovative with its source material: it simply streamlines the plot to a manageable length without bothering to flesh out any of the characters.

Burton's macabre sensibility and a delicious performance from Eva Green as shape-shifting Miss Peregrine (a Burton heroine if ever there was one) enlivens the tortuous plotting and dreary world building.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Proving that originality can sometimes be overrated, the Sundance-hyped Swiss Army Man is like set of non-existent clothes draped over a big name actor determined to show there's more to him than the franchise that made him a star.
Expanded from writer/director Rachel Tunnard's Bafta-nominated short, the film itself feels hopelessly stretched.
Fast's determination to embrace the philosophical ideas at the heart of the story ensures it has an intriguingly weird identity all its own.
A flat and rather pointless retread, gentle to the point of being soporific and a waste of a wonderful cast.
A darkly funny and increasingly disturbing portrait of a young woman's descent into madness after the traumatic loss of her artist father.
Only marginally less boring to watch than an actual magic show.
The ubiquity of blockbuster cinema's wrecking-ball impulse has diminished its impact in the years since ...
Refn demonstrates admirable boldness in his ongoing determination to challenge the form at a time when too much arthouse cinema is, in its own way, as formulaic as the comic book-obsessed mainstream.

It's the fifth instalment of the animated franchise and is as tired as you might expect from a series with this many entries.

There's a suspicion that Perkins' beautiful and expressionistic camera work...is masking the possibility that his subject is really just a bit of a windbag. Still, the tension between these two dynamics proves oddly compelling.

An illuminating, thought-provoking and depressingly timely film.

The film subtly links the complex bureaucracy required to pursue stability between nations with the fostering of certain conditions that allow resentful egotists with dangerous ideas to flourish if we let them.

Never really takes flight the way it should.

Cranking up the tension by gradually moving his camera in closer and closer to his actors, Alvarez smartly shrinks the distance between them and us in order to intensify the what-would-you-do? discomfort the experiment was designed to explore.

The way the film explores the distorting effect of memory is nicely done and Eisenberg, riffing once again on his innate unlikeability, makes his character's curious behaviour strangely compelling.

This film may excel at building anticipation for cool things coming a year or two down the line, but does a movie called Captain America that leaves you wishing you were watching one called Spider-Man really count as a win for blockbuster fans?
Plausibility clearly wasn't a prime concern here.
Neither the plot nor the characters seem particularly plausible on the big screen.

An intense siege movie that gives familiar tropes a blistering makeover courtesy of a precision-engineered plot, a thorough understanding of the world in which it's set and a gnarly and uncompromising approach to violence.

Beautifully told, and infused with dread, death and demons - everything, in short, that makes a good kids' film.

movie_review_blurb: In aspiring to present itself as a diverting mainstream action film, this only ever manages to be a diverting mainstream action film. Magnificence never enters the equation.

A crude, lewd, food-themed riff on Toy Story that basically functions as an animated parable about organised religion.

Fascinating viewing, offering a more sensitive counterpoint to the efforts of various news organisations to brand what she did an elaborate and cynically motivated hoax.

If The Shallows sounds like the name of a sitcom family composed of character-types from dumb movies, it is at least an accurate description of everything related to this idiotic shark movie, not least its heroine.
Grim and dispiriting viewing.

movie_review_blurb: Trespass Against Us finds Michael Fassbender trying out a West Country accent that's about as convincing as the film's efforts to blend genre thrills with earnest family drama.

This uneven but intermittently lacerating and wry film ... won't exactly leave you feeling happy, but may leave you feeling happy that Solondz is still casting his misanthropic eye over middle America.

With enough respect to eschew the easy option of modernising it with a hip and radical make-over, it's kind enough to the characters to get round the problematic sexual politics of the story without making a big statement about them.

A sharp satire about the middle-aged fear of youth.

movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: In maintaining the period setting, Ullmann hasn't found a way to make the themes feel particularly relevant and, despite the committed performances, the intended naturalism of the play feels too theatrical on film.
Genz piles on lots of tedious and increasingly silly plot turns involving shoot-outs in London and domestic fights involving nail-guns - all en route to a lame, cop-out ending.
Dowdle takes admirably sick delight in putting his protagonists through the wringer.
The script is formula and so is the direction, which leaves the acting.

When I walked out during the end credits, Voight was spying on our triumphant heroines through binoculars, making me feel even dirtier than when I sheepishly approached the box office and requested, "One for Bratz, please."
The Salesman is conclusive proof that a social realist film doesn't have to avoid showcasing storytelling ambition when documenting real life issues.
Even though it has visual beauty that makes it required viewing on the big screen, I can't endorse Crimson Peak or claim it is anything more significant than a disappointment.

The Lobster is the kind of movie that can cure anybody going through a period of messy emotional distress, due to how sharply it satirises the ritualistic natures of relationships and single-life, taking its parody to levels of science-fiction extremity.
Although it is emotionally and thematically overwhelming throughout, Son of Saul is undeniably essential viewing.

Green Room may be perceived as needlessly and excessively nihilistic; instead, Saulnier's film is gloriously unpredictable, a unique thriller that rips up the rule book whilst paying deliriously gory tribute to it.
The Assassin feels like a stereotype of a movie that will be beloved by critics but reviled by audiences, even within art house and genre film circles.

A film for anybody who has ever fallen in and out of love, dealing with hopeless infatuation and the slow transition to the messy reality that all but threatens to burn out the initial spark, Carol is more than just a gorgeously crafted period piece.

Like many esteemed classics of the genre, Bone Tomahawk is an exploitation movie at heart, but has the courage of its convictions to treat its material as a gory grindhouse feature, albeit one made with love and effort.
Abrams makes the Star Wars movie every fan wants to see, and it succeeds effortlessly at doing more than merely cashing in on nostalgia.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: If you find family get togethers to be insufferable, they are nowhere near as painstaking as Dolan's latest effort.
movie_title: It's Only the End of the World (Juste la fin du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Joy is far from Joyful; with an uninteresting narrative, performances that feel drained of passion and a filmmaker caught between his roots and his new-found mainstream sensibility, it is an utter mess.

Good Morning Karachi simplifies [...] Pakistani culture to an extent that it merely feels like Pakistan is a society equivalent to the US, with those holding on to its old, unique identity clearly being depicted as villains suppressing change.

Mockingjay Part 2 is a satisfying conclusion overall, with the franchise as a whole being so satisfying within the dismal dystopian YA genre that it only feels disappointing considering what has come before.
Trespass Against Us is an overwhelmingly forgettable film, telling an unoriginal story with no artistic swagger that can make it feel fresh again.

The Sense of an Ending makes more sense as a novel than a feature film; on screen [...] It is a commendable effort from both director and cast, but it can't be viewed as anything other than an admirable failure at best.
It expands its dystopian universe in a way that's both thrilling to its young target audience as well as developing the social and political problems facing Panem in a way that's rather satisfying.
Free Fire may be far from the best movie of the year, but you are guaranteed to have one of your most fun times at the movies when checking out Wheatley's latest.
Mine is convoluted and utterly confused about the story it is telling, building up to one of the most infuriatingly anti-climactic finales in recent memory.
Aquarius is the excellent new film from director Kleber Mendon√ßa Filho, which upon viewing appears to be simply a heartfelt look at the personal cost of gentrification.
A strong contender for funniest film of the year, yet so much more than just a comedy, Lost in London is the rare film to live up to its lofty ambitions.
Some movies hit you in the head, but Jawbone aims squarely for the heart, and as familiar as it may be, you'd need a heart of stone not to walk out feeling a bit moved.
Despite all of its faults, Wild engaged me on a purely emotional level [...] I truly believe its heart is in the right place. When it connects emotionally, the tears you will shed are well-earned.
It takes me back to the joy of reading about Paddington as a child without making it feel nostalgic due to the new approach to the story. It's far from perfect, but it is an essential to view.

Every time it seems that Hollywood may finally be winding down with their producing of endless unnecessary remakes, a movie like Annie comes along to remind us just how creatively bankrupt the mainstream movie industry remains.
To call Mr. Turner one of the year's most overrated films seems unfair, as it's worth watching for beautiful cinematography and a plethora of gentle laughs.
Still Alice is a close-to-heartbreaking portrait of mental illness and a genuinely effecting character study.
With the feminist themes lurking in the background but never explored in a satisfying manner, The Keeping Room is hard to see as anything other than a missed opportunity.

It Follows is too uneven to fully recommend, but it does contain some of the most disturbing horror imagery. Far from the best horror movie of the year, it is still a vital reminder of how boundary-pushing American genre movies used to be.
It is the rare film that is unclassifiable in terms of genre, refusing to neatly fit in to the preconceptions of a horror film, as well as lacking a distinctive explanatory reading.
How to Win at Checkers is annoyingly uneven, a character study that has fleshed out the least interesting elements and left the engaging ones firmly in the margins.
movie_title: How to Win at Checkers (Every Time) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Red Turtle is a wondrous work of animation, that will surprise with how it hides profundity within its seemingly simplistic narrative.
Rams isn't the film that is going to definitively put Iceland on the world cinema map, but it is the boldest invitation yet about the distinctive tone of their cinema.

In Focus, Will Smith's suave con artist Nicky Spurgeon tells his prot√©g√©/part-time lover Jess Barrett (Margot Robbie) his version of the done-to-death clich√©: there are two types of people, hammers and nails.
Yet another example of how Mungiu masterfully weaves an intimate character drama into an intelligent commentary on injustices in Romanian society.
Toni Erdmann has a few show-stopping sequences that give the allusion of an arthouse crowd pleaser, yet the laughs are spread too thin across the overlong and dull narrative.
Mindhorn is a cult comedy classic in waiting and is almost certainly the strongest contender for funniest film of 2017.
Julieta is heartfelt throughout, but the dry manner in which the story unfolds renders it forgettable, especially compared to Alm√≥dovar's previous movies.
The Handmaiden is Park Chan-Wook's best directorial effort since Oldboy, a near perfect blend of awesome visual style and engaging narrative.
A United Kingdom has plenty of flaws, but more than makes up for them with a heart and an affection that is utterly intoxicating.
Sachs demonstrates his ability to make fantastic character dramas, with an ear for realistic dialogue and a satirical swipe at the middle classes.
You've Been Trumped Too is pitched solely at the comatose viewer, as there is absolutely nothing in Anthony Baxter's film that you won't already be aware of.
There are plenty of great things about American Honey, but when stretched out to an incomprehensibly epic length, it is hard to see it as anything other than wasted potential.
The Unknown Girl aims for higher narrative stakes than your average social realist drama, yet it is ultimately defeated by limited scope and underwritten characters.
Bad Santa 2 is a poorly conceived cash-in that has fortunately backfired in every conceivable way.
With so many layers of meta commentary blurring the lines between reality and film, Be My Cat is an enjoyably oddball watch.
movie_title: Be My Cat: A Film for Anne (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Ordinary World is charming in spite of its sheer predictability.
I, Daniel Blake is passionate filmmaking to its very core, as well as the rare art house effort that could stand a chance with mainstream audiences.
The Girl With All the Gifts is a distinctive entry to the zombie genre.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Deepwater Horizon may seem like forgettable blockbuster fare but it is refreshing to see a mega budget movie with something more than just mindless explosions on its mind.
War on Everyone is a mess in every conceivable way.
If you acclimatise to its unique blend of melodrama and realism, then My King is an arresting watch throughout, with plenty of reasons to recommend.
Mustang is an utterly arresting coming-of-age story - and most importantly, one that vitally needs to be told.
There is more to like in Sing Street than there is to hate, but it is the missteps that truly stay with you.
Everybody Wants Some is nothing more than Dazed and Confused's empty cousin.
Dheepan should be a work of social-realism that helps us understand their plight, but only in the small moments does it feel the sum of its humanist intentions.
As modern critics lament the death of the genre, Forsaken is a reminder as to why Westerns went out of fashion in the first place.
Louder than Bombs subverts preconceptions so slyly, many audiences and critics will be easily forgiven for thinking it is nothing more than a work of morose egotism.
High-Rise's rushed, unfocused narrative renders this more an admirable failure than a subversive cult classic in waiting.
Remember is a gloriously trashy thriller, turning a narrative that could have easily been prestige season awards-bait into pure nonsensical pulp.
Spending time with these talentless idiots will be a thankless task, but with a premise that never runs out of steam, You're Killing Me is a cult gem waiting to be found.
Delivering neither on engrossing action or effective satire, this mess is Cohen's worst film to date.
The problem with Triple 9 isn't that it is an uber-masculine piece of genre fiction - it is that it is a formulaic one without a distinctive personality.
Although it may not be for everyone due to its pitch-black tone, Wild Tales is a film that I imagine everybody who sees it can relate to in some way.
This is exquisite filmmaking, from an aesthetically accomplished director who you can feel falling in love with these characters as much as the audience are.
Despite the numerous faults, Catch Me Daddy is effortlessly gripping throughout, with its significant flaws only coming to light after an anti-climactic ending.
45 Years is unquestionably well-written and well-acted, to such a high degree that is literally impossible to argue otherwise.
As well as being one of the most sickeningly overrated films of the year, Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is one of the worst.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Mistress America doesn't fully succeed with what it sets out to do - renewing a tired comedy sub-genre for a new and more cynical generation.
The Man From U.N.C.L.E. is thrilling in a way few action movies are, and certainly far more thrilling than anything Ritchie has directed up until this point.
In Lean on Pete, characters are first and foremost, leading to an finished product that is a knockout emotional triumph.
With nothing new to say on celebrity and most distressingly, nothing remotely funny whatsoever, Pickups feels at least twice as long as its running time.
This Is Our Land is essential viewing for its damning critiques, even if it is too thematically overblown.
In the hands of a director at the top of his game, Blade Runner 2049 is a blockbuster with brains, heart and an abundance of style, that will certainly reward repeat viewings.
Bad Genius is a gloriously preposterous work that is one of the most unique (and certainly one of the most enjoyable) heist movies in recent memory.
Foxtrot is a unclassifiable blend of black comedy, surrealism and socio-political drama that proves to be equal parts unflinching and unforgettable.
Brawl in Cell Block 99 is a gloriously inventive and deliriously dark thriller that's definitely not for the faint of heart.
Last Flag Flying is a forgettable effort from a filmmaker capable of far greater things.
In a rather weak year for big screen comedy, The Death of Stalin can easily stake a claim as the year's funniest film.

Mr. Holmes isn't another fast-paced adaptation of the character that pop-culture has become used to recently, but a quiet character piece that is radical in its introduction of a revisionist history for the character.
In A Fantastic Woman, the substance outweighs the style, as this is an empathetic, wonderful and highly significant cinematic achievement.
Small Town Crime is so overly familiar, that I found myself forgetting it mere moments after exiting the auditorium.
The Shape of Water is del Toro's finest film since Pan's Labyrinth, and certainly the best film he has ever made in the English language.
It's the rare film that, after the overwhelming first viewing experience, doesn't feel like hyperbole to call a genre redefining masterpiece.
Thematically tone deaf, stylistically inert and largely boring, I Love You, Daddy would be an awful film regardless of the news currently surrounding the writer/director.
Happy End is so poorly conceived, the film really lived up to its title by leaving me overjoyed when it finally, abruptly cut to the end credits.
Spielberg felt this story urgently needed to be told, yet he has left the story that needs to be heard firmly in the margins.

Although it has flaws, The Lost City of Z will surely be heralded as one of the finest films of our current era by future cinephiles, due to how it is such a loving throwback to the epics of bygone eras.
Phantom Thread is so thematically and performatively dense while maintaining a comedic lightness of touch, that it is one of Anderson's greatest achievements

For a studio whose storytelling style and command of visuals is so wonderfully inventive, here they've opted for the laziest, most obvious narrative trajectory imaginable, without even a winning sense of humour to back that up.
We may need another biopic to get the full depiction of Donald Crowhurst's ill fated voyage, but The Mercy is more than substantial, even in its current bare bones narrative state.
At this time in the year, where studios are churning out "dump month" genre movies with little artistic merit, a film like Double Lover feels all the more vital; it's trash cinema at its most artful.
Dark River feels like a transitional gateway to better films, bridging the gap between Barnard's older social realist efforts and flirtations with experimental works likely to come.
Annihilation does offer enough surreal horror within its visual spectacle to make it worth recommending to sci-fi fans, but I can't help but feel that it is fairly empty thematically.
The Meyerowitz Stories may feel like business as usual for Baumbach, but it's a quietly evolutionary step in his filmography.
As the closing piece of Marvel's hit-and-miss phase two, Ant-Man bodes well for the future of the MCU.

Clouds of Sils Maria is a lot more interesting than just being an arthouse takedown of the mainstream. Unfortunately, director Olivier Assayas is self-aware of this and his movie frequently comes across as too clever for it's own good.
Amy is an impressive piece of work, largely due to the editing, which manages to make even the most mundane bits of archive footage utterly compelling and emotionally captivating.

Child 44 is bland in every aspect, which is a shame as the source novel could have been turned into an exciting movie if it had the right directorial hands to guide it (as well as a more eye catching title, Child 44 sounds pretty boring in name alone).
The Shaun the Sheep movie won't change the world, but it should act as a wake up call for any animator who sees it - to stop pandering to your audiences and concentrate on entertaining them.
Its use of long-takes and other social realist filmmaking techniques mean it often plays too close to the bone, leaving you feeling uncomfortable more frequently than in fits of laughter.
The Duke of Burgundy is that rare thing that almost every movie promises, yet fails to deliver: it is something that you've never seen before.

Far From the Madding Crowd feels like a missed opportunity more than anything else, as instead of playing to the strengths of both author and director [...] it coasts on playing to the conventions of the same old stale period dramas.
Bad Rap takes an argument that deserves to be had in pop culture, then frustratingly refuses to explore it in the depth it deserves.
Although The Levelling is a familiar story of grief, it is told with an emotional incisiveness by a brand new talent that helps make it feel fresh.
Baby Driver is an indelible cinematic sugar rush and is further proof that Edgar Wright is the true saviour of popcorn cinema.
At its heart, A Ghost Story is a universally relatable story about grief on an intimate scale, transplanted onto a more epic canvas than you would have ever imagined possible.
Whitney: Can I Be Me is the best kind of music documentary.
Nolan has revitalised his approach to filmmaking, and the results are nothing less than awe inspiring.
Arguably the most crowd pleasing, least pessimistic of Kaurism√§ki's works, The Other Side of Hope neglects to explore the refugee crisis that gives it a contemporary relevance.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: With appropriately fiery performances from the entire ensemble, Gook is irresistible - equal parts harrowing and hilarious, not to mention thoroughly moving throughout.
Few movies are as perfect in showing the duality of ageing generations simultaneously distrusting the young whilst wishing they were young again - and even fewer are as funny and insightful as this.
Death Note has plenty of faults, but watched with the brain firmly in the "off" position, it becomes easy to enjoy.
Love & Mercy isn't a groundbreaking movie, but it doesn't need to be.
The jokes may unanimously fall flat, and The Tiger Hunter may offer no new insight into the immigrant experience, but it has a feel good, positive nature that redeems itself somewhat.
Even when handled with care, the sexualised portrayal of Ava feels exploitative, detracting from alls that makes Ava such a refreshing take on a female coming of age story.
You wouldn't get this kind of madness in a Hollywood action film, but its unimaginative fight scenes are more typical of Western filmmaking than the stylish madness of the East.
Loveless is undeniably worth seeing for its performances, but the apparent insight into corruption in Russia feels lacking, with the storyline too cold to get truly invested in.
Sim√≥n deserves all the plaudits for directing her young lead actress in a brilliantly naturalistic performance, which feels genuinely perceptive.
The Look Of Silence's harrowing nature means it is one of the best films I'll never watch again
Despite committed performances, The Voices can never transcend the inherent problems in its screenplay.
Tomorrowland is far from the worst blockbuster I've ever seen, which is the only thing I can really say in its favour.
A bad movie is still a bad movie, no matter how enjoyable; Big Game is merely the best a bad movie can be.
It is a boxing movie that fails to pull any punches - less Southpaw, more South Poor.
The fact that this unusual film not only works, but is one of the best of the year, is conclusive proof that Xavier Dolan has joined the top tier of directors.
Instead of being a generic horror or psychological thriller, The Gift is a superior drama with a plethora of thrilling moments.
God's Own Country makes a few forgivable missteps in an otherwise brilliantly assured debut from Francis Lee.

This is a movie lacking in life or vibrancy, or any real emotions for us to actually connect to or relate to the characters; it is enamoured by its subject matter and as such tries to make itself too respectful.
It's so good in every respect that it really doesn't need the plot alone to keep me engaged avidly.
... [director Jia Zhangke] brilliantly applies the unique formal properties of the wuxia mode-a film language wholly endemic to Chinese film history-to his idiosyncratic style...
Never shying away from the picturesque, the film depicts a vivid world that is crystal clear, gleaming, and suffused with life.
The undisguised perversity in the title of Louis C.K.'s new film bespeaks its general tenor of depravity and self-awareness.
It is a quite lovely film.
Even if you have no interest in American football this is a compelling and inspirational story that brings a tear to the eye.
It may not offer much depth on their achievements but it still is a perfect introduction to their lives.
movie_title: Eames: The Architect And The Painter (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Great routines, silly story but it still delivers infectious, energetic 3-D escapism.
A poignant, grandly entertaining 3-D Highland romp that will leave everyone wanting to give mum a big hug.
Morgan just skims the surface of most of the stories, leaving you disappointed and frustrated when something with potential goes unfulfilled.
Scott Thomas and Marmai are both fine in a film that could almost be a theatrical two-hander but the plot just doesn't hold water.
Beautifully photographed, maudlin and moving, bruising and bittersweet, Take This Waltz is a heartrending emotional roller coaster.
Another shameless dollop of mindless slaughter and corny one-liners.
It will all slide over painlessly when it turns up on television.
Director James Marsh is an award-winning documentary film-maker and he brings some finely honed observational skills to this tale.
The Imposter frequently sends your jaw hurtling to the floor as it tries to understand the great pretender and a family only too willing to accept him as one of their own.
Vaughn is now officially the Hollywood star you would most like to see announcing their retirement.
A film that is most definitely an acquired taste.
Peter Mullan adds gruff authority and class but there is not much else to commend this effort from writer/director/producer Dan Turner.
A lush, insightful drama exploring the tensions beneath the implacable face of modern Iran.
A breezy, undemanding adaptation of the bestselling novels that broke box-office records in France in 2009.
A modest, throwaway trifle but still entertaining.
So much talent in the service of such a forgettable film.

Will Kitty learn from her mistakes? Will she mature enough to be worthy of Levin's love and will he be gracious enough to forgive? His broken heart and her confusion create characters that are real and entirely believable.
Justice, decency and solidarity sometimes feel like old-fashioned virtues but they lie at the heart of The Snows Of Kilimanjaro.
Farhadi confirms his masterly way with heartrending human dramas.
The film is one snappy, fast-paced chase through the streets of Manhattan. Never mind the logic, feel the breeze.
There are a few stumbles along the way but with Brad Pitt and the cast in such fine form it is still a pretty memorable ride.
Beneath its saucy surface Hysteria is a rather sweet romantic comedy.
Veteran French star Francois Cluzet and award-winning comedian Omar Sy are both excellent and the chemistry between them really crackles.
Fine if you like your thrillers raw, bloody and unruly.
Take a box of hankies.
A strikingly original, melancholy work executed with painterly precision and still one of the more underrated films from this innovative director.
Becomes unintentionally funny by the grotesque closing stretch.
It may have some flaws but The Brooklyn Brothers Beat The Best is still the kind of underdog movie you want to clasp to your heart. It is an unexpected charmer.
movie_title: The Brooklyn Brothers Beat The Best (2012)

movie_review_blurb: What a missed opportunity.
This is a fascinating portrait of a man who has always had the courage of his convictions.
There's no shame for Pegg who throws himself into it with manic commitment.
Allen is endearing in his belief that any of his success has been a happy accident and that he has yet to make a great film that will stand the test of time.
An animatronic mountain lion proves to be the star of the show.
It has some charm but is quite underwhelming.
The first hour of Red Lights is pretty good, there is a great rapport between Weaver and Murphy and enough plot development to keep you intrigued.
A smug, academic thesis on the evils of capitalism, Cosmopolis is as exciting as someone reading you the entire book in a flat, unvarying monotone.
An absorbing and intelligent mixture of history lesson and forbidden romance.
Beautifully written and directed by the great Billy Wilder, bittersweet and heartfelt, this is sheer delight.
Preachy and cliched, Victim has some merit in the bantering dialogue and fresh, appealing performances but all the good intentions don't necessarily add up to a good film.
Spirited, upbeat and seasoned with musical sequences, Where Do We Go Now? has an abundance of charm.
It is an odd, low-key film but the brief running time ensures that it never overstays its welcome.
Corny and contrived, this provides both leading ladies with sweet ballads and tart one-liners and at least they resisted the temptation to set it all at Christmas.
The ending is a letdown but this is still a very promising debut from directors James Nunn and Ronnie Thompson.
A film that blurs reality and fantasy, inviting our laughter but also earning our sympathy.
A slow-burning film with echoes of Papillon in its celebration of an indomitable human spirit.
It does take a sledgehammer to crack a walnut and eventually falls victim to the law of diminishing returns but it doesn't pull its punches and is often outrageously funny.
Leaves you feeling that a mini-break or a long weekend might have been sufficient.
Around the gentle tale of romance and longing there are some serious comments on class, politics, the legacy of the Spanish Civil War and European life in the era of Mad Men.
movie_title: Les femmes du 6e √©tage (The Women on the 6th Floor) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Remarkable people in a heartwarming, inspirational film.
The humour is forced and slightly amateurish but sweet moments give this gentle tale some modest appeal.
movie_title: El alma de las moscas (The Soul of Flies) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A remarkably lyrical, strikingly beautiful documentary reflecting on memory, mortality and the inexorable passing of time.
It is pretentious and overbearing at times but passionate.
A slow-burning but satisfying drama that persuasively blends elements of Scum and Papillon.
The Dark Knight Rises is without doubt this year's unmissable summer blockbuster.
A surprisingly optimistic progress report.
All fascinating stuff if a little repetitive and rambling but definitely one for fans.
movie_title: Something from Nothing: The Art of Rap (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Well-researched and essential viewing for Bruce Lee fans.
A film that deserves to be better known and a welcome reminder of what a fine actress the late Yvonne Mitchell was.
A film that convinces you that individuals' actions can make a difference.
A tenderly observed portrait of a man aching for romance even as he resists the idea of full commitment.
Trite and predictable but the musical numbers have heart and there is a poignancy in seeing Houston one last time.
The documentary feels a little slight but the images speak for themselves ...
False Trail may turn a little too conventional towards the showdown but it is well-paced and strongly acted.
There is an understanding of human frailty that makes the film more appealing than the subject matter might suggest.
A harrowing celebration of the human spirit and the will to survive.
Technically flawless The Impossible is a film with a raw emotional wallop that will move even the hardest heart.
Very few people embark on a new career at 75 but the warm, engaging Quartet proves that Dustin Hoffman is a director of considerable promise.
He speaks very powerfully of the dilemmas he has faced and the decisions required to maintain some sense of integrity in his work.
The films of Bruno Dumont are an acquired taste that many of us have yet to acquire.
Measured and thoughtful, What Richard Did rests on the charismatic shoulders of Jack Reynor who maintains our sympathy as his world spins and his true character is tested.
A tacky, low-budget film that is as blunt and obvious as the instruments Baz uses on his victims.
A thoughtful tale that is more a twisted romance than a typical shocker.
Whether it bears any resemblance to what actually happened is almost academic in a film that takes a precious moment in time and transforms it into a witty, civilised country house drama.
A film as absorbing and unassuming as the central character.
A mournful documentary that combines footage of Young in concert in Toronto with a bittersweet trip to his childhood home in Omemee in southern Ontario.
A clich√©d, wearily familiar true-life crime drama clearly made on the cheap.
As we witness the rehearsals, the recriminations and the disintegration of their relationship we gain a real sense of the high personal cost for those in pursuit of perfection.
This has been attracting a lot of enthusiasm from horror buffs but it is hard to see why.
A little overwrought in the final scenes, The King Of Pigs is still visually impressive and thought-provoking animation for adults nonetheless.
The thought-provoking storyline and attention to detail in the animation ensures King Of Pigs retains a strong dramatic wallop.
Hopelessly dated, poorly executed material.
The flashing blades and swirling choreography of the endless fight scenes and the charisma of Yeoh keep you engaged but the end result falls far short of her Crouching Tiger triumph a decade ago.
This is 40 minutes too long.
Let's just say it might be A Good Moment To Call It A Day.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Beautiful Creatures is silly supernatural tosh with lots of garish special-effects and a surprisingly decent cast.
Danny Boyle's bravura command of the film medium elevates the melodramatic Slumdog Millionaire into a dazzling crowd-pleaser teeming with the sights, sounds and sensations of modern India.
A wondrous bedtime story in which you always want to know what happens next.
Sentimental stuff but when an ailing Redgrave sings True Colours it really does bring a lump to your throat.
The fact that there is very little in the way of plot and dialogue means that you spend the best part of two hours looking at pretty pictures.
It is a sensitive, understated film but it does require a good deal of patience on the part of the viewer.
Solid may ultimately be the best word for this pleasing, middlebrow adaptation of Rushdie's 'unfilmable' book.

Ill Manors is not perfect and can only leave you feeling appalled and depressed about the state of the nation but there are still enough powerful moments, strong performances and film flourishes to make it well worth seeing.
The real triumph of The Hobbit is that Peter Jackson leaves you wanting more.
Class conflict, broken hearts, self-sacrifice and the muddy, senseless folly of war are all lightly touched upon in a starchy, old-fashioned drama.
On the surface the story may appear like a cartoon but it is the heart and soul beneath that make it special.
It is a disarmingly daft, anarchic romp that should leave younger children screaming with delight.
A fond celebration of a female friendship shaped by the threat of global annihilation and the first stirrings of the Swinging Sixties.
An idiosyncratic salute to an indomitable human spirit.
Irresistible pop nostalgia.
A muscular, wildly successful attempt to strip the lucrative James Bond franchise back to basics.
The Cloud Atlas is something of a glorious folly that is sometimes appealing, sometimes unfathomable but always handsomely mounted.
The 3D film is a celebration of their remarkable tenacity with enough high dramas and cute moments to keep you enthralled.
An enigmatic, heartfelt account of a vulnerable young boy's yearning for a better life.
It may seem slow and lugubrious but it draws you into these complex, contradictory lives the way a spider lures a fly into a web.
This low-budget throwback to Eighties slasher movies is stronger on gory deaths than lethal one-liners but if you have the stomach for it, it's an efficient little shocker.
You may well have concluded that these people have too much time on their hands but some of the arguments are strangely persuasive and Room 237 will fascinate film buffs.
The Master may not be to all tastes but it is a lyrical, spellbinding epic that tests the little grey cells in the way that few films do these days.
There is eye-opening footage of American missionaries declaring Uganda Ground Zero in a biblical war and powerful personal stories of individuals facing violence, intimidation and hatred.
The random, hectic storyline has little rhyme or reason, the unimaginative 3D feels like a rip-off and only Clemens seems to be taking this seriously.
A powerful tale of love against the odds.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Inevitably, it loses momentum as the premise runs its course but for a good part of the journey this road movie offers disturbingly good fun.
Director Gerry Fox has made countless, award-winning arts documentaries but has bitten off more than he can handle with his feature debut.
It is mannered, pretentious and ragged and yet it is beautifully crafted ...
An extraordinary account of true events from the 2004 tsunami, The Impossible cannot fail to move even the hardest heart.
Hit So Hard allows her to look back in candour as she reflects on her career and life ...
Told with real warmth and charm, this is a confidently handled tale boosted by natural, engaging performances from Venkatesh and Jahangir Badshah as his young friend.
Quirky and original, Up There feels more like an East German comedy from the Sixties than anything typically British but that is a big part of its charm.
Dour and obvious, this is a disappointing footnote to the original.
False Trail is well-paced and strongly acted with the piercing sunlight and beautiful landscapes contrasting nicely with the monstrous acts that unfold in them.

It is less fertile territory than what has gone before but no less satisfying for mystery fans and Sagnier shines in a role that really does allow her to run the gamut from innocent victim to femme fatale.
There are times when it grows on you but those awkward, lingering silences and some wooden performances conspire to make it challenging viewing.
A turgidly oppressive, lifeless film that can't even be recommended to collectors of cinematic oddities.
movie_title: Confession of a Child of the Century (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Bridesmaids, The Hangover and countless others have adequately covered the same territory and The Knot feels like a poor, cartoon-like imitation.
Little happens and everything that does is open to interpretation but feels like a gruelling reflection on a world at the end of time.
Smartly observed and bitterly funny, the deadpan Tiny Furniture feels true to life for an entire generation struggling to find a job and make their mark on the world.
Filmed over four years this documentary captures the blood, sweat and ceaseless commitment needed to compete at the highest levels of a sport.
There are traces of humour to alleviate the gloom of Oslo, August 31st and some beautiful incidental moments.
No wonder we all feel nostalgic for the past.
A fascinating salute to all creatures great and small.
Gritty social realism is equated with people vomiting and taking drugs and the low-budget aesthetic results in casual framing and lots of rough edges.
Duris brings an edgy vulnerability that makes him a sympathetic figure through a tale that never quite adds up.
Isn't there some little corner of Hollywood that still believes in the sweet and charming?
True romantics will fall under its spell.
Ultimately, Cars 2 isn't a bad film but it does have some deadly dull stretches and never hits top gear.
James is hardly the most versatile performer and his gibbering speeches, pratfalls and slapstick antics are awfully familiar.
It is incredibly noisy, messy, completely exhausting and feels as if it is never going to end.
Captain America takes you back to the simplicity of a Saturday morning serial where you cheered the hero and booed the villain.
A beautifully acted, deeply moving tale that brings a lump to the throat.
Arrietty is a magical piece of old-fashioned storytelling with a lovely musical score by C√©cile Corbel.
Beautiful images and a poetic sense of yearning are the virtues of this delicate tale.
The sentimental saga of a father and son's stoical struggle against impossible odds.
t may sound like a Stephen King horror yarn but The Tree's a meandering, mystical tale of dealing with a tragic loss.
Rise may be one of the best surprises this summer, a taut blockbuster with a real heart.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Lurching from breathless melodrama to Bond-like adventure it is never convincing but it is also never dull.
Shrewdly observed and sensitively handled this is a warm-hearted, civilised treat for anyone seeking refuge from the summer blockbusters.
movie_title: Gianni e le donne (The Salt of Life) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Strikingly shot and savage in its violence this is a white-knuckle ride through the most dangerous corners of the Brazilian city.
Azaria hams it up beyond the call of duty: someone should sign him up for panto.
Everyone bumbles along and the actors go into overdrive trying to convince us that this is all terribly hilarious but most of the time they are fighting a losing battle.
An unwieldy, quasi-operatic fable about manic depression, existential angst, transcendence and the end of the world.
A stylish but fatally unfocused piece.
The 3D technology adds some eye-popping moments but the best thing about this reissue is the chance for a new generation to see a modern classic on a cinema screen.
It is safe to say there will not be a dry eye in the house. The technology may change but the emotional tug of an all-American tearjerker is eternal.
It may stray into a few redundant subplots along the way but Everything Must Go succeeds as a plaintive portrait of a man cast adrift from all the past certainties of his life.
A little too neat and obvious for its own good but the sassy wit of the dialogue is fun and Findlay is a rising star.
A simple story told with abundant charm.
Treacle Jr is a little British gem that blossoms into an endearing salute to friendship and the power of positive thinking.
The plot never quite adds up and starts to drift aimlessly in the closing stages.
movie_title: As If I Am Not There (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A lyrical, slow-moving documentary on Japan's abiding fascination with insects.
A boisterous, bustling spectacle that attempts to balance the onslaught of special-effects wizardry with some welcome touches of humour and humanity.
The story of friendship and sacrifice is told in an unfussy, old-fashioned manner but director Christian Carion creates some tense moments and secures game performances...
There are enough jolts, jumps and bursts of gallows humour along the way to recommend it to fans of scary movies.
Never pulls all the elements into a convincing whole, despite solid performances from the eternally watchable Cox and rising star Kebbell.

There are echoes of classics like Hell In The Pacific in Tracker and the seesawing relationship between the two men is entertainingly handled, if repetitive, until some welcome 11th-hour twists in the plot.
If you don't expect a classic heartbreaker you'll enjoy this old-fashioned movie romance.
On this evidence, Jack Sparrow and his merry band can carry on sailing for a few years to come.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It sounds heavygoing but if anything Amreeka is a little too sweet and cosy for its own good.
Newcomer Clara Augarde proves to be a real find in Love Like Poison, a severe coming of age drama set in the Breton countryside.
All of this feels a little too pat and obvious until we edge towards a lump-in-the-throat finale with an emotional wallop absent from the predictability of the previous scenes.
The gruelling training, clandestine mission and sacrifice is familiar Boy's Own stuff but the lack of a decent budget really hurts the film.
First Class takes the X-Men story back to its roots and is just the kick in the pants the series needed. It is smart, spectacular, never cheesy, often thrilling and always incredibly entertaining.
A glossy melodrama that turns a gossip column premise into an earnest, well-acted rumination on modern relationships.
There are aspects of Senna's life that are left untouched here but that is a small reservation about such a dynamic and captivating documentary.
This Disney fare is so bland and unremarkable that you might be better off staying home and watching a repeat of Glee.
The scenes in which JoEllen meets her growing collection of half-sisters and half-brothers are among the most emotional in a sweet but slight documentary.
An entertaining and accessible overview of the 2008 meltdown.
Retirement can be a death sentence but in the eccentric, meandering French road movie Mammuth it becomes a second chance to reconnect with life.
Screwed may be based on the true-life experiences of former prison guard Ronnie Thompson but it seems to serve up every available clich√© from the handbook of tough nut British prison dramas.
Blurring fact and fantasy in a haunting evocation of the repression that marked the Franco era.
This puerile exercise in bad taste has all the appeal of a bratty child trying to shock the dinner table by uttering some mild profanity.
Foster's direction is on the timid side but Gibson's performance manages to make a weird situation feel real and unexpectedly touching.

Told with sly humour and eye-catching period detail, Potiche offers frothy fun underpinned by some astute observations about the dawn of feminism and the seismic changes in French society at this period.
Foster and an Oscar-nominated Harrelson effectively convey the outward steel and inner fragility of these men of war but the film is slow-moving and maudlin.
It is a film that tends to accentuate the positive but it still leaves a warm glow of sweet remembrance.
A cheesy, clunky B-movie blockbuster lacking the wit and wonder that you find in the best comicbook adaptations.
Absorbing throughout, Incendies has the feel of a Greek tragedy until a conclusion that stretches credibility to breaking point.
A frenzy of double-dealing action, sweaty sex and appalling violence that has some real moments of knife-edge tension.
The screenplay sticks to a tried and trusted formula which tends to lessen the emotional impact of an amazing true story.
Sweet, shamelessly cheesy and surprisingly wholesome.
A true cult classic.
movie_title: La Mort en direct (Death Watch) (Death in Full View) (1980)

movie_review_blurb: The true story of a lonely, underachieving young lad's special bond with a disabled dolphin seems guaranteed to make you teary-eyed.
Like a cheap, uninspired ITV bank holiday drama in which a decent cast is left stranded by a lousy script and lifeless direction.
A delicate little heartwarmer of a film.
A decent thriller with a notable performance from newcomer Dimitri Storoge as the young Momon.
A leisurely, elegiac production that needed a sharper focus.
A film with a documentary-like intensity and a sense of British reserve that makes it all the more moving.
A slow-moving and often implausible tale.
An unexpected charmer.
A fascinating account of a complex, charismatic man.
Attractive, picture postcard cinematography from Terry Stacey adds to the appeal of a film that is easy on the eye and pleasantly undemanding in every other respect.
Even with the bonus of Pearce's sardonic performance Lockout is still little more than a soulless, slapdash computer game.
A beautifully judged, small-scale human drama that lingers in the memory long after some of those rowdy, big-budget blockbusters have faded.
An interesting subject but a dull film.
One to avoid.
Maybe it will all seem better one bank holiday Monday on the telly.
The intricately woven tale of hide and seek is full of priceless, poker-faced comedy and heartrending tenderness.

Hansen-L√∏ve deftly captures all the emotions of a time when the shortest separation feels like an eternity and the slightest misunderstanding a calamity.
movie_title: Un amour de jeunesse (Goodbye First Love) (2012)

Juan of The Dead is rough and ready, the effects are a little shoddy, the comedy is broad and sometimes homophobic but there are just enough whimsical moments and deadpan hilarity to make it worthwhile.

A sprawling, messily ambitious epic of unrequited love and unfulfilled hearts that is lent an added poignancy by the casting of Mastroianni's mother Catherine Deneuve as the older Madeleine and by all the cinematic ghosts that accompany her appearance.
In this low-budget Irish tale Charlie Barnham (Emmett Scanlan) is a loathsome psychopath who regards the rest of humanity with sneering contempt.
A melancholy French musical that stretches across four decades and several continents.
A challenging, heartfelt but often confusing drama that seesaws between the Paris of 1969 and contemporary Montreal.

Leaves the impression that no matter how striking the aesthetic, Seidl is really not telling us anything we don't know already.
Obvious and heavy handed in pointing out the never changing struggles between the haves and have-nots but there are still some touching moments and strong performances to make it worthwhile...
The sheer injustice at the heart of an overlong tale still creates an automatic sympathy for the women, sisters in a way to the women in Made In Dagenham.

A heartwarming, social-realist fairytale with enough rowdy humour and sweet sentiment to appeal to Loach's dedicated global followers and beyond.
A straightforward film but one in which Brannaman's gift and modesty shine through.
A great score from David Byrne puts the icing on this unruly but beguiling production.
The film is ultimately about a spectacular fall from innocence that feels both highly personal and universal.
A powerful, poignant film.
Emmerich steps out of his comfort zone to offer a beguiling picture of Elizabethan London and a neatly balanced tale of political intrigue and personal heartache.
A meaty, enjoyable adult movie especially if you still miss a regular visit to The West Wing.
It makes for a poignant if shallow remembrance.
What a charmless embarrassment.

movie_review_blurb: Let's hope they can wrap everything up with a better film than this one.
Gandolfini's bashful, bear-like Doug is endearing but most of this earnest film just doesn't ring true.
Generally it is a great, swaggering, globe-trotting slice of entertainment to divert and delight on a stormy winter's night. Sometimes that is all you want from a trip to the cinema.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It is necessarily incomplete but still constructs a haunting portrait of a woman who deserved a better life and death.

Fresnadillo favours creepy suspense over gore resulting in a polished psychological drama.

Director Josh Trank is a talent to watch.
It isn't the smoothest transition but strong performances from Stephen Graham and Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje keep the idea afloat.
It is a heartfelt, heartwarmer of a film that lacks the pain and profundity that the subject matter really deserves.
A movie buff's delight.

movie_review_blurb: A frantic sequel that is tamer than the original but no more appealing.

An exhausting, politically incorrect romp that revisits every cliche of the hormonal teenage comedy.

It may not cut as deeply as you might have hoped but fashionistas will be fascinated.
Recommended if you are a dedicated follower of fashion.
A film of rosy optimism it features a beguiling performance from screen newcomer doret who achieves a wonderfully natural, touching chemistry with de France.
An uninspired, sub-Hitchcock effort.

Rather too much is going on to be comfortably accommodated in one film.

Will their mutual hatred melt away under African skies? Will there be lots of opportunities to sacrifice their dignity in search of lazy laughs? All guaranteed.

movie_title: Aatsinki: The Story Of Arctic Cowboys (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It makes for a great story but Pantani remains an elusive figure and the film is annoyingly inconclusive and evasive - more determined to cheer his achievements than explore the bigger picture of his rise and fall.
movie_title: Pantani: The Accidental Death Of A Cyclist (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Jimmy's Hall is covered in a misty-eyed nostalgia at times but it is also infused with a sense of melancholy and anger.
Funny in places but relentlessly crude.

Heavily reliant on the skills of his two actors to keep us engaged. Fortunately, the two actors are both on top form.
A tense, involving combination of love story and thriller.
Borgman remains an elegantly teasing puzzle even as you begin to suspect there could be slightly less here than meets the eye.

A messy, unwieldy affair.
A film to watch from behind shaking fingers, if at all.

An intriguing chamber work.

It has that tiny glimmer of everyday life beneath its tasteless antics and desire to offend.

A sentimental, visually stunning adaptation of the Reif Larsen novel.

movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

A joyous hurrah for a unique figure.

Painless family fun.

A mawkish tale of the beautiful game supposedly based on true events.

movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A particularly languid, slow-burning period drama.
Things soon go bump in the night, a broken clock chimes, a suspicious figure lurks in the woods etc.

Journeys from the sublime to the heartbreaking as it charts the giddy, intoxicating happiness of a couple in love.
A small-scale production but one that burns brightly.

Characteristically provocative in its subject matter and abundantly inventive in its visual ornamentation.

A measured, challenging historical drama but also one of Dumont's more accessible films.

A solid, entertaining tale of how a musical paradise was gained and lost.

It is all perfectly painless froth but there are moments that make your toes curl.

A charming French comedy with a plum role for Fabrice Luchini.
McCarthy co-wrote and produced Tammy so she only has herself to blame for such a predictable, pedestrian tale.

A mild, predictable little British drama.

A tale that has been scripted and expertly shaped by Linklater into a richly textured, completely winning human story.
A triumph that soars far beyond a lazy re-tread of the original. It is altogether darker, richer and more complex.
Are you ready for three hours of overkill?
A cheery charmer that brings a smile to the face.
The idiotic plot is exasperating and the ridiculous behaviour beggars belief. You just don't believe a word of it. The daft premise doesn't help.

A breezy, deadpan satire on our obsession with celebrity culture and the lengths some people will go to secure a fleeting moment in the limelight.

"Oh God, this is humiliating," trills Diane Keaton and she never said a truer word.
Blood doesn't always ring true but there is enough meat in the story and merit in the cast to make it worth watching.
Savour the archive footage, concert scenes and celebration of their devoted fans who appear like rats to the call of a Pied Piper at the first hint of a free warm-up concert in Warrington.
movie_title: The Stone Roses: Made of Stone (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It is an enjoyable, amusing and well-executed film even if it does feel awfully insubstantial and inconsequential.
It is a perfectly respectable if bloodless version of the Fran√ßois Mauriac novel that shocked readers in the Twenties.
A gem of a film that is certain to steal your heart.
movie_title: Hasta la Vista (Come as You Are) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The second feature from Katalin Varga director Peter Strickland is an idiosyncratic, impeccably crafted mindbender that shifts between the beguiling and the bemusing.
The result is overlong but still offers a clear-eyed engagement with a Kenya where love is a transaction and the heart remains a lonely hunter.
Gerwig keeps you on side and rooting for Frances to get her act together in what becomes an affectionate salute to messy lives, an endearing underachiever and a New York state of mind.
A film that pays tribute to a complex personality, a genuinely talented entertainer and a very different age from today.
It is a straightforward and understated documentary of personal tragedy with a lesson for us all on how precious and fleeting life can be.
Poorly acted and unintentionally funny this is definitely a bad day at black rock.
It is a great story, deftly told and a wonderful testament to what an inspirational figure Billie Jean King has been.
The bright, warm sunlight of the Cte d'Azur casts a golden glow over a film set in the summer of 1915.
Has more to offer than your average US thriller.
Think what they might have achieved with better material.
An elegant, stunningly photographed reflection on the human condition that is as odd as it is entrancing.
It is at once amusing, intriguing and mystifying and I think you will be glad that the running time is brief.
[It] just leaves some decent shots of rising swells, breaking waves and daredevil surfers to hold the attention for two hours.
This fizzy romantic comedy is slight but charming and perks up considerably when Allen himself makes an appearance.
A beautifully photographed and elegantly handled existential drama.
This engaging and thought-provoking portrait captures a sense of the farm over the seasons and salutes Hook as a hero of food production.
A leisurely and engaging testimony to the courage and tenacity of a generation.
Maybe a Hitchcock or Chabrol could have made something gripping from the melodrama and mystery of it all but this feels workmanlike and obvious.
A frustratingly inscrutable film that fails to engage.
The lacklustre script is so determined to spell out thoughts and emotions that it becomes insulting.
A haunting, beautifully acted tale of impossible dreams and lost hope.
It treats the characters with respect and a tender regard for an idealism that maturity seems unlikely to sustain.
The plotting is disjointed, the execution feels incoherent and none of it makes a great deal of sense.
The plotting and dialogue may not always be top drawer but director Eran Creevy carries it off with slick confidence.
A sensitive, unflinching exploration of bleak lives Shell marks the emergence of a distinctive new voice in British cinema and a striking young performer in Chloe Pirrie.
he pacing is sluggish and the sentimental story never surprises. I wasn't feeling the magic.
Amiable, lightweight fun.
A thought-provoking history lesson.
This Maniac may have artistic aspirations but it doesn't make the film any more palatable.
Despite the flaws, Flying Blind is a quietly intriguing little drama and a promising feature debut from shorts filmmaker Klimkiewicz.
A handsomely crafted film but one that already feels dated.
An uncomfortable, provocative little drama that really gets under the skin and will not be for all tastes.
Has echoes of Michael Haneke as it explores the guilty secrets and bitter resentments lurking beneath the calm, respectable surface of a community in affluent Recife.
Boorman brought a fresh eye to the LA locations in a film frequently remade but never equalled.
An Easter treat.
An amateurish, painfully unfunny misfire.
It may not be Bertolucci's most dynamic film but the quiet sense of hope that he finds makes it an unexpectedly poignant chamber work.
Kassovitz deftly negotiates the complexity of what happened but his sympathies clearly lie with the islanders in a politically-charged tale with an approach similar to the work of Costa-Gavras.
There is solid professionalism on display throughout Oblivion but just nothing to get very excited about.

Deepa Mehta's respectful approach to the material may meander and simplify, but it gradually gains in emotional power, building into a moving account of a man whose many experiences mirror the growing pains of an independent India.
Nothing is clear in a film that is as challenging as it is rewarding.
A poignant tale of lost souls from a golden age of US cinema.
An old-fashioned but satisfying drama.
Animal lovers will be particularly offended by some tales in this mind-numbing marathon.
There is just too much going on, with some interesting characters edged out of the limelight ...
Without resorting to graphic violence or melodrama A Hijacking builds into an extremely tense tale with all the nail-biting immediacy of an unfolding news story.
Tense, slow-burning and handled with impeccable discretion Our Children offers a piercing and compassionate glimpse into the unthinkable.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Journey to Italy (Viaggio in Italia) (Strangers) (The Lonely Woman) (1954)

movie_review_blurb: Franco attempts to capture and match Faulkner's stream of consciousness prose with split-screen imagery, interior monologues and slow motion to create a film that might seem more at home as an art museum installation than a mainstream cinema release.
The first feature in almost quarter of a century from the veteran director of El Topo and Santa Sangre is a surprisingly witty, accessible magical mystery tour through his past.
All the talent in the world can't elevate this forgettable fare.
A quietly inspirational, beautifully made drama that also seems to reflect some of the Icelandic character and a whole nation's ability to survive testing times.
A complex father/son relationship is viewed through a raw depiction of prison life in the riveting Starred Up.
A wonderfully atmospheric, deeply romantic film.
If you enjoyed Monsters, Inc 12 years ago then you're not going to be disappointed even if it does feel a little slight at times.
It's a well-made and entertaining conspiracy thriller but remains a disappointingly superficial treatment of material that promised much more.
Easily the best film adaptation of an Irvine Welsh novel since Trainspotting, it features a terrific central performance from James McAvoy as Bruce Robertson.
There are few surprises in this clich√©-ridden plucky effort that may have been better as a TV production.
The influence of Ken Loach makes way for the dynamics of a Quentin Tarantino-style heist. The result is an expertly crafted heartbreaker that cuts to the core of desperate lives.
The film grows increasingly demented and grotesque but beneath the desire to offend lurks an old-fashioned morality tale.
Gillen conveys the anger and anguish of his character but this is a painfully slow piece that keeps the viewer at arm's length.
A thoughtful perspective on attitudes to homosexuality in the church and Polish society and Chyra's strong performance make this a poignant drama.
Based on the prizewinning novel by Meg Rosoff, How I Live Now is impeccably crafted with some beautiful cinematography from Franz Lustig and tender direction from Kevin Macdonald.
It is a compelling human story in which you grow to admire Helen's refusal to surrender her dream no matter how crushing the reality of their circumstances.
movie_title: Folie √† Deux - madness made of two (2012)

movie_review_blurb: MacKay draws us into the guilt and anguish of a troubled mind and director Paul Wright has a lyrical touch but this is a grim ordeal of a film.
The Unbeatables is good fun for young and old alike, delivering its moral lessons and criticism of the beautiful game with a light touch. It is typical summer family fare, but with more of a kick.
The end result still lacks a coherent sense of what the film is trying to achieve.

Alfonso Cuar√≥n makes it look effortless in Gravity, sculpting exemplary sound design, breathtaking images and 3D technology into a film that plunges the viewer straight to the heart of a sweat-inducing, pulse-racing nightmare scenario.
All of the cast can hold a tune and director Dexter Fletcher stages showstopping numbers with aplomb.

It doesn't provide blinding new insight into Monroe's life but it is filled with less familiar newsreel footage and decent movie clips and has some brief, invaluable glimpses of a troubled inner life.
Decent and perfectly respectable but lacks the soaring, swooning fireworks of Baz Luhrmann's swashbuckling approach or even the intensity of the admired Sixties version by Franco Zeffirelli.
The mind boggles, the stomach turns and the heart sinks. You have been warned.
There is a sense of intimacy and a warm humanity shining in all his work and this is an eloquent, moving tribute ...
movie_title: Which Way Is the Front Line from Here? The Life and Times of Tim Hetherington (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Sincere, whimsical and pretty dreary.
movie_title: Nugu-ui ttal-do anin Haewon (Nobody's Daughter Hae-Won) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Im Sangsoo seems too much in love with what he seeks to condemn for The Taste Of Money to have real bite.
A gentle, plaintive character study elevated by a glowing central performance.
Dedicated film buffs will love it.
The sarcastic banter and male chemistry between Treadaway, an outstanding Iwan Rheon, Gerard Kearns and Matthew Lewis provide as much pleasure as the mechanics of the twisted revenge plot.
The three main child actors, including Emma Watson as Hermione, have gained in confidence and grown nicely into their roles and all of the regular ensemble from the first film return.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: This darkly attractive film has a painterly quality to its visual look and some impressively elaborate animatronic effects that will delight genre fans.
The special effects may have moved on over the past 40 years but virtually every other aspect of the film is inferior to its predecessor.
Disturbing, edge-of-the-seat fare that is not for the fainthearted.

As the rituals of Christmas are observed, the family edges closer towards a sense of understanding and acceptance in a picture that captures a sense of life's messy uncertainties and the way we sometimes hurt the ones we love the most.
movie_title: Un Conte de No√´l (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Like Father, Like Son uses a well-worn plot device as a springboard to explore the meaning of family and fatherhood in an age and a society where guilty parents struggle to achieve a healthy life/work balance.
The F Word offers a sweetly engaging 21st century variation on When Harry Met Sally, milking laughter and tears from the eternal dilemma of whether men and women can ever be just friends.
This is a considered, unsentimental attempt to understand the filmmaker's seemingly inexplicable entanglement with a convicted con man.
