The frantic plot and shrill comic relief make for a disappointing dud.
movie_title: Justin and the Knights of Valour (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The novelty value alone is enough to make it of interest but even more noteworthy is the fact that this is such a charming and winning tale.
The result is a quietly inspirational, beautifully made drama that also seems to reflect some of the Icelandic character and a whole nation's ability to survive testing times.
A well-spun yarn ...
Harrowing true events are dramatised with surprising restraint in the low-key Eden.
As welcome as a cooling gelato on a hot summer's day.
A heist thriller with a distinctly British sensibility, Wasteland marks an assured and engaging first feature from writer/director Rowan Athale.
The depth of focus, framing of characters and objects and use of the claustrophobic sets add extra pleasure to what was already a thoroughly enjoyable "perfect crime" nail-biter.
Gil is a serene and compassionate figure although the film only offers sketchy information on his life and career.
There are characters who help to connect the stories and provide a straight line through a very twisted narrative. In its best moments this is an exciting, involving multi-story thriller.
A languid slow-burner that builds into a bleak portrait of a troubled teen.
The story is routine and the animation rarely inspired, which makes it feel as if nobody cared enough to make the film soar.
It's all complete nonsense, entirely predictable and feels like it is going to last for ever.
Even fans of the original are likely to feel deeply disappointed.
Kuma grows increasingly compelling as the complexity of the relationships become more apparent and we learn what is at stake for everyone.
Give me a nice Audrey Hepburn film any day.

Pieta is the kind of film that sends sensitive audiences rushing towards the exit and yet for those who remain to the bitter end there is method in all of this savagery, purpose visible through the grey clouds of unrelenting bleakness.
Cumming's witty, golden-hearted Rudy is just one of the delights in a real heartbreaker of a film.
It lingers in the imagination long after more disciplined, well-behaved films have faded.
Once the film takes to the race track nothing matters except the roar of the engines and the bloody-minded determination of two very different but equally charismatic individuals.
There is a righteous anger behind Any Day Now that rubs away sentimentality and a witty, heartfelt Cumming impresses as a man driven to ensure his voice is heard and his love matters.
Lowery focuses on melancholy moods, inner turmoil and the golden glow of cornfields to create an earnest, leisurely tale of lost souls and last chances.
There is a lot to be learned from this thoughtful film as you marvel at the amazingly intimate images of colony life.
Why would anyone want to watch such trash?
The Double does offer some dark amusement along the way but is more likely to baffle than beguile.
A wry ensemble comedy that takes a generous view of the failings and foibles of its characters.
A tart, likable comedy that must have been pitched as "Spellbound meets Bad Santa".
The tone of the film may be a little too cartoonish and whimsical for its own good but this is still a winning, odd-couple heartwarmer.
Beautifully shot in black and white The Artist And The Model offers a mature, touching reflection on the eternal bonds between art and life.
movie_title: El artista y la modelo (The Artist and the Model) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A tense tale of dishonour among thieves this is as hard-boiled and flinty as anything Hollywood was making at the time.
A blockbuster that redefines the term overkill.
Fast Five maintains the winning formula and underlines the sad fact that stars Vin Diesel and Paul Walker still have nothing better to do.
Strawberry & Chocolate (Fresa y Chocolate) has a special place in cinema history.
Everyone concerned must have realised that they were on the proverbial hiding to nothing.
An important docu-drama with all the tension and immediacy of a political thriller.
movie_title: Burma VJ: Reporter i et Lukket Land (Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The unknown child actors are appealing but Kisses tries too hard to pluck at the heartstrings.

It is contrived and predictable, squandering the chemistry between co-stars Sandra Bullock and Ryan Reynolds as it creates lazy escapist entertainment that is forgotten as soon as the end credits have rolled.
A garbled, appallingly misogynistic fantasy that makes little sense and plays like torture porn cloaked in artistic pretensions.
An undisciplined, overlong tale that substitutes spectacle and star cameos (Twiggy, Steven Spielberg, etc) for a coherent narrative.
The presentation is pedestrian, the tone is overly reverent and the viewer might find their time better spent reading a Dickens classic.
You are swept along by the confidence of the storytelling even as you accept it might not hold up to close scrutiny.
movie_title: K√¶rlighed p√• Film (Just Another Love Story) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Sergio Leone's masterpiece.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the West (1968)

movie_review_blurb: An absorbing, worthwhile drama.
Writer/director Anne Fontaine has created a conventional film from the early years of Coco but one that delivers all the elegant virtues of a satisfying costume drama.
Some stories are more convincing than others in this sprawling blend of thriller, melodrama and social drama.
The action scenes are much more impressive than the predictable plot.

This big-budget revamp of the Seventies TV series flounders around with little consistency of tone, courting kids with roaring dinosaurs and visual gags, then winking at adults with near‚Äëthe‚Äëknuckle asides.
The film has a slick surface sheen and evocative soundtrack (Simple Minds, A Flock Of Seagulls, etc) but those are just incidental pleasures in a languid condemnation of soulless excess.
Despite moments of poignancy you are left wondering why this contrived affair has strayed into the cinema.
Cassel surely deserves Oscar and Bafta consideration for a level of acting that dominates every frame of an exceptional thriller that easily surpasses any recent American efforts in this genre.
movie_title: Mesrine: Part 1 (Killer Instinct) and Part 2 (Public Enemy #1) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: You wonder how the actors kept straight faces making this shameless codswallop.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Some viewers may find it all unbearably sentimental but the film deserves praise for an unexpected ending that doesn't launch an all-out assault on the tear ducts.
After a slow-burning start Orphan degenerates into an increasingly grisly, far-fetched affair with a jaw-dropping twist that has you chortling with disbelief.
An enigmatic and intriguing little tale with a flavour of the paranoia once found in the Roman Polanski classic Repulsion.
A film that is entertaining, informative and filled with irresistibly cute critters.
The film version of the novel will drive you potty if you try to make any sense of it. Just surrender to a far-fetched fantasy and the reward is a lush, high-gloss weepie.
Surprisingly tolerable teen fare with hints of the wit and warmth that the late John Hughes once brought to the genre.
Well-acted by an attractive cast, A Perfect Getaway is far from perfect but it knows its limitations and serves up a thrill ride laced with humour and guaranteed to get the heart racing.
It is a gentle wisp of a charmer that never overstays its warm welcome.
Sickly slush that is intermittently enlivened by Thomas Haden Church as Evan's goofy business rival.
There is the feel of a Sam Peckinpah western to a grimly predictable story that blends beautiful scenery with brutal reality.

Landa is a man you will love to hate. His performance is a credible candidate for a Best Supporting Actor Oscar. He is the best thing in this patchy, overlong but ridiculously enjoyable return to form for the bad boy of American cinema.
Some of the elaborate routines of escalating chaos raise a sympathetic smile but mostly Rumba feels like being forced to watch a mime artist for an hour and quarter.

This feels like a story destined to end in tragedy but although there are plenty of opportunities to transform this into a heartbreaker, writer/director Courtney Hunt allows the audience a ray of hope.
Intelligent, resourceful and elegantly made, Moon marks a mightily impressive low-budget debut from director Duncan Jones.
This is storytelling at its most spellbinding - streets ahead of the rival summer blockbusters.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Looking For Eric is a British film that lifts the spirits and might even bring a tear to the eye. Loach has scored a winner.
The cast is personable, the photography is attractive, the script is cleverly constructed and mildly amusing but there is nothing here that screams comedy classic.
A grotesque misogynistic romp, Doghouse is too laddish and corny to even hold a candle to the witty Shaun Of The Dead. Perhaps Lesbian Vampire Killers wasn't so bad after all.
Energetic direction and a promising central performance counteract the modest budget and some less-than-convincing plot elements.
After watching this you may think twice before consuming another mouthful of tuna.
A grimly effective new version of the notorious Last House On The Left.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Director Michael Bay has always had a passion for big, noisy spectacles and Revenge Of The Fallen is a bravura display of his ability to mastermind global destruction. What it lacks is the human touch, decent dialogue, novelty and restraint.
The film lurches uncertainly in tone from frisky nostalgia to fatalistic drama without really getting under the skin of one of the forgotten pioneers of British pop.
A likable cast brings some charm and humour to Gigantic but it remains an overly mannered, self-conscious effort.
Beyond the Fire is a well-intentioned but plodding attempt to address the trauma of sexual abuse.
Johnny Kevorkian makes a promising debut with The Disappeared, a slow-burning tale of the supernatural that makes effective use of some atmospheric London locations and a well cast Harry Treadaway.

The velvety villainy of James Mason, the crop duster chase and the thrilling finale scrambling around Mount Rushmore are just part of the pleasure in a classic that deserves to be seen on the big screen.
It isn't as fresh or as funny as the earlier Ice Age animated features but then it doesn't embarrass its predecessors either.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Public Enemies is an efficient, well-made period thriller the impact of which is dulled by our familiarity with the subject and knowledge of the outcome.
Red Mist is a lazy, incoherent shocker with nothing to recommend it.
An affectionate and thoughtful portrait of an artist.
movie_title: Am I Black Enough for You? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A daft mixture of the lurid and the ludicrous.
movie_title: Encarna√ß√£o do Dem√¥nio (Devil's Reincarnation) (Embodiment of Evil) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: My Sister's Keeper ducks some of the bigger moral dilemmas, which may have added more grit. There again this is not a film with grit on its mind, just how quickly it can have you reaching for a handkerchief.
The jokes are obvious and tend towards the scatological. The rambling dialogue also makes this an endurance test. Year One, Audience Enjoyment Nil.
Sunshine Cleaning is a winning combination of heartbreak and quirky humour.
Fame and fortune are not what they had anticipated in this well-acted fable that requires you to suspend disbelief not least because both brothers seem to be too old to be budding football stars.
The action sequences are the prize attraction and even they leave something to be desired.

There are a lot of big, cruel laughs in this but it was a lot easier to warm to the innocent Borat than the self-absorbed Br√ºno and the film begins to overstay its welcome even at a trim 80-odd minutes.

This film is the work of a cinematic master. Writer/director Claire Denis handles the ebb and flow of everyday human existence with such tenderness and truth that her film feels like a great warm hug.

Fired Up will never win any prizes for wit or originality. The jokes are obvious, the plot is predictable and the whole formulaic film feels like a gentler throwback to racy Eighties teen comedies like Porky's.

A midlife crisis unfolds with all the hushed reverence of a visit to an art gallery in The Private Lives Of Pippa Lee, a wry, engaging ensemble piece that feels like a throwback to Seventies films such as A Woman Under The Influence.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An unexpectedly gripping melodrama that draws you into the heart of a situation where no one emerges unscathed.
You probably couldn't stand an entire evening of Zehnder's music but the film offers a charming insight into a little known segment of world music.
Flavourful behind the scenes footage mingles with infectious concert performances to make this a very welcome record of a unique piece of music history.
Fart jokes and fat gags are top of the agenda in this flat-footed parody.

The script is leaden but the action speaks volumes as Woo delivers an efficient spectacle of naval battles, slow-motion combat, death-defying stunt work, daredevil espionage, noble deeds, self-sacrifice and more plotting than a Labour Cabinet meeting.

Reminiscent of the alienation in classic Antonioni films or the paranoia of Michael Haneke, the icy Afterschool is a little too self-conscious in its artiness. Alternating between the fascinating and the tedious, it still worms its way under you skin.
The mixture of obvious jokes and winsome sentiment pretty much robs the film of any guilty pleasure value it might have provided.
Charming and idiosyncratic, The Beaches Of Agn√®s has a strong emotional pull for anyone familiar with Varda's career as a film-maker, photographer, artist and committed feminist.
movie_title: Les Plages d'Agn√®s (The Beaches of Agnes) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The expertly choreographed and often preposterous fight sequences are reminiscent of Jackie Chan in his glory days and are the saving grace of an otherwise crude thriller.
Steeped in a bleak atmosphere and beautifully made, Vinyan journeys from the credible to the pretentious as the tension mounts and the horror grows increasingly extreme.
This laboured romantic comedy has little to recommend it beyond the picture-postcard locations.

Up has wit and warmth, wonderful storytelling, winning characterisations and a palette of bright and beautiful colours. If ever an animated production was a serious contender for a Best Picture Oscar, then this is the one.
A quietly affecting, acutely observed little gem of a drama.
Fast-paced, gory and often amusing in a cartoon manner.
A glossy, meandering wallow of a film with personable stars and predictable storylines. Blandly forgettable even with Aniston at her most winsome.
A worthwhile documentary.
An impressive debut from expat British director Peter Strickland with a powerful central performance from Hilda P√©ter.
Largely improvised and inevitably a little rambling and loosely structured but there are some genuinely funny moments along the way.
It has the same understanding of male emotions as a Nick Hornby bestseller and could be that rare warmhearted weepie with an appeal that spans the genders and generations.
A rambling, unruly salute to the transformative power of the imagination that is filled with visual inventiveness, wilful eccentricity and even a burst or two of Pythonesque humour.

The film is a little sluggish in its pacing but solidly handled and doesn't pull its punches in depicting a France where some of the population were only too willing to accept their fate as a conquered nation.

In its best moments the film offers an entertaining throwback to the Seventies heyday of John Carpenter and David Cronenberg, when a creepy situation could be just as effective as a burst of stomach-churning special effects.
Gruesome, disturbing, definitely over-long but strangely moving, Thirst brings vivid new ideas to an overworked genre.
So many questions and not many answers as this proves to be a film stronger on suspense than satisfaction. Ultimately it doesn't make a whole lot of sense but it is fairly intriguing while it lasts.
Never mind the quality, just savour the adrenaline rush.
Imbued with a dry humour and some daft action moments it feels like a relic of the psychedelic Sixties that has been rediscovered.
The Vampire's Assistant is entertaining but awfully uneven with serious flaws in pace and plotting and a tone that veers between ghoulish comedy and gothic fantasy.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Coffin Rock is not without potential but never catches fire. We don't care about any of the characters, Parsonson's hammy histrionics often make his character laughable rather than terrifying and the violence grows increasingly vile.
An involving and persuasive film that remains frustratingly one-sided as it bandies about unsubstantiated accusations, fails to follow up on key issues and leaves you wanting to know much more.
It is an imaginative scenario but you will still need a strong stomach and a real enthusiasm for zombie films to appreciate this effort.
A brutal, blood-soaked film that feels like a primal scream.
It sounds a passable premise but what we get is a toe-curling disappointment that wastes the talent of some familiar television faces. No sale.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: In An Education a star is born. Carey Mulligan is simply beguiling. She has the wit and intelligence of a young Emma Thompson, the dazzle of Julie Christie, the fairytale enchantment of Audrey Hepburn.

Strip away the weirdness, the accusations and the lurid headlines and what remains is a poignant portrait of an entertainer, singer and showman working his socks off to create the best possible concert. No fan could want a better legacy.

Comical and endearing, Tales From The Golden Age lacks real bite or satirical sting but it does underline the Orwellian nightmare of a regime in which the party line must be obeyed regardless of logic, common sense or personal safety.
Fewer laughs than the average episode of ITV's Benidorm.
Pandorum doesn't make a whole lot of sense and is shot and edited in a way that only adds to the confusion. In space nobody can hear you scratching your head.
A premise worthy of a vintage screwball farce is developed into a breezy, crowd-pleasing comedy in The Invention Of Lying.
A film of ravishing images and fascinating facts although David Attenborough's BBC work is just as impressive.
A chaotic, hyperactive, sugar-rush of a film with special effects that appear quaintly hand-knitted and low-tech.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: [Pacino's] grandstanding performance is still hard to resist and symbolises the baroque excess of this shockingly violent gangster classic.
One of the most challenging and visually accomplished films of Almod√≥var's long career.
Business as usual courtesy of ever-more outlandish ways for people to die.
Funny People is genuinely funny at times, predictably foul-mouthed, touching and surprisingly frank in its approach to death, love and loyalty.
A film that offers an intense personal perspective on the reality of an adrenaline-rush existence lived in the full knowledge that every day could be your last.
A graphic and extremely disturbing exploration of lust and love that deserves its reputation as a classic of world cinema.
movie_title: In the Realm of the Senses (1976)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately the initially intriguing story eventually grows confusing and unconvincing as Welsford reveals some head-scratching twists in a clumsy journey through obsession, paranoia and betrayal.
Mesrine: Killer Instinct is an exceptional French thriller but the companion film Mesrine: Public Enemy No 1 is even better. The pace is just as dynamic, the performances are equally impressive.
Fuelled by nostalgic anecdotes rather than insightful comment, the film really comes alive in the superb archive footage.
We never truly understand what goes on in his mind but all the hazards and heartbreak of his epic swim make for fascinating viewing.
All the elements are familiar but Blomkamp's swaggering, guerrilla-style approach transforms them into a zestful slice of cartoonish mayhem.
A romantic weepie that tugs at the heart strings... In our more cynical age it just feels incredibly corny and obvious although the final 20 minutes amidst the mud and carnage are well-staged.
The aerial dogfights are the best thing in the film but any time it returns to earth it does so with a bump amidst turgid drama and leaden dialogue.
Sorority Row proves to be just another crass slasher movie, recycling familiar ingredients to diminishing effect.
A tasty little confection inspired by two true stories.
A stunning, semi-autobiographical tour de force from writer/director/producer/performer Xavier Dolan, it is a film with the sting of shrewdly observed truth.
Away We Go is not Mendes's best film but it's not as unbearable as you might have heard.
Writer/directors Christopher Miller and Phil Lord have fashioned a state of the art kids' movie primed with old-fashioned values.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An uneven mixture of crude high jinks and sweet romance, this just about makes the grade thanks to its breezy geniality and Pine's charismatic performance as Danny.

An intriguing two-hander that grows less persuasive as events unfold. There are hints of Pinter and signs of Mamet but nothing quite disguises the theatricality of the piece despite some sturdy acting.
This sharp-eyed documentary captures every aspect of the No Mind experience from the sublime to the utterly ridiculous.
The devastating effects of European colonialism are confronted head on in this thoughtful, crusading film.
movie_title: BirdWatchers - La terra degli uomini rossi (2008)

movie_review_blurb: We seem to be witnessing the prime of Kristin Scott Thomas as French cinema offers her some of the most demanding roles of her career.
There is nothing revolutionary about Creation but it tells an absorbing true story and finds a human perspective to some extraordinary historical events.
Zahn is adorable and Jennifer Aniston brings an endearing tartness to Sue but even their best efforts don't redeem the muddle of Management.

The world has hardly been breathlessly awaiting a new version of Fame and an older generation will probably find it uncomfortably corny with showbusiness schmaltz smoothing away the rougher edges of the more adult original.
Surrogates favours action-packed, empty-headed spectacle over credible, coherent plot and the brief running time leaves you wondering what they left on the cutting room floor.
Heavy-handed, Born In 68 struggles to hold your attention despite some engaging moments along the way.
The film has little new to offer but Ozg√ºr Yildirim directs with assurance.
An imaginative fantasy set in a future world that appears to have come straight from a Terminator film.
If you can just savour the spectacle and not worry about the tangled plot then it is a more than acceptable summer blockbuster.
Restrained, worthy and dull.
A handsome, old-fashioned melodrama that is entertaining enough but it merely skims the surface of the period.
An existential-heist thriller with moments of dark comedy, JCVD is decidedly different and has its moments but you probably have to be a diehard fan to really cherish it.
The wonderfully expressive features on Bolt make him feel almost real and the movie has enough charm and humour to please both adults and children.
The Curious Case Of Benjamin Button is not just a technical marvel, it is an epic piece of storytelling with an incredible attention to detail.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A clutch of fine performances helps to silence any reservations you might have about the screen version of Doubt.
Filled with shoot-outs, knife fights, amazing stuntwork and striking colours, this breathless yarn feels completely bonkers at times.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Somehow love conquers all in this lengthy but engaging ensemble piece.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Routine special effects merely add to the impression that this is a second division fantasy.
Allen's last couple of movies have been far from vintage offerings but Vicky Cristina Barcelona is pure pleasure and finds him back on form. It is smart, sunny, frisky and extremely funny.
One for horror fans that everyone else can happily avoid.
Anodyne family fare, Hotel is awash with all-American sentimentality but the many cute canines might just make it bearable for younger viewers.
It isn't the most subtle movie, with characters constantly spelling out the big message - in order to change the world, you first have to change yourself.

There is something depressingly old hat about the slapstick in The Pink Panther 2, a movie whose target audience appears to be tiny tots and those with a high tolerance for jokes about people falling over.
An extremely stylish, emotionally aloof film that lacks a strong enough story to create a great horror yarn.
Sacha Gervasi's endearing film has a real affection for the band's indomitable spirit which saves this from being another Spinal Tap and lends it some real heart.

The saving graces are a commanding performance from Del Toro and the inspirational humanity of Guevara; even facing defeat and death he still has an unshakable belief that right will prevail and social justice will flourish.
The irrepressible Fisher sails through all the slapstick and shrillness and remains very likeable but the manic Confessions Of A Shopaholic does her no favours.

Gran Torino is a vastly entertaining star vehicle that manages to reconcile the vigilante ethos of Eastwood's early hits with the more humane values that have been such an appealing facet of his later career.
Director Paul McGuigan serves this up with a flashy swagger but there is no disguising the fact that it is an incomprehensible mess.

It is a talky film that avoids happy endings and easy solutions. Instead, it grips with a tale that feels remarkably true to life and leaves you with an even greater appreciation of the people seeking to inspire future generations.
If ambition and flair were the only hallmarks of a five-star film then Franklyn would be top of the class.
The International is far from being a Bourne or a Bond but it does pass muster for a Saturday night at the movies. Just.
Predictable and uninspired, it is one more example of the dumb comedies that Hollywood is churning out at an alarming rate.
This may dabble in Jewish mysticism and the legacy of the Nazi era but scratch the surface and you discover just another standard scary movie.
Although elements of the movie appear stage managed it is still a very watchable document of everyday lives.
This is a sprawling but thoroughly absorbing saga that reminds you of the classic French resistance drama Army In The Shadows.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Lurching between crude comedy and self-conscious excess, Surveillance is just weird enough to keep your attention.
Zack Snyder's Watchmen is the Godzilla of the genre, laying waste to any remaining misconceptions.
The rich soundtrack is one of the highlights of this solid, unfamiliar story in which most of the actors do all their own singing.
Although Nick & Norah is episodic and uneven, it does have considerable charm.
The ending is unexpectedly sentimental and comforting, the pace is slow and contemplative but there is enough humour and humanity to keep you watching as it drifts by.
Sam Mendes has created an intelligent, thoroughly engrossing, beautifully acted adaptation of a classic novel that depicts the tragic underside of America's sunniest decade.
A twisty slice of pulp fiction bigger on atmosphere than credibility.
A haunting account of outcasts forging their own definition of home on the very margins of mainstream society.
Michael Winterbottom has become a master at relating dramatic true stories in a documentary style.
Told with a spare style and a tart wit, it records sprawling events with a claustrophobic sense of intimacy.
A quietly impressive first feature from novelist and documentary maker Lucia Puenzo.
There is a positively chilling performance from Javier Bardem as an embodiment of human evil to match Dennis Hopper's memorable turn in Blue Velvet.
A love story that also serves as a reflection on identity, blind faith and individuality.
Marks a return to form after the self-indulgent tomfoolery of its globe-hopping predecessor, even if the revenge heist scenario now feels very tired.
A self-effacing figure, Philibert never imposes himself on the film, preferring to stress the communal experience of its creation and the very human stories that have emerged from his return journey.
Morrison's book is painfully honest and whilst the film is sensitively handled and impeccably crafted it is also curiously distant and unmoving.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An uneven but ultimately impassioned recreation of the riots at the 1999 World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle.
It is an immensely likable, big-hearted romantic comedy that has a wide-ranging appeal as unpretentious feel-good escapism and a perfect date movie choice.
So corny and old-fashioned that only diehard romantics are likely to consider it magical.
Overly familiar material is handled with enough skill and conviction by Indian director Santosh Sivan to create a quietly compelling drama.
An unusually soulful and appealing romantic comedy.
The world can rest easy -- the old magic still works in Indiana Jones And The Kingdom Of The Crystal Skull.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This is very much a film of ideas.
Richard Eyre is fast becoming the new master of unhealthy obsession.
It is as if the spirit of recent Zhang Yimou spectaculars have informed this warm and very likable Hollywood fare.
A slick, cat-and-mouse thriller that unfolds with sharply-diminishing plausibility.
A highly entertaining and extremely accessible film.
Visually accomplished but dramatically mundane.
The champagne wit of Noel Coward's eighty year old play still fizzes and sparkles in Stephan Elliott's jaunty adaptation of Easy Virtue.
Turner Prize-winning artist Steve McQueen makes an impressive feature debut.
Jumper is almost in too much of a hurry at times and logic and cohesion suffer as a consequence.
An old-fashioned, unashamed heartwarmer more likely to prove a crowd- pleaser than a critical favourite.
A globe-trotting con game adventure that has a degree of charm but also displays the exasperating indulgence of an ambitious auteur project that may have been more fun to film than it is to watch.
A gruelling, grimly effective British chiller.
Kaufman directs this sprawl of ideas, twisted chronologies and bitter regrets with a tightly disciplined control of the material.
It is only marginally more absorbing than watching paint dry.
If you have no idea who these bland Disney charmers are or why they appear to be so popular, then this perfunctory concert film is unlikely to leave you any the wiser.
The Young Victoria feels like a breath of fresh air. It is a charming costume drama that peeks behind the pomp and pageantry to capture the human side of Britain's longest-reigning sovereign.
An earnest Cage lends some gravitas to a film of amazing coincidences and less than amazing special effects that sci-fi fans will embrace until something better comes along.
Romance may be alive and well but the charming, well-made romantic comedy continues to look like an endangered species thanks to Ghosts Of Girlfriends Past.

Star Trek is everything that fans could have hoped for. It throbs with a dynamism that we haven't seen in the series for a very long time and creates a slice of expertly crafted science-fiction escapism.
A virtuoso piece of storytelling with amazing attention to detail.

Intrusive narration from Frears doesn't help and the fact that Cheri is such a drip makes the all-consuming nature of the romance hard to swallow. The film just can't match the elegance and wit that come so effortlessly to Pfeiffer.
It does boast a lavish recreation of the period, fabulous costumes, the rugged beauty of some prime European locations and enough torrid emotions to make for a captivating period piece.
O' Horten is a slow-burner - as gentle as a falling snow flake but filled with dry humour, warm smiles and melancholy reflections on the human condition. It leaves a lovely afterglow.

is the humanity of the youngsters and the hopes of their families that win your heart rather than Johnson's attempts to say anything meaningful about Eurovision's contribution to peace between nations in modern Europe. Good fun.
Their awkward struggle to overcome shyness and take a chance on love becomes the basis of a gently life-affirming tale of loneliness and longing.

Andrea Arnold confidently navigates the pitfalls of the 'difficult' second feature with Fish Tank, which confirms her status as a torchbearer for the social realist traditions of Ken Loach and the Dardenne brothers.

The film will not win any Oscars but then nobody is tipping Dan Brown to win the Man Booker Prize any time soon. If the book belongs to the beach and the airport then the film deserves a big bucket of popcorn on a carefree Saturday night.
Fighting isn't a dreadful film, just one where it's best not to expect any great surprises.
Cantona provides a few bright moments in French Film, a damp squib of a romantic comedy with little in the way of wit, flair or sparkle.
This is an arch, knowing exercise in cinematic parody where every line of dialogue seems to come with inverted commas. Stretched over two hours it becomes unbearable.
Completely predictable, sickeningly sentimental and definitely limited in its appeal to diehard fans only.
It is Campion's most fully realised, satisfying achievement in a long while and will be warmly embraced as a prestige item with awards potential.
Tsar is likely to remain merely an intriguing but far from satisfying footnote to the Eisenstein classic Ivan The Terrible.
Compared with the wit and humour of any Pixar movie or Aardman feature this is shoddy stuff.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A meagre budget and a lack of clear-cut character motivations blunts the impact of what might have been a powerful Mean Streets-style study of male friendship.
This film has enough quirky charm, quiet humour and shining humanity to be well worth a look.
Told with delicacy and feeling Everlasting Moments slowly builds into a memorable salute to a remarkable life.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga √∂gonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The relationships are never completely convincing and there are too many unresolved questions to create an entirely satisfying tale.
movie_title: La Fille Coup√©e en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Director Safy Nebbou retains a tight control of pace and mood as nerves are strained and the truth becomes apparent.
movie_title: L'Empreinte de l'ange (Mark of an Angel) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: To anyone not sympathetic to Gilliam's flights of fantasy, Parnassus will reek of rambling self-indulgence but fans will welcome it as a return to what he does best.
Dennis Lee's sentimental drama is full of big stars and good intentions but still winds up feeling no better than a tear-jerking television soap opera.
Drag Me To Hell is surprisingly conventional fare that feels like an old Twilight Zone episode buffed up with lashings of bad taste for a new generation.
Obsessed is a particularly silly example of the [bunny boiler] genre with little rhyme or reason to the story and direction that is singularly lacking in subtlety.
Yet another American thriller with little to engage the brain.
An ingenious and thoroughly entertaining Spanish thriller.
Enjoyable in places and merely humdrum in others, Taking Woodstock ultimately feels like a minor Ang Lee digression in between more memorable works.
The film unfolds with such a fine balance of charm, humour and heartache that it is impossible to resist.
It's not a bad film and is an improvement on X-Men: The Last Stand but it also feels like every other comic-book adaptation we've ever seen and that is a major drawback.
An ambitious, wildly uneven venture beautifully photographed by Adam Levins.
The Damned United is really a tale of male camaraderie, sporting rivalry and the flawed nature of a man who many consider the greatest manager that England never had.
There is a vague sense of unease in the air but this remains a tedious movie in which everything remains unspoken, underdeveloped and annoyingly inconclusive.
Although this horror movie is based on true events the result is hard to distinguish from any other haunted house ghost story.
A touching tale from director Vadim Perelman with a surprise ending that leaves you plenty to ponder.
The result is an absorbing, old-fashioned drama without the gung-ho rhetoric you might have expected.
A maudlin quest for love with only Phoenix's performance to keep you interested.
It is an immensely likeable affair but it does feel more like a string of amusing anecdotes rather than a film of any substance.
Religulous is a thought-provoking delight.
Sometimes a quiet whisper is more compelling than the loudest shout. Cherry Blossoms is a gentle, maudlin tale of love, loss, family ties and the fleeting nature of life.
A remarkable achievement for a modest documentary that captures the daily experiences of farmers eking out a living in the low mountain valleys of Loz√®re, Ard√®che and Haute-Loire.
movie_title: Profils Paysans: la Vie Moderne (Modern Life) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: a winning combination of personal testimony, history lesson and heart-thumping action footage that chronicles Ireland's contribution to the development of surfing. An impressive insight into a little-known world.
Lisa Ray provides the one spark of life in an otherwise drab, graceless production that appears to be set in the Eighties and has the feel of a bad Jilly Cooper novel.
The surprise factor is that the film has just enough charm and good humour in its own right to broaden that demographic to a wider, recession-hit audience in search of undemanding, feel-good fun.
The situation is cleverly exploited for light laughs and the kind of sunny, undemanding entertainment that is easy to consume.

It is Jim Sturgess who dominates with a charismatic performance that creates an empathy with McGartland as he journeys from arrogant hustler to vulnerable IRA insider crushed by the impossible demands of his double life.
The story makes precious little sense but the car chases help to keep you awake and smouldering hunks Walker and Diesel get to make eyes at each other one more time.

Beautifully crafted and expertly acted, Let The Right One In eschews the easy options of excessive gore and cheap laughs to create a haunting, emotionally involving journey into the macabre. It can only become a classic of the genre.
Family audiences in search of Easter entertainment will not feel disappointed by what is basically one long chase and the film will make a great theme-park ride.
Made on a modest budget this is a brave film from writer-director-star Jacques Nolot who brings an unflinching honesty to his performance.
A tale illustrating the banality of evil is as timely as ever but the execution is heavy-handed and even with location filming and elaborate sets it still feels very theatrical.
Amusing without being uproarious, I Love You Man manages to offset some of its raunchy dialogue and bad taste antics with good humour and charm.
This film will make you rush to a concert hall or the nearest classical music store to savour Beethoven's compositions.

The savage comedy of In The Loop is enough to justify hailing it as a triumph. What takes it to a different level is the way that Iannucci and a great team of writers ultimately manage to make the smile freeze on your face.
This is glossy, forgettable fare more at home as a TV matin√©e.

State Of Play is a good, old-fashioned thriller. It has believable characters and credible situations. It alternates dogged investigation with scenes of sweaty tension that Alfred Hitchcock would have been happy to orchestrate.
The story may not be entirely unfamiliar but writer/director Eran Creevy transforms autobiographical material into an engaging, energetic little drama that is full of promise.
Unfolding amid the dappled sunshine and dusty roads of Provence, this is a film that lifts your spirits.
movie_title: Le fils de l'√©picier (The Grocer's Son) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Lovable Seth Rogen tries something a little different in Observe And Report and it really doesn't work.
Beowulf meets Aliens in a rip-roaring mixture of B-movie clich√©s, wooden acting, dumb dialogue and bloodthirsty action scenes. Indulgent fantasy fans of all ages should find it a guilty pleasure.
An uninspired concoction of overly familiar ingredients, this crude comedy seems aimed at booze-filled lads looking for an undemanding Friday night diversion.
Children will undoubtedly delight in this juvenile cartoonish caper.
movie_title: Les aventures extraordinaires d'Ad√®le Blanc-Sec (The Extraordinary Adventures of Ad√®le Blanc-Sec) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Dead Man Running feels like the last gasp of the Guy Ritchie dodgy deals and diamond geezers genre.
A graphic mixture of violence, heartache, sex and kung fu, Love Exposure is not for all tastes but there are wonderful moments.
Draws strong performances from a well-chosen ensemble cast.
Stone is justifiably angry at America's clandestine interference in the domestic politics of its neighbours and at the media's collusion in demonising figures like Chavez.
The stunt work is impressive, the various international locales are easy on the eye and Cruise and Diaz make a fun couple but it all feels calculated and mechanical.
Stilted performances and an odd whimper of an ending are further flaws in this good-looking but turgid period piece.
The plot is slight and whimsical but eventually develops into a quietly touching love story.
Young children may love it but adults will find it hard to endure.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Even with the addition of 3-D it feels as if the Step Up series has nothing new to offer.
A stately tale that is more of a curiosity than anything else.
movie_title: Eccentricities of a Blonde-haired Girl (Singularidades de uma Rapariga Loura) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Mostly this is just a film of countless deaths and endless clich√©s...
Beautifully crafted and full of surprises Mother grows more compelling as it unfolds.
John Le Carr√© can certainly rest easy at night but if you just want undemanding escapism it delivers the goods.
There is so much plot to condense into just over two hours of screen time that The Girl Who Played With Fire is more efficient than inspired.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A film you either love or hate. I didn't love it.
Still works on a basic level of cheering the hero and hissing the villain as the plucky Dre heads for a final showdown at a kung fu tournament.
Full of obvious jokes and schmaltzy sentiment, Grown Ups is as much fun as watching endless home movies of people you really don't know very well.
A playful, sun-kissed musing on the blurring of art and life, artifice and reality.
Aniston still has a winning way with a comic line although it is really Bateman who carries the film, yet even his understated performance is consistently upstaged by young Robinson.
A laboured set up brings little reward...
Sigismondi's dramatised account of the band has echoes of Almost Famous as it captures a tangy flavour of the hunger for fame and the bittersweet reality of success in the Seventies rock scene.
Critics find this glib Stephen Frears' confection a real rib-tickler but the crude, witless idiocy of it left me stony faced and irritated.
The film continues to grow in the memory months after it was first seen which is always a sign of something great.
The Horde doesn't waste time on niceties like explanations or characterisation but if you like your action movies served raw and bloody it will not disappoint.
A de-glamourised Natascha McElhone is so unconvincing as the harridan of a mother that her performance is hard to take seriously.
The result is intriguing, fitfully amusing and terribly sad because if the story was for real then it has left Phoenix a laughing stock and a broken man.

It runs out of steam in the final third but The Other Guys is constantly kept afloat by a grand cast that includes Michael Keaton as station captain Gene Mauch and Eva Mendes as Gamble's smouldering wife Sheila.
Scary fun for young teens.
An ambitious, visionary work, Enter The Void is a relentless assault on the senses that grows repetitive and redundant during its final 30 minutes.
A film that effectively captures the camaraderie, chaos and complexity of soldiers doing their best to win the "hearts and minds" of the local population.
The film's wry wit and understanding of childhood anxieties will remind older viewers of the television series The Wonder Years which is no small compliment.
It is not awful just very, very ordinary.
If you have ever smiled at a Bertoli commercial it could be just the film for you.
Melding the abundant misunderstandings of a Shakespeare comedy with the New York wit of a Neil Simon play, City Island is a boisterous charmer with a big heart.
The eccentric humour is an acquired taste and the contrived story overstays its welcome.
Understated but involving, The Girl On The Train tells a very personal and specific story that resonates with wider insight into the state of modern France.
movie_title: The Girl on the Train (La Fille du RER) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Avoid at all costs.

You can guess the whole film but the picture postcard locations are easy on the eye and the wonderful Redgrave steals the show. Her heartfelt conviction and natural warmth slice through all the schmaltz to make the silly storyline feel real and touching.
It is certainly the best film director Antoine Fuqua has made since he last traced the thin blue line with Oscar winner Training Day.
There are echoes of The Wicker Man in this supernatural tale but the storytelling is clunky and disjointed and Smith's fondness for tipsy, hand-held camerawork becomes extremely annoying.
The mixture of bravura camera work, muscular direction and inventive storytelling remains unmissable.
Wild Grass uses all the trickery of cinema to create a very enjoyable and oddly touching tale.
As Holofcener charts the telling little developments in these randomly connected lives the film offers wry smiles, smart repartee, mild whimsy and some plaintive, poignant moments.
Heigl and Kutcher are both easy on the eye but neither of them quite have the charisma required to overcome the flat script and uninspired direction.
This leaden romantic comedy feels like a pilot for a television series that never made the grade.
An avalanche of scatalogical humour and lame jokes that make the Austin Powers films look like masterpieces by comparison.

Coppola's fascination with family ties and guilty secrets is at the heart of a grandiose but half-baked saga that doffs its cap to the florid theatricality of Powell and Pressburger and Sixties Italian classics such as La Dolce Vita.
Get Him To The Greek promises a fun time but rarely delivers the goods.
Even diehard fans might find it a bit of a chore.
Annoyingly unfathomable at times this is a film where coherent narrative is very much secondary to the hauntingly beautiful images and vivid atmosphere of a journey into the heart of darkness.
Writer/director Nick Whitfield is clearly a talent to watch.

Duris keeps everything on track, oozing sex appeal and displaying a gift for physical comedy. Heartbreaker is ripe for an American remake but you pity whoever has to follow in the gossamer footsteps of quicksilver charmer Duris.
It isn't quite as witty or inventive as you might have hoped but if it is the last film in the series then it offers an honourable conclusion to a wonderful decade of family entertainment.
Writer/director Nick Whitfield is clearly a talent to watch.
Lymelife is tenderly observed and generally well-played with Timothy Hutton bringing a weary stoicism to one of his best roles in a long while.

The portrait of social change in Sixties America is sketchy but the film effectively states the case for Morrison as a charismatic, complex figure who lived fast, died young and left a lasting legacy.
The film is a swirl of raging hormones, bitter jealousies and the aching grip of feelings that have yet to be physically consummated.
Don't say that you haven't been warned.
Issues of race and social injustice add a little grit and texture to an otherwise overlong and over familiar gangster story.
Told with an unfussy elegance and economy, Leaving builds a steady intensity as it sustains credibility in the journey from drama to melodrama.
Old fashioned and low key, London River feels like a dour kitchen sink chamber piece from the Sixties.
You wince at the cheesy dialogue poor Brody is obliged to mouth and wonder what such actors as Laurence Fishburne, Alice Braga and Topher Grace are doing here.
A B-movie science-fiction melodrama that really needed the genius of David Cronenberg to bring it to life.
Charming and highly original but a little of it goes a long way.
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Clarke does all he can to grab your attention but then you learn he has nothing worth saying. A big disappointment.
This brief animated feature feels like a bit of a cheap rip-off that might work as a time-filler on children's television but doesn't warrant the expense of a family trip to the cinema.
Intellectually and aesthetically Police, Adjective is a film of merit but that doesn't make it any easier to endure.
Bardem is compelling but Biutiful is unrelentingly bleak.
It offers a plaintive window into an unfamiliar world.
[A] likeable if unsurprising culture clash comedy set in the early Nineties.
Small children with low levels of expectation are the target for this blandly unimaginative mix of live-action and 3D animation.
An emotion-charged documentary...
There are amusing moments but it's as illuminating as an average episode of Coach Trip.
One of the great love letters to the chaos and creativity, joy and sorrow of movie-making.
A brooding Australian thriller that marks director David Mich√¥d as a talent to watch.
Not a perfect film but still entertaining in its own right.
A noble stab at the Bard but ultimately an unsatisfactory film.
Informative and thought-provoking...
movie_title: Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A smart comic performance from Felicity Jones is the film's saving grace.

The latest collaboration between veteran British director Ken Loach and screenwriter Paul Laverty has a disappointingly routine well-worn thriller plot but they deliver it with a welcome layer of moral complexity in the end.
A modest look at love and friendship but Spector manages to tell it with a generous heart and a sharp-eye for what makes relationships tick.
Naturalistic performances from a non-professional cast add to the austere integrity and touching humanity of this bleak tale.
Retains a strong literary flavour but is also told with much cinematic verve and an engaging eagerness to please.
You Will Meet A Tall Dark Stranger is a typically wry, rueful ensemble piece in which love makes fools of everyone.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Eagle is not your typical sword and sandal epic. You could easily mistake it for a western, a war movie or even a timely commentary on the human casualties of 21st century conflict.
The plot is utter tosh but executed with such flamboyant style that you might think it was Shakespeare. Or not.

The backstage shenanigans and tear-stained soap opera are all too predictable in Country Strong but the performances lend it conviction and the soundtrack has enough heart and soul to endear it to true country music fans.
A fascinating, idiosyncratic film that demands to be seen in 3-D.
An unremarkable B-movie revenge thriller.
A predictable but well-made chiller.
A Belgian production that can boast some accomplished Finding Nemo-style underwater visuals.
A sci-fi thriller in which the playfulness of Groundhog Day is cannily molded to the paranoia of The Manchurian Candidate.
There are gruelling, gleeful scenes of blood-drenched murder and dismemberment that will test even the hardest stomach.
Made with the visual polish and dramatic intensity of a fictional feature, Armadillo is a significant addition to the documentaries on the war on terror.
The inventiveness starts to fade after the first hour but there is enough originality and winning humour in that hour to make Rubber a great guilty pleasure movie.
If you long for the days of legal eagle thrillers such as Jagged Edge or Basic Instinct then The Lincoln Lawyer is for you.
Get Low has all the modest pleasures of a well-told tale.
An amateurish, low-budget bloodbath.
An absorbing, level-headed documentary exposing the way in which nothing is allowed to stand in the path of corporate greed.
A witless, puerile spoof of the Twilight movies.
It is not a film that offers a great deal of insight or explanation, just a chance to luxuriate in the world that Kiefer has created.
movie_title: Over Your Cities Grass Will Grow (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The storytelling is simple and feels a little rushed. Not a classic but a good half-term option for younger children.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Arbor is one of the most imaginative and compelling documentaries seen in recent years.
An unorthodox but unforgettable valentine to a friendship that blossoms between two lonely people.
It matches moments of globetrotting, Bourne-like cloak-and-dagger intrigue with the documentary precision of a police investigation determined to leave nothing uncovered.
Landis enjoyed some massive hits in the Eighties but this is his first feature film in 12 years and his style seems a little rusty.
A screwball comedy with charm and sass it established a template that countless films have followed down the decades.
Pitts is a solemn, silent presence and his director's eye ensures a succession of expertly composed images that each tell a story.
Another Year may sound like a profoundly miserable film but it is more like a film that refuses to sugar-coat reality.
Mammoth looks sleek and is well-acted but the preachy tone is hard to bear.
Not exactly the most subtle of films, Fit does muster some touching moments as it illustrates the campaigning slogan Some People Are Gay. Get Over It.
The historical events may be little known but everything else from the swelling score to the cardboard characters feels all too familiar.
The Kids Are All Right is warmly recommended to anyone in search of smart, grown-up entertainment.
This is a superb beginning to the end of a great British success story. You rejoice that they decided to forgo 3D. The Potter films don't need gimmicks to get our attention.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This modest story works because of committed performances from both actors.
movie_title: La t√™te en friche (My Afternoons with Margueritte) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It is a thriller that still has the ability to shock because it holds up a mirror to the impulses in all of us. Perhaps that is why so many people found it hard to stomach in 1960.
A disturbing debut feature from Australian playwright Michael Rowe that is reminiscent of the Roman Polanski classic Repulsion.
The great thing about Catfish is the compassion it shows towards everyone involved. It tries to reach an understanding of the truth but without mocking or judging.
A slightly preachy but entertaining tale for younger viewers on the perils of global warming and the foolishness of human kind.
If the only Freds you are aware of are Astaire or Flintstone then I'm afraid that Fred: The Movie will come as a terrible shock.
It's beautifully made but feels more like an art installation than something you might savour in a cinema.
Diego Luna's promising debut as a director is a slight and charming tale of a troubled young boy's retreat into fantasy.
Did they really say "I've saved your ass" in medieval Europe?
Chou steals the show, especially when he speeds into action in glorious Kato-Vision.
A powerful, piercing, brilliantly acted exploration of the ways in which love can die.
Despite good intentions and moving moments it could almost be a television movie.
There is a lot of plot in Henry's Crime, although there's nothing you couldn't second-guess and while Farmiga is delightful and Caan a joy the end result is unremarkable.
You are more likely to be scoffing than biting your nails at this theatrical little effort.
Steeped in both magic and mythology, The Secret Of Kells offers a refreshing alternative to Hollywood fare.
A sobering and thought-provoking film.
Shrink neatly intertwines the lives of the leading characters in a manner reminiscent of Robert Altman's Short Cuts but without that film's haunting poignancy.
Flashy, action-packed and totally forgettable, The Losers still fits the bill for a lads' night out.
The lean running time leaves little room to develop the characters or deepen the story but Carriers is a decently done doomsday B-movie.
It may be slight and more than a little fuzzy but there is a certain soulful charm to Unmade Beds that keeps you engaged.
The new version is serviceable, bland and forgettable.
Thanks to a recent restoration overseen by Martin Scorsese, the Oscar-winning classic is now looking better than ever and fully deserves its return to cinema screens.

If you are going to make a film about Orson Welles then you need an actor who can provide a brilliant impersonation of this colossus of the New York stage. They have found such an actor in Christian McKay.

Avatar may be a little hollow in the centre but the sheer scale and ambition of the production make it hard to beat. Never mind the inadequacies of the story, just savour the spectacle and what can be achieved with the appliance of science.
A slick, razzle-dazzle entertainment that doesn't engage your heart in the way that it should.
Kristin Scott-Thomas and Anne-Marie Duff are both brilliant and Aaron Johnson convincingly captures the sarcasm and raw emotions of Lennon in a film that is both hugely enjoyable and moving.
A handsome, entertaining romp of a film that they really should have called Lock, Stock And Two Smoking Pipes.
More subtle and insightful than you might have expected.
The slapdash sequel doesn't tamper with the winning formula, which means lots more joyless slapstick, crude stereotypes and girls behaving very badly.
movie_title: St Trinian's II: The Legend of Fritton's Gold (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Funnniest moment? The loud snores from a fellow critic at the press preview.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Oliver Parker and Barnaby Thompson do nothing here to destroy a winning formula which is cannily constructed to appeal to the target audience of teenage girls and nobody else.
movie_title: St Trinian's II: The Legend of Fritton's Gold (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Stylish but stilted, beautiful but tiresome, it becomes a film that simply tests the limits of your patience.

John Hillcoat's impressive screen version is not without its flaws but it does capture the abject bleakness of McCarthy's vision in a way that feels like the cold chill of winter invading your very bones.

It's Complicated rarely rises above the level of a television sitcom but Streep is witty and believable and has great chemistry with an ebullient, charismatic Baldwin and together they make the film a painless slice of escapism.
Mugabe And The White African is an outstanding documentary offering eye-opening testimony to the plight of one family who seem symbolic of so much that has gone wrong with the country.
An intriguing, claustrophobic thriller.
The yearning to become human again adds emotional heft to the gory dystopian mayhem.
Highly resistible.
t is a performance that could win [Clooney] a best actor Oscar in a film that is as warm and civilised as a welcoming bar on a bleak winter's night.

Monologues float and sting like a Muhammad Ali punch, words are like weapons, expletives are strung together with such ferocious precision that they sound like poetry. Shame the plot is virtually non-existent and the ultimate effect is tiresome.
This po-faced adventure has more in common with the Kevin Costner clinker The Postman than anything touched by the hand of a Pulitzer prize-winning novelist.
Told with a measured pace, Still Walking gently beguiles as it captures the tensions, the silly misunderstandings, love and lingering regrets that are present in all families.
A comedy so irritating and cheerless that you wonder if the cast were blackmailed into appearing.

An amiable, Mel Brooks-style spoof that mercilessly satirises the gallic Bond's racism and breezy misogyny. Glamorous locations, expert production design and sly nods to the Swinging Sixties setting are all endearing.
movie_title: OSS 117: Rio ne r√©pond plus (Lost in Rio) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A well-balanced documentary all the more incisive for its decision to eschew editorialising and let the evidence speak for itself.
A welcome reminder of just how fine an actor Gyllenhaal can be and one of the reasons to catch this understated tale of a family at war.
The film's ace is a hard-working performance from Andy Serkis who plays Dury with wild-eyed gusto.
It's hard to conclude this is a film for children but it will provide any adult with a bittersweet reminder of childhood's distant joys and woes.
Amiable, lightweight fare that adults might appreciate more than children.
Notable for its calm composure, unfussy style and some fine performances.
Beautiful cinematography, exceptional performances and an admirable sense of restraint combine to make it one of the most gorgeous and satisfying period dramas in recent memory.
A laidback, slightly underwhelming farce on the madness of the military.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Inferno could have been a film to rank alongside Vertigo or Peeping Tom and its abandonment is one of cinema's great tragedies. This is a dazzling act of resurrection.

The use of 3-D leaves the not unpleasant sensation that snow is gently falling throughout the entire cinema. A respectable, high-tech stab at an old favourite but the Alastair Sim version remains the best.
The balance of Welcome increasingly tips towards Simon's story but along the way there are some heavy-handed but effective attacks on France's hostility to the immigrants in their cities.
[Diablo Cody's] salty dialogue is the saving grace of Jennifer's Body, a gleeful, old-fashioned mix of gore and giggles that feels awfully pleased with itself.
Some viewers have found this film adorable but its quirky cuteness was lost on me.
A morally dubious thriller that is caught between social realism and lurid sensationalism.
Complete codswallop but perversely entertaining.
When it takes to the skies Amelia really soars with thrilling recreations of Earhart's solo flights but when it returns to earth all that remains is soap opera.
Cold Souls is odd and gloomy but the deadpan comedy and introspective musings are engaging and Giamatti's tour de force is worth the price of admission.
Unless you share Bana's worship of screeching tyres and throbbing engines then this is probably something you only really need to see on the small screen.
A minor work from Brokeback Mountain director Ang Lee that is enjoyable but ultimately underwhelming.
Filmed in ravishing black and white, White Ribbon is hypnotic film‚Äëmaking with a thought-provoking afterglow.
It isn't quite as enthralling or as soulful as the original but it still persuades you that such a far-fetched premise should be taken seriously - which is no mean feat.

The film is slow-burning and lugubrious but there is some amusement to be found in the parade of eccentric individuals, running jokes and repetitive dream sequences served up to illustrate the fact that life is one big cosmic joke.
Romola Garai is extremely good but the film is an elegant disappointment.
An amusing and beautifully acted little caper but the very American shenanigans may well struggle to keep you entirely engaged.
A wonderful soundtrack and a collection of great performances make this an entertaining and touching ensemble piece.
movie_title: Le Premier Jour du Reste de ta Vie (The First Day of the Rest of Your Life) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The fear of the unknown and what may lurk in the dark shadows of your own home creates moments that set the heart racing in this subtle, understated little shocker.

A bizarre mix of Dali imagery, Heath Robinson-style contraptions and a large dollop of British eccentricity. Artificial sets, painted backdrops and endless whimsy are part of the attraction but a little goes a long way.
The mix of sentimental melodrama and comedy of manners might lack a little edge at times but the film remains likeable and more enjoyable than many low-budget British ventures.
On a snowy Boxing Day afternoon tucked up at home bursting with mince pies and bonhomie you might tolerate Nativity on the TV. In the glaring spotlight of the big screen it's a Christmas turkey.

Moreau's marvellous performance captures the vulnerabilities of a woman who never dares to dream that her work might be taken seriously and who seemed to spend a lifetime poised between the call of greatness and the threat of madness.

The 1976 setting is nicely evoked in some hideously familiar wallpaper, fashion choices and facial hair but the film never feels more than a convoluted shaggy dog story stretched out over a very long two hours.
Scott shows a talent for composition and creating atmosphere but Cracks covers very familiar ground and winds up feeling sluggish.
A sentimental but beguiling charmer of a film.
The screen version does not disappoint and features an outstanding performance from John Malkovich.

Zac Efron may be the bait that tempts you to see this tale of theatre life and moral dilemma but is it Christian McKay's amazing Welles that leaves you searching for the superlatives and singing the film's praises.
Immodesty Blaize goes behind the tassels and sequins to discover the appeal and comes to the far-from-earth-shattering conclusion that it's all about harmless fantasy.
This is not a film that lets you off the hook or allows you to avert your eyes. Commendable in its own way but not something I would rush to recommend.
Not a classic like Reservoir Dogs but a perfectly watchable thriller thanks to a cast of old pros.
A cut above the average music documentary.
movie_title: Blur: No Distance Left to Run (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Centurion is certainly atmospheric but the brutality and beheadings make it disappointingly monotonous.
If you want something to engage the mind as well as set the blood boiling then it is an unexpected pleasure.
A sequel that more than matches the original's impact.
This deliberately amateurish, self-indulgent effort manages to be odd while rarely remembering to be funny.
The Georgia locations are handsome and the people are pretty but any resemblance to real life is purely coincidental.
Solid performances from all three cast members keep you involved until the last moment.

Julie Rutterford's well-observed script has a lively wit, the rainswept seaside sets are atmospheric and the cast are beyond reproach but once they part company from credibility the film's spell is broken.
A feeble family comedy that really tests your patience.

It's all efficiently done and gory but director Samuel Bayer adds so little to the old familiar scare story that you wonder why they didn't just save a bob or two and reissue the Robert Englund original.
A missed opportunity.
The cast is fine but the film is strident and bland. Having an Audrey Hepburn DVD on standby might be the best back-up plan.
You may have qualms and reservations about Four Lions but it will make you laugh and it might even make you shed a tear. It is comedy without a safety net. A comedy of terrors.
This is a perceptive biographical documentary that includes a wealth of previously unseen footage and the affectionate personal testimonies of friends and family members who knew him best.
There is a lot of unconvincing, random plot, most characters are deeply unsympathetic and the women are poorly served by underdeveloped roles.
A big, sweeping epic executed in a manner that makes all the spectacle and pageantry appear effortless.
Maoz tells his story with economy and focus, creating a sweatily convincing account of the personal hell he found on the front line of modern warfare.
A full-blooded melodrama pitched at the level of grand opera.
Appearances from Britain's Got Talent stars Diversity, Flawless and George Sampson, along with some nimble routines, enhance the appeal of this energetic, unpretentious slice of teen entertainment.

Tight close-ups and direct-to- camera confessionals are the order of the day in a film so peppered with sleazy sex, casual violence and endless swearing that it comes perilously close to caricature. Nobody's finest hour.
Daft dialogue and silly costumes, sword fights and death-defying stunts, breathless chases and slithering snakes. Nonsense but entertaining nonsense.

Almost matches its predecessor, taking up the tale moments after the original ended and hurtling us through another adrenaline fuelled rollercoaster ride.
Hugely ambitious and oddly beguiling...
Feels like a relic from the Seventies, but it does have funny moments.

A breezy satire on consumerism that takes a smart idea and develops it into an entertaining morality tale.

A decent film.
Funny, inventive, surprisingly affecting and packed full of delightful touches, this is family entertainment of the highest order and definitely worth catching in this format.
A film that you will not easily forget. It is a cry from the heart told with an emotional charge that takes your breath away.

A wry, melancholic look at post-war Japanese society.
A solid, slightly old-fashioned drama.

Very American, very crass and very underwhelming.

movie_review_blurb: A quirkily endearing low-budget effort.
The romantic-comedy formula is so barely disguised, it feels like it should be a spoof.

A beautifully made but often uneven film with a luminous central role from Ronan.

A dazzling, helter-skelter comedy that fizzes with invention and silly slapstick.
Despite the heavyweight presence of Harrison Ford and Brendan Fraser, the film feels too much like a television production than something that merits big screen status.

Amy Adams can add sparkle to even the most lacklustre screenplays and that seems to be her function in Leap Year, a disappointing romantic comedy set in the kind of Ireland that only exists in the movies.

[Eisner's] version of The Crazies may not have the raw power of the 1973 original but it is an efficient, slightly soulless depiction of how quickly civilised values are abandoned as panic erupts in America's heartland.

Burton's Alice In Wonderland joins the ranks of Return To Oz and Hook in confirming that it's rarely a good idea to return to the scene of a classic novel unless you have something new and exciting to bring.

A sweet, low-key production with a modest charm.

Immensely entertaining and very well acted.
A film that is worthy and well made rather than exceptional.

Unsparing but even-handed in its characterisation of a father and daughter as two stubborn individuals desperately seeking a way to reconnect.
A big disappointment.

Overlong but acutely observed it is cleverly understated and consistently intriguing.
A dour, dogged little drama.

A creepy supernatural yarn from the director of Trollhunter.
