Shot in lustrous black and white, Lover For A Day is an elegant reflection on the meaning of fidelity, revealing the characters in what could be their true colours.
movie_title: Lover For A Day (L'amant d'un jour) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: It couldn't be more relevant in our era of spin doctors, fake news and cyber attacks.
It is nonsense but it is slick, highly entertaining nonsense.
Understated and confidently judged, it becomes a testimony to the old-fashioned virtues of social-realist storytelling rooted in ordinary lives and timely concerns.

Intriguing throughout, Rust unfolds with assurance as [Aly] Muritiba carefully places his camera to direct the focus of our attention, or lingers on a close up as if to confirm the importance of a particular moment or speech.
Bunuelian in its brash satire of corporate ambition, Time Share can be as blackly comic as a Coen brothers screenplay ...
It is the starting point for a wide-ranging examination of complex issues surrounding freedom of speech, censorship and corporate responsibility.
The story of three siblings reunited by a call from their long estranged father is told with an unpredictable blend of rueful regrets, home truths and bursts of absurdist comedy.
You are encouraged to savour the spectacle of this efficient blockbuster rather than question the logic of the plot.
A decent cast and striking photography lend substance to the depiction of a mission driven by patriotic fervour and heroic intentions.
This wry and rueful film largely consists of three men talking and its static quality makes it feel more like a play with Cranston stealing the acting honours as the rascally, sardonic Sal.
You admire the ambitious storytelling and the craftsmanship of its execution.
Flimsy but good wholesome fun.

Roman J. Israel, Esq is a fantastic showcase for Washington who really shines here, making Israel noble, flawed and unknowable. Yet, taken as a whole, it isn't quite worthy of the character or his performance.

The pin-sharp precision of the dialogue, the magnificent, lilting musical score from Jonny Greenwood and the quality of the performances all combine to create an audacious, spellbinding slice of storytelling.
Worth seeing for Washington's committed performance ...
An honest man becomes a thorn in the side of a corrupt, callous society in the gripping political drama Glory.
A painstakingly realised portrait of the agonising final days of the Sun King.
movie_title: The Death of Louis XIV (La mort de Louis XIV) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Graceful, heartfelt and infused with a generous spirit, this is a rare and lovely drama.
Ragnarok is unpretentious high-spirited entertainment that feels like a breath of fresh air.
Sandberg knows all the tricks and delivers enough jolts to ensure the horror franchise keeps making money.
Undeniably schmaltzy but it is also engaging and funny. Only a curmudgeon wouldn't respond to its life-affirming message.
movie_title: Mein Blind Date mit dem Leben (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Not entirely coherent, Napping is still visually striking with some outstanding action sequences.
movie_title: Napping Princess (Hirune-hime: Shiranai watashi no monogatari) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The agonising last days of a woman in the final stages of Alzheimer's are captured in a stark, unflinching manner by Wang Bing's gruelling documentary.
A film that looks fantastic but becomes bogged down in soap opera conventions and biopic clich√©s. A lot of dodgy wigs and liver spots float before our eyes to convey the passage of years.
There is so much plot to cover here that there is little time left to engage with the characters.
This odd couple "romp" is so dumb and shows such disregard for human life that it beggars belief.
The seas sparkle, the skies shimmer but the script refuses to shine as it soon becomes bogged down in family dramas and soap opera clich√©s.
There is a bracing originality to The Untamed, a surreal mixture of science fiction and sexually charged kitchen sink drama from cult Mexican director Amat Escalante.
A film that brings little insight to a troubling issue.
It is entertaining and there is ultimately a poignancy in an artist addicted to perfectionism.
Detroit tells such a powerful, visceral tale that it demands to be seen and discussed.
Expertly made but strangely uninvolving.
Absorbing, handsomely crafted ...
Bautista is strong but others feel out of their depth.
An entertaining if glib film, especially if you are a Cruise fan.
A lacklustre comedy in which a raucous hen party winds up with an inconvenient corpse.
Pleasant enough but winds up underwhelming.
This globetrotting spy yarn is desperately old hat and lacking in budget and energy.
An outstanding debut feature.
Rooney gives a forceful performance while Mendelsohn is creepily plausible as a man who seems both predatory and sincere in his feelings for the younger Una.
Random encounters, narrow escapes and some tough home truths drive a scrappy story that is delivered with considerable charm.
A low-budget American drama that is rough and ready at the start but blossoms into a life-affirming charmer.
The performances are engaging and the film is very likeable, especially as we witness the landscapes through the changing seasons of sun-dappled summer and snow-clad winter.
movie_title: Back to Burgundy (Ce qui nous lie) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Pitched as a film where 'heist meets horror', The Vault is a muddled tale of two halves.
An emotional journey that resonates well beyond this hidden corner of America.
A tense, well-acted thriller that keeps you involved until the bitter end.
The few bright spots in this horribly violent sequel come from Liev Schreiber's return as grizzled veteran Ross Rhea. His warm, world-weary performance belongs in a much better film.
This modest, melancholy affair unfolds with wry humour and a warm heart as the demanding father and his resentful son find peace, love and understanding.
A bold experiment of a film that can only be called haunting.

The constant suggestion of cross and double-cross becomes a little wearing as the film heads to the two-hour mark and we never really care about the characters or feel they do more than strike the coolest of poses and the fiercest of blows.
Love moves in the most twisted, mysterious ways in The Song Of Scorpions, a film whose gentle manner belies it darker themes.
An eerie tale that is all the more effective for its restraint.
The notion of an immature, untrained Spider-Man brings a fresh feel and the always reliable Michael Keaton makes a sinister but strangely sympathetic villain as The Vulture.
An insufferably pretentious affair that feels like a selection of improvised rehearsals rather than the finished article.
Uncompromising, challenging and deeply felt.
movie_title: The Death of Louis XIV (La mort de Louis XIV) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If you want to understand the mind behind Twin Peaks and Blue Velvet then David Lynch: The Art Life is probably essential.
It is a gruelling film but one that weaves a sombre spell.
movie_title: The Death of Louis XIV (La mort de Louis XIV) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Thoughtful in its approach the film feels authentic in its depiction of individuals for whom food is an enemy.
The candlelit interiors and misty forests make the film look inviting and the acting is fist rate with Farrell winning our sympathy and Dunst capturing all the longing and heartache of Edwina.
Manic, simplistic and never especially funny, Monster Island is a plucky attempt that is unlikely to cause any sleepless nights for Despicable Me 3 or Captain Underpants.
Young kids will have a giggle and even grown-ups might crack a smile. A very pleasant surprise.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Dunkirk brings a lump to the throat and a tear to the eye. Highly recommended.
City Of Ghosts salutes RBSS while reminding us how little was being done to bring the nightmare to an end.
It starts to feel far-fetched and the plot never quite adds up.
An ill-advised twist in the tale leaves you feeling foolish for ever taking it seriously.
Powerful performances help to make this the stuff of nightmares.
One of the best Merchant Ivory productions and one of the finest adaptations of an EM Forster novel.
Girls Trip is crude and veers towards soap opera but there is a chemistry between the stars, some funny situations and Haddish steals the show as the unrelentingly vulgar Dina.
A film that begins with the premise of a classic western or a cat-and-mouse thriller unfolds more like a worthy radio drama or a fringe theatre production.
A thoughtful, poignant drama that is comfortably carried on the shoulders of an ebullient, heartfelt performance from M√∏ller ...
It may buzz with energy and unspool at a breathless pace but originality is not one of its strengths.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It is a suitably grey and gloomy portrait of the artist as a young man with an eclectic soundtrack and a plucky central performance from Dunkirk's Jack Lowden.
A thoughtful, poignant story that deservedly won M√∏ller the Danish equivalent of the Bafta best actor prize.
Connors' compelling performance creates a degree of sympathy for Jason however the film seems a little too fond of his brutality and casual misogyny.
Sad faces all around.
It may not withstand close scrutiny but The Ghoul provides a workout for the little grey cells and suggests Tunley is a filmmaker to watch.
The path from resentment to reconciliation may be well-worn but it is travelled with a good deal of charm and sensitivity in Lola Pater.
It may have its failings but it is never less than entertaining.
It achieves stray laughs and some clever moments, but not enough to render it more than a strained curiosity.
[A] meticulously executed, obsessively stylised exercise in genre worship that quickly becomes overpowering.
movie_title: Let the Corpses Tan (Laissez bronzer les cadavres!) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An intense, claustrophobic tale of the human costs of an impossible conflict.
If you didn't love Grace Jones before, then you will after watching Grace Jones: Bloodlight And Bami.
[An] entertaining, low-key documentary.
A gripping, fresh perspective on crime and punishment.
Witherspoon once triumphed with Legally Blonde but this is lethally bland.
It is a delicate, melancholy piece graced by two fine, understated performances and Fonda stands out as a practical, pragmatic woman who is not ready to give up on life just yet.
The film looks beautiful but is deeply unpleasant to watch.
A modest but intriguing film.
Plummer plays the elderly Kaiser with a mixture of arrogance, roguish wit and vulnerability and completely steals the show.
This pun-filled film unfolds with affection and features a gallery of quirky characters from veteran chairman Doug to 12-year-old novice Rhys. A real delight.
The story of AA Milne and the creation of Winnie The Pooh should warm the heart and bring a tear to the eye but there are only fleeting moments when it hits the mark.
Harrelson makes [his character] more than a two-dimensional ne'er-do-well, finding poignancy in his good intentions and generous acts.
If you are in the mood for an old-fashioned, romantic tearjerker, then The Mountain Between Us is only too happy to oblige.
An awkward hybrid of cin√©ma v√©rit√© documentary and drama.
A restless mixture of inventive animation and over-elaborate storytelling set over a single long night in Kyoto.
movie_title: The Night Is Short, Walk On Girl (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Interesting enough but not especially insightful or revealing.
Shot in black and white, The Party feels highly theatrical and mannered but it is also gleefully funny and performed with relish by a starry cast.
A sleek visual polish and a game cast can't disguise the fact that Flatliners is one film that should have carried a Do Not Resuscitate Order.
[A] breezy coming-of-age story.
A poignant portrait of a revolutionary artist.
The film slowly wins your heart as it explores the complexity of a relationship with problems that have no easy solutions.
Mulubwa's sullen, inscrutable Shula is a compelling presence at the heart of the story, but more clarity in explaining her ultimate fate might have made the film even more accessible.
Tarling Is Darling is too niche and meandering to connect on a wider level.
There may be a predictable arc to the narrative, but the uncompromising performances and sensitive direction allow it to punch above its weight ...
As modest and endearing as its central character, Violeta At Last marks a welcome return for director Hilda Hidalgo Xirinachs.
This modest, sensitively handled documentary becomes as compelling as any drama in this heartbreaking production.
Avid Sir David Attenborough watchers may have already seen elements of this film but there is plenty of new footage to make it well worth seeing.
Her ordeal is depicted with a combination of striking images, social satire and the potent sense of a youngster confronting the injustices and uncertainty of the adult world.
Hallucinations and fantasy sequences tend towards the tacky in a film that fails to make the most of an incredible journey.
The film is savagely, often uproariously, comic but the laughter freezes on your lips as you question if something this horrible can ever be truly funny.
A hulking, two-fisted Vaughn is surprisingly effective in the kind of film that might once have starred Charles Bronson, but it is not for the fainthearted.
There is a fond, wistful tone to Last Days In Havana (√öltimos d√≠as en la Habana) that encourages you to indulge its inconsistencies in plotting and style.
movie_title: Last Days in Havana (√öltimos d√≠as en La Habana) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An efficient atmospheric potboiler but it lacks the impact of the book.
What had initially seemed a straightforward figure winds up feeling like a man with all the contradictions and moral dilemmas of a protagonist in a Martin Scorsese/Paul Schrader film.

Pavlenkova's rich, emotional performance is one of the reasons it becomes such an involving, touching film but Tverdovsky's sure touch, bone-dry social satire and affinity with the outsider confirms him as a talent to watch.
Robert Bolt's intelligent screenplay captures a portrait of a fiendishly complex, hopelessly idealistic individual and explores the politics at play.
This sweeping saga of a generation marked by political and social upheaval is told with a combination of virtuoso filmmaking and unrelenting schmaltz.
A solidly engrossing political drama, anchored by a commanding central performance from Liam Neeson.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As the casualties mount and the ironies increase, the story eventually tightens its grip ... as it lurches towards grand guignol and there is a positively Nymanesque tone to Benedict Taylor's score.
Exuding sunny optimism, sassy wit and sheer joie de vivre, Lady Bird could be the perfect antidote to these angst-ridden times.
An assured piece of storytelling made all the more gripping by the knowledge that it is autobiographical.
movie_title: What Will People Say? (Hva vil folk si) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The central odd-couple characters effectively utilise both the comic skills and dramatic abilities of Bryan Cranston and Kevin Hart, whose affectionate chemistry provides a large part of the film's appeal.
An intelligent balance between romantic drama and literary biography that could hold a solid appeal for upscale arthouse audiences.
A robust, sinewy production that honours the film's enduring themes and proves that it has stood the test of time.
An exquisitely crafted period drama telling the true story of blind musician Maria Theresia von Paradis and pioneering physician Dr Franz Mesmer.

Filled with casual betrayals, divided loyalties and enough story to spawn a franchise, The Villainess roars along like a runaway train and is a brilliant showcase for Kim, who kicks sand in the face of any Hollywood bad girl.
A sweetly imaginative, tenderly played coming of age drama.
Carell finds the outrageous and the sad within Riggs' personality but it is the warmth and force of Stone's highly convincing performance that wins game, set and film.
Hostiles acknowledges that American history is steeped in blood and hatred but still searches for signs of hope arising from the ashes of countless atrocities.
We only see what Loung sees, feel what she experiences but through her ordeal there develops an emotional connection to a country undergoing some of its darkest hours.
An unashamed tearjerker that seems determined to ensure that even the stiffest upper lip will wobble. Cynics should consider themselves warned.
The best laid plans go hysterically awry in Suburbicon, a gleeful skewering of America's dark heart from director George Clooney.
A treasure trove of expertly chosen clips, rare interviews and behind-the-scenes footage mean the daunting three-hour running time leaves you wanting more.
movie_title: My Journey Through French Cinema (Voyage √Ä Travers Le Cin√©ma Fran√ßais) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An engaging Hungarian film whose tough exterior conceals a warm heart.
A film that is decent, sincere and surprisingly watchable.
Exhausting, edge-of-the-seat thrills.
Victoria & Abdul feels awfully like Mrs Brown 2 but Dench is just as good and you are hugely invested in the emotional wellbeing of the elderly monarch. She is the film's saviour.
A gruelling experience that heads off the rails and feels more like personal therapy for director Darren Aronofsky rather than a film for public consumption.
A sentimental, meandering tale in which all the little fleeting pleasures don't quite constitute a satisfying whole.

Jowly, bald and portly, [Oldman] matches all the familiar physical characteristics of Churchill with an expert approximation of his vocal mannerisms from an alcohol-slurred splutter to the spellbinding rhetoric that inspired a nation at war.
It is a maudlin affair but the beauty and precision of the tango remains spellbinding.
An offbeat romance that also contains some graphic scenes of animal slaughter.
movie_title: On Body and Soul (A Testr√∂l √©s L√©lekr√∂l) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: In Between may seem a little cartoonish at times but ultimately emerges as a joyous celebration of sisterhood.
A handsome, well-made trip down memory lane that works best if you've forgotten the final score.
The plot is convoluted, the running time is excessive and the cast is top heavy with underemployed Oscar winners but fans of the original may still enjoy the ride.
This warm-hearted French drama feels like a love letter to the teaching profession and its powerful influence on young lives.
There are some random funny moments but most of the time it feels manic, mirthless and lacking in charm.
[A] small undercurrent of social commentary adds some extra spice to a juicy whodunit.
Interesting to a degree but you are left wondering what exactly the point is.
The combination of Greengrass's muscular direction, Damon's soulful performance, a classy cast and some expert action make this a must-see movie.
It is totally captivating and utterly tragic and confirms John Maclean as a major new talent.
It is a handsomely crafted, perfectly decent period drama and a partial return to form for Hirschbiegel after ill-advised English-language ventures like Diana and The Invasion.
A sweeping, breathless, gloriously overblown adventure yarn filled with marketable ingredients, from rip-roaring battle scenes to exotic landscapes, big-hearted romance to cliff-hanging suspense.

Vaguely aims for a Ghostbusters vibe and falls far short with its mixture of flashy special effects, lazy nostalgia for 1980s pop culture and a flippant script that veers uncomfortably between family entertainment and adult wisecracks.
Despite a seasoned cast that ranges from James Franco to old reliable Tom Wilkinson, this awkward fusion of Shallow Grave and Home Alone never amounts to a credible or compelling tale.
Everything is drawn in the broadest of brushstrokes: a baby on the way for Jones, a haunting incident from Engel's past, etc.
Utterly spellbinding.
The pleasure of this screwball comedy comes from both Tracy and the viewer falling under the spell of the irresistible Brooke and Gerwig's delightful performance.
A captivating story shot on breathtaking locations in southern Jordan that feels like a companion piece to Lawrence Of Arabia.
An often challenging and ponderous work.
A wide-ranging, slightly meandering documentary essay that blends crowd-pleasing japes with thought-provoking analysis.
This is a film that mines the profoundest truths from the simplest of stories and underlines the sheer absurdity of the situation.
It's a modest pleasure of a film that leaves you hoping it is not the last word from the octogenarian Boorman.
It's an accomplished and intriguing work that marks Jung out as a talent to watch.
It is a model of dignified, delicate restraint but there are times when it seems to suffocate under the weight of its own sumptuous respectability.
A surprisingly jaunty slice of Hollywood history that cuts a little deeper when it tries to illuminate the politics and injustice of the period.
A guaranteed middlebrow crowd-pleaser offering a plaintive ode to friendship, community, British reserve and the kindness of strangers.
The moody, black-and-white cinematography, literary voice-over and intense exploration of messy relationships and broken hearts effortlessly evokes the world of Eric Rohmer and Francois Truffaut.
The film is unashamedly middle-brow and sentimental but it tells such a good story that it is hard to resist.

The world really doesn't need another film celebrating the notoriety of gangsters Ronnie and Reggie Kray but the decision to have Hardy play both brothers gives this lengthy film an irresistible appeal.
Rams may sound bleak and unforgiving but it has a generous spirit and wit that make it entirely accessible.
A wistful remembrance of the joys and sorrows, triumphs and tragedies that mark a human life. You suspect it is a film with the force to linger and grow in the memory.

The latest space mission saga from veteran director Ridley Scott may not be a genre landmark like Alien, but what it lacks in subtlety it certainly makes up for in spectacle and heart-in-the-throat tension.
Moody cinematography and a brooding sense of a community in which loyalty is everything add to the appeal of this sprawling, fact-based saga.
The quality of the cast is almost as impressive as the sight of some of the terrain that awaits them.
An uninspired mixture of slapstick comedy and sentimentality, A Walk In The Woods gets by on the charisma of the two stars but there are times when it feels stretched to breaking point.
Aside from the dynamic Sheehan, it is a lifeless, uninvolving effort.
McNamara's breezy screenplay condenses complex events and an eventful life into a trim, accessible feature.
An intriguing tale that twists and turns in some unexpected ways.
Given some of Pacino's dubious choices in recent decades (Jack And Jill was the nadir), you assume he can appreciate elements of his own career in a story very loosely inspired by true events.

A contemplative, often ravishing-looking, immersion in the complex politics, power struggles and personalities of the Tang Dynasty as seen through the moral dilemmas facing an enigmatic trained assassin.
An often risibly pretentious film that seems relentlessly drawn to the incomprehensible.
You need to be patient with Before The Winter Chill. It is a gloomy, slow-burning film that adds insight and intrigue the way an artist brings texture and colour to a painting.
A film where action speaks louder than words.
Stylish but heavy-handed.
A pretentious burlesque of a film in which you are never entirely sure what Gosling is trying to say.
Strikingly original and often extremely funny, Force Majeure is a refreshing change from our steady cinema diet of mindless thrillers and charmless comedies.
Niccol draws us into the fine details of this hidden military world and airs some meaty arguments about the appliance of science to the act of killing.
The film is forgivably simplistic and sentimental but also stirring when it reminds us once again of the countless injustices from the Nazi era that can never be made right or forgotten.
It is undoubtedly beautiful, brooding and enigmatic, with Mortensen's grizzled presence holding the attention, but quite what it all means leaves you scratching your head in puzzlement.

Deeply embedded in a sense of local community and the familiar rhythms of the changing seasons, the grape harvest and annual festivals, Home from Home evokes the work of Thomas Hardy and the look of photographer Ansel Adams.
movie_title: Home from Home: Chronicle of a Vision (Die Andere Heimat) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Offers a solid, serviceable adaptation of Tom Rob Arthur's bestselling novel, the first in a trilogy featuring the character of idealistic state security operative Leo Demidov.
Intriguing and unsettling, The Falling eventually sacrifices some of its grip with a more conventional explanation of events but is still striking with a dreamy score by Tracey Thorn.
The bond between Carrie and these "lost boys" makes for a sincere, simplistic and poignant tale.
Proceeds without flashy tricks or showy technique, offering the pleasures of captivating storytelling with an irresistible human pulse.
A weary, half-hearted adaptation of a familiar Edgar Allan Poe short story that is largely devoid of chills or suspense.
The spectacular visuals and fights are the real stars.
Lovers of period drama should not feel disappointed but it does lack some of the wild passion and intensity required truly to capture your heart.
An awkward, heady mixture of science-fiction, soap opera, western and Greek tragedy but the quality of the performances and the cinematography render it better than you might have feared.
Overlong and leisurely, Samba is still a charmer thanks to the performances of the two stars.
A glum, ear-splitting rehash of familiar elements from The Hurt Locker and Saving Private Ryan with the slippery aliens as a side dish rather than a great threat.
It is fatally lacking in wit and conviction, often playing more like a television sitcom than something that deserves a place on the big screen.
A European animated feature that brings elements of Ice Age and Finding Nemo to the tale of Noah and the ark.
movie_title: All Creatures Big and Small (Ooops! Noah is Gone...) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: In the end it does not feel much different from an above-par television episode but then that is probably no bad thing and it does leave you wishing that British film-makers would make better use of an old reliable such as Peter Firth.
It is enchanting in parts but falls far short of becoming their sum.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It is the tearjerker sentimentality that is hard to stomach, in what is far from Van Sant's finest hour.

It is a Saturday morning matinee crossed with a Sunday service sermon but what really hits home is the thrill of the high-speed chases and the movie magic deployed to create a sense of awe and wonder.

It is a film suffused with compassion as it celebrates the inner strength and quiet defiance of individuals at the mercy of a world where a shared humanity becomes the first casualty when intolerance and hatred take hold.
There are imperfections in this Macbeth but it has a raw, haunting power that is hard to deny.
Avengers: Age Of Ultron is smart, nimble and recognises that the one way to make yet more scenes of mass destruction involving is to give the story behind them a little heart.
A melancholy morality tale that beautifully illustrates the folly of conflict and blind hatred.
The D Train has a great set-up but fumbles in the second half, going for easy laughs and obvious situations.
Bill is daft fun for all the family, plus there is the bonus of Damian Lewis as Sir Richard Hawkins.
[An] engaging but rather underwhelming affair.
Watchable and smartly executed but there is little chemistry between the two stars.
The film races through the endless flashbacks and clich√©d material and winds up feeling a bit of a potboiler.
This interminable farrago feels like swimming through a sea of excrement.
Director Adam McKay displays a little bit of Martin Scorsese's stylish swagger as he uses every possible means to make high finance seem sexy and compelling.
[A] relentlessly stylish, operatic parade of grotesque characters and wistful regret.
Spotlight is the kind of completely absorbing film that makes you think, makes you feel and keeps you on the very edge of your seat.
A decent, absorbing film but it all felt more urgent and compelling when it was unfolding on a daily basis on the news.

Harrowing scenes of carnage and death still fascinate Bay more than personal stories or political complexity so it makes for an exhausting watch that never lets up and rarely provides any contrast to the heat of battle.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Every half-hearted plot twist and supposedly startling jolt underlines just how feeble and derivative this all is. The end result is just silly rather than scary.
Goosebumps has a clever mixture of monsters, mayhem, comedy and romance that will remind parents of childhood favourites such as The Goonies, Gremlins or Jumanji.

Even if you know a lot about the period, Trumbo is still full of telling detail and Bryan Cranston's heartfelt performance as the remarkably driven and engagingly human Trumbo makes it well worth catching.
All the guilt, shame and anguish create a heady brew in an atmospheric but sometimes overwrought tale of a family in crisis.
Bullock is great fun as the brash, bossy empress of spin doctors and has a feisty chemistry with the snake-like Thornton.
Deadpan comedy and a sense of compassion mark this as a film to seek out and treasure.
An intelligent, insightful and very personal portrait of an artist.
Director Ericson Core has ditched the fun of the Patrick Swayze/Keanu Reeves original and replaced it with soulless action scenes.
You are constantly reminded of the old saying: 'The only thing necessary for the triumph of evil is for good men to do nothing.' An unshowy but utterly compelling documentary.
Deadpool has been a labour of love for star Ryan Reynolds and he is the reason to see the film.
Ralph Fiennes is the life and soul of the party in A Bigger Splash, which is just as well because it is a fairly dull party.
Will Smith embodies virtue and gritty determination as compassionate pathologist Dr Bennet Omalu in the true-life drama Concussion.
Blythe Danner has been acting for half a century but she has rarely had a part as good as Carol in I'll See You In My Dreams.
movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The film is disjointed and disappointing, leaving the view that Jane Austen and zombies do not make ideal bedfellows.
Silly but rarely funny.
Sadly, the film's monotonous pace, decision to forego the use of music and coolly detached manner becomes a tiresome combination even at a relatively trim running time.
If Franz Kafka had ever devised a film for the Three Stooges, it might look something like Men & Chicken.
All the surface razzle-dazzle can't quite conceal the lack of heart and soul underneath.

Freeheld is earnest and well-intentioned but often feels like it is trying to teach us all a lesson. It works best in the tender emotions of one woman facing the awful reality of losing the woman she loves.

Sticking doggedly to the tried-and-tested formula of the television comedy, this big-screen return is virtually a carbon copy of the original with the starry cast delivering spot-on imitations of their beloved predecessors.
Dragon Blade offers a daftly entertaining throwback to historical epics of the 1960s.
The best advice is not to dwell on the story but savour the graceful, lightning-fast bouts of fisticuffs.
The struggle unfolds in a predictable and nasty way in a film that is technically polished but way too long and tiresome.
[An] absorbing, affecting take on the many burdens of being human.
Ville-Marie is solid enough in places but lacks the flavour or punch of unexpected elements that would allow it to feel more distinctive.
Breathe offers ample evidence of the growing confidence and skill of Melanie Laurent as a director.
It is a bittersweet film but one with a surprising degree of warmth, a generosity of spirit and a sense of hope.
A measured, intelligent thriller that grows more gripping with each passing moment.
There hasn't been a more charming French film this year.
A perfectly respectable, well-crafted, slightly dull period piece.
The sincere performances, engaging music choices and confident direction all help confirm Ruizpalacios as a promising new voice in Mexican cinema.
It is interesting enough as a film history footnote and a story of obsession but slightly more compelling for the unflattering portrait it paints of McQueen.
movie_title: Steve McQueen: The Man & Le Mans (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Radiator may sound maudlin, even depressing but it is so true to life and true to itself that it ultimately emerges as life-affirming and very touching.
A quietly compelling Bulgarian drama that views the age of austerity through the tragic dilemmas of one victim.

Hypnotic but inevitably repetitive, The Show of Shows feels more like something you might dip into in a gallery context rather than consume in a single sitting but, at its best, offers an intriguing window into a lost world.
A mixture of thriller, courtroom drama and history lesson, Bridge Of Spies makes for a satisfying, entertaining movie. Jimmy Stewart and Gary Cooper would be proud.
The tale torn loyalties and brazen betrayals make for a solid thriller.
A sad heartbreaker of a film.
One of the best British films of the year.
Filled with fortune cookie wisdom this makes you appreciate just how good Love Actually is.
There are echoes of The Lion King, Bambi and much more in this simple coming-of-age story.
It's well worth seeking out.

Blending visual spectacle with complex moral dilemmas, Peedom has created a hard-hitting, wide-ranging documentary that captures a sense of the vital issues that will determine the future of Everest and the local communities.
A bracing, very entertaining little road movie with more grit and gumption than the subject matter might have suggested.
Russell lays it on pretty thick with Joy's quirky, suffocating family but Lawrence creates the kind of plucky underdog you are only too happy to cheer and Joy is a feelgood way to start the year.
Brie is bright and engaging but womanising, wisecracking Sudeikis seems awfully bland to be the object of so much desire.
If you want to know the cinema of Godard, then this is a great place to start.
A glum, heavy-handed state-of-the-nation drama ...
A painless concoction that glides along on the charisma of its star Sandra Bullock, in a role that was originally written for George Clooney.
A terrific surprise of a film.

The film is such an immersive experience that you can almost feel the mud under your feet, sense the chill on your skin and the danger that lurks around every corner of an untamed wilderness in the 1820s.
Told with intelligence and discretion, Room is distinguished by exceptional performances.
A formulaic comedy where the actors appear to be a good 10 years older than the characters they are playing.
A perfect introduction to a great American film-maker.
A film that offers a flat, low-key dramatisation of true events from more than 30 years ago.
It's not a magnificent seven but fans will certainly lap it up.
Emerges as a weighty, fitting salute to Wilson's restless creativity and a touching celebration of the love that would prove to be his salvation.
You appreciate that this is all part of Hartley's distinctive style but the laughter provoked is just as often at the absurdity of it all rather than because it is funny.
The film starts to drift and deteriorate into something perilously close to a trite, TV-movie tearjerker rather than something as harrowing and real as a Cassavetes drama.
A very enjoyable, soft-centred tale of guilty secrets, hidden lives and family ghosts.
An unpersuasive mixture of clunky family tearjerker and lazy crime caper.
This is a rousing, big-hearted British triumph that sweeps you along on a tide of bittersweet tears and hearty laughter.
Everyone becomes a pawn in a much larger game as this muted, low-key thriller weaves its tangled web.
The Boxtrolls has a few fun moments that children might enjoy and a great vocal cast that adults will appreciate including Nick Frost and Richard Ayoade as henchmen Mr Trout and Mr Pickles.
Never less than enjoyable but beneath the satirical swipe is quite a conservative film intent on wagging fingers and teaching lessons.

Lehane's punchy dialogue and the brooding atmosphere keep you watching even as you fear The Drop might not amount to anything substantial but this is a film that's just waiting to strike and tighten its screws.
Peter Strickland confirms his growing reputation as the champion of notoriously disreputable genres with The Duke Of Burgundy.

The dialogue bites and scratches and there is the sting of something like the truth in certain situations, but as the clunky plot laboriously joins the dots towards a melodramatic finale it all feels desperately obvious and not a little silly.
This is, above all, a celebration and as such is entertaining, informative and good fun.

The dramatic heft may feel a little light to some viewers but it is still hugely engaging and perceptive about the way one person can have a very different identity and presence in the lives of everyone close to them.
There is nothing in the old-fashioned The Rewrite that is unexpected but it has some funny one-liners and the smooth professionalism of Grant, Tomei and the able cast make it work.
The Keith and Holly relationship has an Educating Rita potential that is never fully explored or realised.
The film's sunny disposition and affirmative message are very appealing and only the coldest heart could resist rooting for the two boys to find their happy ending.
Entertaining enough but very mild.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This slow-burning Australian chiller is well-acted and often quite stylish but it feels awfully familiar and surprisingly tame by the time it reaches an anti-climax of an ending.
A breezy, affable adaptation of the Judith Viorst book.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Everything is so calculated and phoney that you don't believe a word of it.
Serena is an undoubtedly handsome production with some beautiful cinematography from Morten Soborg.
Imagine smashing open a giant Mexican pinata and watching the contents cascade to the ground in a riot of colour and tinsel. That's what Book Of Life feels like.
Fury is about the sheer hell of war and the knowledge that every moment could be your last.
Time-lapse photography, striking lighting, theatrical intensity and Bj√∂rk's infectious enthusiasm will make this an irresistible attraction for her many fans.
The plot is ropey but the soundtrack is fantastic. Whitehouse shows great screen presence and the likes of Steve Coogan, Ricky Tomlinson and Lisa Stansfield add some colour to the supporting roles.

What matters is the clash of the titans that took place over 12 days of interviews and the award-calibre performances from Sheen and especially Langella make the final confrontation edge-of-the-seat cinema.
Jesse Moss's documentary is as compelling and heartrending as any drama.
You can almost feel a trickle of sweat start to form as director Yann Demange and his crew evoke a nightmarish world in which trust is a luxury that only the foolish can afford.
It tugs at the heartstrings a little too vigorously and overstays its welcome but The Judge still passes muster as able mainstream entertainment and Downey Jr gives it edge and class.

The combination of Lehane's terse, punchy dialogue and cleverly constructed plot with Roskam's fondness for character and fresh eye for American locales makes for an idiosyncratic, slow-burning tale that ultimately satisfies.
The breezy tone of the early stages deepens into something more profound by the film's conclusion.
Gives us a sense of the childlike glee Guo-Qiang still finds in his work and of a family life scarred by China's Cultural Revolution of the 1960s.
movie_title: Sky Ladder: The Art of Cai Guo-Qiang (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Blood Ties is the kind of film that Martin Scorsese or Sidney Lumet might have made back in the 1970s.
A film that once again serves as a vast parking lot for used yesteryear action stars.
It is no less compassionate or political than we have come to expect from the brothers, although it is more sentimental than their early work.
A light, unexpected delight.
It risks curling the toes of non-believers but wins you over in the end by wearing its heart so boldly on its sleeve.
The Dark Knight takes the process a giant leap further, transforming a typical summer blockbuster into a brooding, unsettling reflection on the increasingly blurry boundaries between good and evil.
More sentimental and contrived than previous films from Belgian brothers Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne, this is still a topical and touching tale.
A competently handled but overly derivative spinetingler supposedly inspired by true events.
Cynics will find it toe-curling in its whimsicality but incurable romantics will be won over but its sweet sincerity.
The technology keeps advancing but the soap opera stories remain just as corny as ever in Into The Storm, a 1970s-style disaster movie dressed up with 21st century special effects.
The brutal, sadistic stories and mannered macho dialogue do grow tiresome, sapping the film of energy and interest.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Smart, sweet, entirely predictable and completely engaging, What If is the kind of fairytale romantic comedy that sends you out with a big goofy smile on your face.
Ridiculous stuff mostly but entertaining and Johansson is terrific.

More than 10 years have passed since Toy Story 2 but that lengthy absence has only increased the appetite for a further adventure and allowed the geniuses at Pixar to devise an inventive and satisfying story.
Measured and sparing in its use of dialogue and music, Mystery Road remains strikingly atmospheric and expertly controlled as Sen builds a sense of quietly escalating tension.
Incurable romantics will find it a polished and superior weepie that is earnest in its intentions and largely successful in its execution.
Lovers of tense, twisted Scandinavian thrillers will want to seek out The Keeper Of Lost Causes, a pacy, well-crafted adaptation of the Jussi Adler-Olsen bestseller.
movie_title: The Keeper of Lost Causes (Kvinden i buret) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Mystery Road may be set in modern Queensland but it has the feel of a flinty, slow-burning western as one stetson-wearing lawman stands against an entire community.
The quietly chilling thriller Night Moves deals eloquently with the burden of conviction as it follows three activists who embark on a dangerous plot to blow-up a hydroelectric dam in Oregon.
It all feels terribly feeble and no matter how energetic and broad the comedy mugging of Diaz and an ill-looking Segel it rarely raises a laugh. What a right old Carry On.

All interesting enough stuff set to some amazing images but it does become a little worthy and dull when it comes to celebrating Dr Patricia Wright and her efforts to ensure the survival of the species.
A darkly amusing tale begins promisingly but runs out of wit and energy long before the closing credits.
A rousing, blood and thunder mystery that works even better if you have yet to read the book.
Charming and exasperating in equal measure.
You can tell where all of this might be headed but that doesn't detract from the pleasure of a warmhearted, fairytale drama that doesn't need to be taken too seriously.
Suddenly, we seem to be trapped in a cheap, corny rehash of B-movie cliches from the 1980s and you can't wait for it to slink away into a corner and disappear.
A refined, languid period drama from the novel that is not without its flaws but impresses with its fastidious attention to detail, craftsmanship and oppressive atmosphere.
Audiences tickled and delighted by the initial premise are only likely to feel disappointed by the way it pans out.
An eccentric, energetic muddle of a film that is badly overcooked by commercials director Fredrik Bond.
The rescue itself packs an emotional punch but everything else about The Finest Hours feels a little dull and corny.
A worthy addition to landmark tales of journalistic ethics such as the Kirk Douglas classic Ace In The Hole and the Oscar-winning Network.
No great shakes.
It is unashamed tosh but at least director Sam Taylor-Johnson has fashioned it into tosh with a touch of class.

The easy charm of stars Miles Teller and Analeigh Tipton more than compensates for a screenplay that never quite bridges the divide between old-fashioned romance and the cruder tone that seems par for the course in modern comedy.
Unfortunately the elements that are fresh and intriguing are the very ones that receive the least attention.

In truth some of the clips are not that remarkable but what really makes them resonant is the dreamy, seductive music of Richard Hawley who adds shades of melancholy and wistfulness to all these moments of lost loves and young dreams.
movie_title: Love Is All: 100 Years of Love & Courtship (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This is close to perfection with Katharine Hepburn repeating her stage triumph as spoilt socialite Tracy Lord.
Coherence proves that you don't need a big budget to make a big impression. A few bright ideas are much more valuable.
The central character and performance are intriguing but not enough to sustain a film that feels more and more like a TV-movie matinee.
Factor in a scene-stealing dog called Uggy and you have one of the most unexpectedly delightful films of the past year.
The cast is strong, the characters are intriguing but the more you learn, the more the film loses its grip on your emotions.
It requires complete attention but the reward is a compelling, low-tech, existential sci-fi yarn with real heart and soul.
The fight against cyber-terrorism couldn't be more topical and the film is as stylish and strikingly well-made as we have come to expect from Mann.

Director Peter Strickland offers an affectionate, impeccably crafted salute to continental soft porn films of the 1970s crossed with something intense, theatrical and closely related to Jean Genet's The Maids.
A charmless, half-hearted combination of Bridesmaids and The Hangover that veers between a sentimental bromance and wacky antics in the worst possible taste.
There are a number of promising elements here, including the performance of Aymen Hamdouchi as Dave's best mate Tariq, but the film is flashy, uneven and shallow.
A frantic, sci-fi yarn where the likeable cast compensate for the underdeveloped plot and the shaky, handheld camera work.
Although The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel is hardly groundbreaking it offers a very welcome opportunity to renew acquaintance with the characters we met and fell in love with three years ago.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: There is such tender conviction in the performances and such easy assurance in the flowing camerawork and editing that you are obliged to concentrate even more fully on the substance rather than the style.
An absorbing, briskly handled account of true events with strong work from Jeremy Renner as swashbuckling, self-righteous reporter Gary Webb.

Chappie is an ambitious futuristic epic that struggles to balance its more philosophical elements with Blomkamp's cartoonish instinct to blow everything to smithereens. Not exactly subtle but still a watchable guilty pleasure.
Co-directors Wash Westmoreland and Richard Glatzer keep the film simple and straightforward, cutting to the core of the matter without the need to tug at the heartstrings.
Inspired by the suicide of poet Heinrich von Kleist in 1811, Amour Fou... immerses the viewer in a long gone age. There is an attention to detail and manners that is quietly absorbing.
A handsome, thoroughly respectable adaptation of the novel by Ir√®ne N√©mirovsky that became a bestseller 60 years after her death in Auschwitz.
This is the film of a full-blown romantic who believes in true love, happy endings and the importance of an absolutely fabulous wardrobe.
Curtis gives the performance of his career as he gets to grips with the troubled mind and generous heart of charismatic, true-life speed chess champion Genesis 'Gen' Potini.
It's a warm and insightful profile of the man and his movies that inevitably leaves you wanting to revisit some of his classics, or watch them for the very first time.
The film has its intellectual airs but it delivers witty one-liners, belly laughs and physical comedy.
Sometimes it works but more often it just feels corny and obvious.
A film all the more heartwarming because it is based in truth.

Positioned somewhere between a contemporary Romeo and Juliet and a fatalistic film noir, Catch Me Daddy marks a grimly impressive debut from music promo director Daniel Wolfe and his brother Matthew, who co-writes.
The stop-motion techniques used by Aardman animation remain as appealing as ever, giving life to Heath Robinson-style contraptions, clever visual gags and characters.
Bad taste jokes and a goofy bromance follow in an uninspired, unfunny romp.
Oyelowo is sensational in Selma. He makes you believe, body and soul, heart and mind, in his performance as Martin Luther King.
Christopher Nolan's epic is visually stunning and offers some ingenious ideas on time and space as it plays on our darkest fears about the end of life on Earth.
You know where 'Say When' is heading but this tale of pre-life crisis and arrested development has a dry wit and sharp lines thanks to screenwriter Andrea Seigel.
Filmed in black and white with a light, jazzy score courtesy of Gruff Rhys, Set Fire To The Stars offers a slice of biographical remembrance without a great deal of substance.
It is a beautifully written and expertly acted two-hander that takes dramatic licence with real historical events to create an urgent, compelling high-stakes drama.
The Imitation Game does justice to a great British hero and a story of incredible triumph against impossible odds.
This handsome looking film feels old-fashioned and stodgy.
A manic, mindless festive farrago that displays a casual regard for logic, stops every second for a bit of a song or dance and maintains an idiotic grin on its face through an interminable two hours.

Jennifer Lawrence holds everything together, ensuring by her sheer presence that you are willing to stick with it to the bitter end even as it feels that everything is in a holding position waiting for take off.
My Old Lady may be a little too neat and tidy, a little sentimental and soft-centred but it is also very, very enjoyable.
This strident, idiotic sequel is more like torture than entertainment - the cinematic equivalent of someone scratching their nails across a blackboard for the best part of two hours.
Michael Bond's bestselling books have been brought to life in a film that is slight, silly and awfully British but also warm, funny and just a little bit magical.
St Vincent is jaunty, fun-filled entertainment but the plot is on the ragged side and you'll need to forgive all the brazen tugging at the heartstrings.
Black Sea is well-crafted and handled with reliable professionalism by its Oscar-winning director Kevin Macdonald, even if it does ultimately tend towards the predictable.
The Circle is both a fascinating history lesson and a tender love story.
Once you adjust to the exuberant theatricality and goofy comedy it does start to grow on you.
The Hobbit: The Battle Of The Five Armies is a fantastic farewell to familiar characters and landscapes that blends spectacular action sequences with some touching human moments.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Gleeson is a delight and Farrell gives his best performance in ages, capturing both the unrepentant philistine and endearing vulnerability at war in the tormented Ray.
Undeniably beautiful and exciting even if its directors do err a little on the safe side.
A pedestrian, globe-trotting cloak-and-dagger yarn that was reportedly butchered in post-production, and which contains only intermittent flashes of the more interesting film that might have been.
The Last of the Unjust demands patience and commitment from the viewer but the reward is an utterly fascinating, spellbinding history lesson.
Every generation loses their heart to one great big weepie. Was it Love Story for you? Out Of Africa maybe? The Fault In Our Stars could well be the weepie of choice for this generation.
This is a true story of human endurance but also a poignant tale of a woman desperately seeking to conquer her demons and cleanse her spirit.
You need to take all of this with a large pinch of salt but the cast is game and it is as light as a souffl√©.
American Sniper is a typically thoughtful, unflashy Clint Eastwood production that respects Kyle's achievements while questioning the price he had to pay.
Simmons is unnervingly good as a teacher who rules by fear and the final showdown provides as gripping a climax as you will see all year.
Vikander brings a real sense of the inner rage and frustration Brittain must have felt as she constantly battled against the narrow expectations of her gender and class.
A heartwarming true story that has been expertly crafted into an irresistible, emotion-charged documentary.
A faithful adaptation of the Thomas Pynchon novel that feels as if a labyrinthine Raymond Chandler thriller has been thrown into a cocktail shaker with Alice In Wonderland.
It is ridiculously entertaining in parts but let down by a yawn of a plot and some fairly cheap looking effects work.
Horns is a very wacky, oil and water mixture of coarse black comedy and gory supernatural thriller.
This slick, soppy romantic ensemble has the snappy banter and skin-deep emotions of a television sitcom but the game cast make it passable if forgettable entertainment.
A measured, elegantly choreographed tale with Shu Qi convincingly capturing the steely determination and conflicted heart of the lethal, black-garbed assassin.
As a decent, involving thriller, it exercises the little grey cells and passes muster.
The levels of deception, delusion and denial were exhausting but they make for a spellbinding documentary.
Director Thomas Vinterberg has fashioned elements of his own childhood into a sentimental melodrama that might make a decent TV series.
Ryan O'Neal has the role of his career as Redmond Barry, an Irish rogue who lies, fights and sleeps his way to prominence in 18th century society.
Distance allows for a more measured perspective in this intelligent, carefully balanced documentary.
A barnstorming Brian Cox is the star attraction in The Carer, a sentimental, old-fashioned drama pitched somewhere between Sunset Boulevard and Ronald Harwood's The Dresser.
Brings a novel twist to the romantic comedy but spoils the fun by miscasting Oscar-winner Jean Dujardin.
movie_title: Up for Love (Un homme √† la hauteur) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's not a bad idea but the film is just another overblown, overstuffed epic, top heavy with special-effects and made even more chaotic by the abundance of largely unfamiliar characters.
It may feel a little too calculated and cloying at times but Sweet Bean still manages to tug successfully at the heartstrings.
It is a reminder of what a dynamic presence Gary Oldman was in his younger days as he captures the snarling attitude of punk idol Sid Vicious.
A sober, restrained production that ultimately delivers in a visceral, bullet-strewn climax.
It may be extremely slight and even too wholesome for modern tastes but Pete's Dragon is still welcome family fare.
The cast are game and full of energy but Efron and especially Anna Kendrick deserve better than this obnoxious material.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A charming, poignant film with a lovely score from Michael Nyman.
movie_title: Ingrid Bergman in Her Own Words (Jag √§r Ingrid) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Dory's story will not leave a dry eye in the cinema.
An offbeat supernatural drama with echoes of British classic Don't Look Now.
A real crowdpleaser of a film.
In the end, we are left with a powerful account of one man determined to make a difference in a country that is spiralling far beyond any individual's control.
It's hard to see the film winning David Brent a whole new army of admirers but loyal fans will be suitably outraged, amply amused and might even shed a little tear along the way.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's wholesome and sweet enough but a bit dull.
A film that leaves you with that sinking feline.
A gripping, offbeat period drama with a tremendous musical score from the great Scott Walker.
A very strange but utterly mesmerising documentary.

Steve Hoover's documentary never questions Mokhnenko's right to play God with people's lives but builds a powerful portrait of the way one man has made a difference in a country that is no longer master of its own future.
If you have enjoyed Almod√≥var classics such as All About My Mother or Volver then Julieta needs to go on your autumn must-see list.
There are some entertaining moments but little attempt to address the easily abandoned moral values of a venal duo who got rich at the expense of other people's suffering.
Hollywood's fondness for obnoxious comedies continues unabated with Bad Moms, another vulgar, mean-spirited affair.
Caf√© Society is very hit and miss with moments that delight and performances that strike all the right notes alongside a laboured, over-busy plot and elements that never quite gel.
The film's characters are more gullible than credible and its plot isn't exactly full of surprises.
Collet-Serra brings a touch of class, milking a decent amount of tension from a shameless B-movie premise.

The fist fights are bruising, the killings are ruthless, a heart-thumping car chase through the streets of Las Vegas is spectacular and a final showdown between Bourne and a figure from his past is suitably brutal.
A fine, thoughtful performance from Ethan Hawke is the star attraction in Born To Be Blue, a melancholy dip into the tortured life of jazz trumpeter Chet Baker.
All the accusations may be familiar but the cumulative effect is depressing in the extreme.
There isn't anything terribly new in The Conjuring 2 as furniture moves and vilelooking demons keep jumping out of the shadows but the acting and the craftsmanship make all the difference.
Often momentarily enchanting but lacks rhyme or reason as we wearily move between the three kingdoms and are left with enough loose ends to fill another book.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Malin Buska glides between fierce determination and giddy adolescent but the film fails to make the most of a potentially fascinating subject.
Unbelievable.
A handsomely crafted, slowburning tale that tries a little too hard to place its political themes at the forefront of the action.
An ironic, sun-kissed salute to teen spirit and a long, hot Biarritz summer of sex, seduction and damaging consequences.
It is undoubtedly corny, exceptionally cheesy and very American in its gung-ho simplicity but as escapist entertainment on an epic scale it is a guilty pleasure.
Spacey is on form, capturing Nixon's bulldog growl and his slippery manner. It is all very watchable but what it needs is a little less conversation and a lot more action.
Definitely one for uncritical, incurable romantics.
Remainder is a clever mindbender of a thriller in the manner of Memento and Inception.
The Meddler is undeniably corny but it is sweet, heartfelt and played to perfection by a very able cast.
Lurid, violent but very watchable.
A typically fast-paced riot of smart one-liners, clever visual gags and sentimental life lessons that warm the very cockles of your heart.
The Colony does generate some cheesy do-or-die tension in the final half hour, but most of the time it is hard to take seriously.
A deeply moving and unexpectedly uplifting film.
The plot may be a little predictable and melodramatic but the underlying depiction of the struggle to be true to yourself remains as relevant now as it was 40 years ago.
The joy of Men & Chicken is the way the absurdist comedy on the surface eventually gives way to the philosophical arguments that lie beneath.
Breezy, inoffensive entertainment.
A film that celebrates the joy of living and the strength of family ties, even if the family gene pool has been adulterated in the most spectacular way.
Talk of the presidency of Georges Pompidou and the clashes between rural and urban ground the film in the past but the struggle to be true to yourself is as relevant as ever.
Dire stuff with a mean-spirited, ugly script.
Ice Age: Collision Course is the fifth helping of an animated series that hit the law of diminishing returns a long time ago.
[A] powerful, thought-provoking documentary ...
Tumultuous social change is reflected in, and challenged by, intense personal experience in Summertime (La Belle Saison), an exuberant autobiographical piece from writer/director Catherine Corsini.

If you like flinty, offbeat Westerns, flavoursome dialogue and expert acting, then there's a fair chance you will relish Bone Tomahawk. But be warned, this slow, absorbing tale eventually turns savage and requires a cast-iron stomach.
A breezy, action-packed and affectionate addition to the long-running series.
A film that takes a great subject and turns it into something determined to send you to sleep.
movie_title: Ming Of Harlem: Twenty One Storeys In The Air (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It is a great premise with some mirthful moments but slight and lacking the depth or insight you might hope for.
If your local high street is a swill of foul-mouthed, drunken louts every weekend then K-Shop will definitely strike a chord.
Has Isabelle Huppert ever given a bad performance?
Smart ideas and political satire battle it out with relentless smut in a decidedly uneven affair.
Mild-mannered and vaguely amusing ...
Why was Noel Clarke ever considered one of the great hopes of British cinema?
A wonderful reminder of all our yesterdays.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Blair Witch Project inexplicably gave the whole world sleepless nights in 1999 but the latest sequel, imaginatively entitled Blair Witch, is unlikely to have a similar impact.

Attempts to bring a fresh perspective to the traditional film noir thriller but winds up falling back on all the old familiar cliches from world weary narration to flirtatious banter that falls far below the Bogart-Bacall benchmark.
Snowden may be unsurprising but it still emerges as a solid, old-fashioned biopic with a dynamic approach to a densely packed story.
La La Land really is as good as everyone claims. It is an irresistible, big-hearted valentine to starry-eyed dreamers and the enduring magic of the movies.
The end result may never dig too deep or address the bigger issues, but Deepwater Horizon is still a solid, often surprisingly restrained nailbiter of a disaster movie.
A Monster Calls is a coming-of-age tearjerker wrapped inside a web of fantasy and magic.
Gory and thought-provoking science fiction for people who wouldn't normally be caught dead, or undead, watching a zombie film.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The final showdown is actionpacked and well staged but we never really care about any of the characters, making this Magnificent Seven merely adequate.
A real charmer of a film.
A promising subject and good performances but Imperium doesn't make the most of either.
The film's heart is always in the right place but Mary often seems naive to the point of imbecility and the approach to her story is relentlessly schmaltzy.
An odd, stylish little film, reminiscent of Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind.
Often feeling like a loosely connected series of encounters the film has a measure of wit and charm but is decidedly lightweight.
There are elements of Harry Potter, X-Men and The Addams Family in a film that makes up for any lack of originality with large helpings of high spirits, visual flair and fizzy energy.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Urban Hymn may sound predictable but director Michael Caton-Jones holds the attention, showing that these two women with very different lives have more in common than we thought in a film that's well worth searching out.
It sounds the kind of story that should fire the blood and excite great passion but it is workmanlike and too worthy for its own good.
Two men learn about life, love and modern masculinity in a film full of strange sights, bright ideas and a tremendous amount of flatulence.
A solid cast in an old-fashioned disaster movie.
The result is sympathetic to Knox and leaves you with plenty to ponder.
A slightly grander version of the kind of trashy potboiler that might normally make a decent two-part ITV drama.
This surreal black comedy is populated by immoral, irreverent cops and grotesque villains and wears the influence of Quentin Tarantino and Elmore Leonard like a badge of honour.
Mel Gibson is back and he's madder than ever in Blood Father, a weary, B-movie thriller with intriguing parallels to the star's own life.
Louis Theroux makes a plucky attempt to crack the dark secrets of Scientology but mostly hits a brick wall in My Scientology Movie.
A thoughtful, affectionate documentary.
Gaudy outfits, copious nudity and repetitive jokes are the order of the day in this mind-numbing oddity.
A rousing documentary, with Noel Gallagher as executive producer and ample commentary from natural-born storytellers Noel and brother Liam.
You suspect the cinema world has not seen the last of Robert Langdon.
The dreamy film has plaintive and poignant moments but it never justifies an excessive running time or arrives at any significant conclusion.
A striking, powerful thriller.
Even if Cosmos deliberately eschews easy comprehension it remains involving and intriguing enough to keep the viewer on board.
A full-bodied, highly quaffable documentary.
A sweet crowdpleaser guaranteed to lift your spirits.
A stylish but silly science-fiction potboiler in the tradition of Frankenstein.

The cast are well chosen, with Cleau a steely femme fatale and Amalric conveying the desperation of a dumbfounded Julien as he succumbs to his fate like a man caught in a trap from which there is no escape.
What you don't expect is how deeply it cuts and how much you care about the characters and the people caught in the crossfire of their impossible dreams.
A tense, gripping salute to two lesser-known heroes of the war.
This plodding, workmanlike version of the story often leaves you wondering why they bothered.
Although The Blue Room is elegantly handled it has a very brief running time and ends up feeling rushed and sketchy rather than fully realised and satisfying.
What really makes it worth your attention is a grand adventure story full of heart.
The road trip has echoes of Little Miss Sunshine and there is heartache and hilarity ...
A lurid potboiler that no amount of surface style can salvage.
In many respects, Knox is no more sympathetic a figure than she was nine years ago, but perhaps the film allows us to be no longer blinded by all the fury that surrounded the case.
A sober, thoughtful documentary that combines a lament for a lost Eden with a rousing call to action.
Dynamic storytelling and powerful performances bring out the pathos in an unusual tale of conflicting loyalties set on the criminal edges of a travelling community.
